ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 3-1. - Abandoning of animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to abandon an animal within the city limits. The police chief, or designated representative may order the seizure and impoundment of any such abandoned animal. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 1-01, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-2. - Seizure of abused animals. 
    The animal control officer shall liberally utilize the authority granted by section 821.022 of the Texas Health and Safety Code to seize and impound any animal which appears to have been cruelly treated, pending a hearing before the Municipal Judge of the City of Portland, Texas on the issues of cruelty and disposition of the animal. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 1-02, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-3. - Safety of animals in motor vehicles; seizure of any cruelly treated animals pending justice court hearing. 
(a)  Animals in moving vehicles. No person shall transport, carry, or leave, on any public roadway, any animal in a motor vehicle, attachment, or accessory, unless the animal is safely enclosed within the vehicle, attachment, or accessory; and if traveling in an unenclosed vehicle (including but not limited to convertibles, pickup trucks, jeeps, and flatbed trucks), the animal shall be confined by a vented container or cage, by chain or rope or other device cross tied to prevent the animal from falling or jumping from the motor vehicle or from strangling on a single leash. 
(b)  Animals in parked vehicles; removal if endangered. No person shall leave any animal in any standing or parked vehicle in such a way as to endanger the animal's health, safety or welfare. Any animal control officer or police officer is authorized to use reasonable force, including the breaking of a side window, to remove an animal from a vehicle whenever it appears the animal's health, safety, or welfare is or soon will be endangered. The endangered animal shall be impounded. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 1-03, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-4. - Animal traps without holding mechanism. 
    Humane traps used to capture dogs, cats, and other small animals, alive shall be checked out at least once every twelve (12) hours by the individual setting the trap. Humane care shall be provided for any trapped animals including the provision of food, water and protection from extremes of the environment including heat, cold, and precipitation. Trapped animals bearing identification, and/or city registration shall be turned over to the city animal control facility or the animal's owner. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 1-04, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-5. - Enforcement. 
    Any person violating this chapter, upon conviction, is punishable by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). The fines normally assessed for the various violations may be reduced to one-third ( 1/3 ) for animals that have been neutered. 
(Ord. No. 893, Art. 8, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-6. - Injunction. 
    A person who is in violation of this chapter shall also be subject to a suit for injunction as well as possible prosecution for criminal violations. 
(Ord. No. 893, Art. 9, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-7-3-10. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CITY OF PORTLAND LICENSE TAGS 

Sec. 3-11. - Required. 
    Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to own, possess, or harbor any dog three (3) months of age or over or any cat three (3) months or older in the city unless such dog or cat is tagged in accord with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2-01, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, § 1, 8-19-03) 
Sec. 3-12. - Application. 
    Application for a dog or cat license tag shall be filed in the office of the animal control officer or authorized veterinarian on a form provided for that purpose. This application shall hive the full name, residence and telephone number of the applicant and the breed, sex, age and color of the dog or cat. It shall be the responsibility of the owner to notify the animal control officer, within thirty (30) days of any changes in the owner's address or telephone number. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2-02, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-13. - Rabies vaccination prerequisite to issuance. 
    No dog or cat license tag shall be issued unless the applicant presents an approved NASPHV Rabies Vaccination Certificate stating that the dog or cat has been properly immunized against rabies during the previous twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2-03, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-14. - Fee. 
(a)  Before the issuance of a license tag, the animal control officer or authorized agent shall collect from each applicant a license fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each dog and cat. 
(b)  Identification tags issued by participating veterinarians will also be five dollars ($5.00) for each dog or cat. The veterinarians shall withhold two dollars ($2.00) for administrative purposes. The remainder of the fee will be forwarded to the city. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2-04, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, § 1, 8-19-03) 
Sec. 3-15. - City of Portland animal license tags. 
(a)  Upon the registration of a dog or cat, the animal control officer or authorized veterinarian shall deliver to the applicant a metal tag which shall bear a serial number, together with the words "Dog-or-Cat License Tag, Portland, Texas", and such serial number shall be inscribed upon the license receipt so issued. Such metal tag shall be attached to the dog or cat for which it is issued by means of a substantial collar or harness and no person shall remove any such tag from any dog or cat without the consent of the owner or of the person to whom the tag is issued. No tag shall be used on the collar or harness of any dog or cat other than that for which the tag was issued. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, harbor or possess any dog three (3) months old and over, or a cat three (3) months old and over, that does not at all times wear a collar or harness with the metal tag attached as provided in subsection (a). 
(c)  If a dog or cat tag is lost, the animal control officer may issue a duplicate, if the owner or the dog or cat for which the tag was issued presents a certificate showing that the dog or cat was immunized against rabies as required by this article, along with proof of the prior registration of the dog or cat, and pays one dollar ($1.00). 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2-05, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, § 1, 8-19-03) 
Sec. 3-16. - Term. 
    A dog or cat license tag shall be good for one (1) year and shall be renewed upon expiration. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2-06, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-17. - Reciprocity with other municipalities. 
    Any person who is the owner of a dog or becomes the owner of a dog, or cat after the first day of January of any year, which dog is three (3) months of age or older, or which cat is three (3) months or older, and which has been previously licensed by another municipality, shall, upon residing in this city or within thirty (30) days thereof, report to the animal control officer, giving the full name and residence of the owner of such dog or cat and the breed, sex, age, color and special markings, if any, of the dog or cat, the license number of tag previously issued for the dog or cat, the name of the municipality issuing the same, and a certificate acceptable to the city, stating that the dog or cat has been properly immunized during the calendar year for which the license was issued. Upon compliance with the provisions of this section, such owner shall not be required to secure a tag for such dog or cat, for the balance of the calendar year for which the tag was issued by the other municipality. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 2-07, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, § 1, 8-19-03) 
Secs. 3-18-3-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LIVESTOCK AND OTHER DOMESTIC ANIMALS 

Sec. 3-21. - Running at large prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper or person in charge of any horse, mule, jack, jenny, cattle, swine, sheep, goat or similar animal to allow or permit the same to run at large within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-01, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-22. - Location of stables, pens, etc. 
    Every animal referred to in section 3-21 shall be kept in a stable, shed, pen or other enclosure and every such stable, shed, pen or other enclosure shall be distant at least two hundred (200) feet from every adjoining lot in any residential district, as such district may have been duly designated and defined under the zoning ordinance, and regulations enacted by the city council, and every stable, shed, pen or other enclosure, wherever located within the city for the keeping of such animals, shall be distant at least fifty (50) feet from every building or structure used for sleeping, dining and living. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-02, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-23. - Staking upon or within reach of public property. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to stake any livestock for the purpose of grazing upon or within the reach of any public street, alley, sidewalk or park within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-03, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-24. - Impoundment and sale. 
(a)  The police chief, or designated representative shall take up or cause to be taken up any livestock found running at large within the limits of the city in violation of this article and shall impound any such animal in a suitable place provided for that purpose. 
(b)  The police chief, or designated representative shall, within three (3) days after any livestock is impounded under this section, post three (3) notices, one (1) at the county courthouse, one (1) at the city hall, and one (1) in some other place, giving therein a full description of such animal and stating a date and place of sale of such animal, which date of sale shall not be less than five (5) days from the date of posting notice. Such animal shall be sold at public auction to the highest bidder for cash. 
(c)  The police chief, or designated representative shall collect a fee of forty dollars ($40.00) per head for taking up and impounding an animal under this section, and twenty dollars ($20.00) a day for feeding and taking care of such animal and twenty dollars ($20.00) per head for selling such animal which fees so collected shall be paid over to the general fund. After deducting the fees for impounding, keeping and selling the animal, the police chief, or designated representative shall return the balance of such sale, if any, to the owner. If the owner fails to call for such amount within fifteen (15) days from the date of sale, then he shall pay the same over to the general fund. At any time within six (6) months after any sale, the owner may apply to the police chief, or designated representative and, upon satisfactory proof of ownership, he shall be entitled to receive the amount deposited on account of such sale, after paying such costs as may be necessarily incurred to establish his/her rights thereto. 
(d)  The owner of any animal impounded under this section may reclaim the same from the city animal control facility at any time before sale by paying all fees and expenses of taking up and keeping such animal. 
(e)  At any time within six (6) months from the date of sale, the owner of any animal impounded and sold under the provision of this section shall have the right to redeem the same by paying to the purchaser thereof double the amount paid by such purchaser for such animal and the reasonable expenses incurred in keeping the same, as determined by the city. 
(f)  The police chief, or designated representative shall keep a book in which he shall record a description of all animals impounded under this section, the date of impounding, the date of sale, the amount realized from the sale, the fees and expenses due for impounding and keeping the animal, the name of the owner, if known, and the name of the purchaser. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-04, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-25. - Fowl running at large prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person raising or keeping chickens, turkeys, geese, guineas, ducks, pigeons, or other fowl to permit or allow the same to run at large or be at large within the limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-05, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-26. - Pens or other enclosures for fowl. 
    It shall be the duty of every person raising or keeping chickens, turkeys, ducks, geese, guineas, pigeons, or other fowl to keep them in a pen, coop, or enclosure, and such pen, coop, or enclosure shall be distant at least fifty (50) feet from every building or structure used for sleeping, dining or living, and shall be kept in a sanitary condition, and shall also be kept in such a manner as will be reasonably calculated not to become offensive to adjacent neighbors or to the public. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-06, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-27. - Pens or other enclosures for rabbits, guinea pigs, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of every person raising or keeping rabbits, guinea pigs, white rats, white mice, hamsters and other small animals to keep such animals in a pen, coop or enclosure, and such pen, coop, or enclosure shall be kept in a sanitary condition. The keeping of such animals shall not create a nuisance by means of odors, noise, or unsanitary practices or pose a public health hazard. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-07, 11-15-94) 
Secs. 3-28-3-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DOGS 

Sec. 3-31. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this article, the "owner" of a dog is any person who permits or suffers such dog to remain on his/her premises for the space of five (5) days or longer. The term "reasonable control," as used in this article, means that a dog is held securely by a leash of suitable length and strength, and is maintained under control by the owner thereof or some other responsible person, or is confined in a shipping receptacle or automobile. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 3-08, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-32. - Immunization. 
    Every dog within the city limits of the City of Portland, over the age of three (3) months shall have been vaccinated against rabies within the past twelve (12) months by a licensed veterinarian and the owner shall have an approved NASPHV Rabies Vaccination Certificate stating such. 
    No dog license shall be issued unless the applicant presents to the animal control officer or authorized representative an approved certificate stating that the dog has been properly immunized against rabies during the previous twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-02, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, § 2, 8-19-03) 
Sec. 3-33. - Running at large prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner of any dog to allow such dog to run at large or stray beyond the premises of the owner, unless such dog is under reasonable control. As used in this article, the "premises of the owner" is defined as being that area contained within the owner's residential structure or within the limits of a gated, fenced area adjacent to the owner's residential structure and sufficient in nature to confine the dog or dogs. As used in this article, "premises of the owner" shall not include the area between the front walls of the residential structure and the city street in front of the residential structure. As used in this article, "reasonable control" is defined as chained in the rear yard of the residential structure or on a leash as described in section 3-31 above. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-03, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 925, § 1, 9-17-96) 
Sec. 3-34. - Liability for damages caused by dogs in public places. 
    Every owner of a dog shall be liable for damages for any and all injuries to persons or property that may be caused by such dog. Such damages to be determined and collected in appropriate legal proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-04, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-35. - Noisy dogs and conditions that are a nuisance. 
    No person shall harbor or keep any dog that, by loud or frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling, shall cause an annoyance to the neighborhood. No person shall harbor or keep any dog without collecting and disposing of, in a sanitary manner, all feces, trash and debris related to the dog or caused by the dog's activities. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-05, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-36. - Dangerous animals defined as: 
(a)  Any animal, which because of its physical nature and aggressive propensity, is capable of inflicting serious physical harm or death to human beings; or 
(b)  Any animal which has behaved in such a manner that the owner thereof knows or should reasonably know that the animal is possessed of tendencies to attach or bite human beings or other animals; or 
(c)  Any animal certified by a Doctor of Veterinary Medicine, after observation thereof, as posing a danger to human health or safety, animal life, or is likely to be destructive of property based upon a reasonable medical probability; or 
(d)  Any animal that commits an unprovoked attack on a person or animal; or 
(e)  Any animal that threatens or attempts or displays intent to commit an unprovoked attack upon a person. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-06, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-37. - Dog kennels. 
(a)  Term defined. As used herein, the term, "dog kennel" shall mean: 
(1)  Any building, lot, yard, shed or other place on or in which five (5) or more dogs more than six (6) months old are kept; or 
(2)  Any building, lot, yard, shed or other place on or in which one (1) or more dogs are housed or boarded for pay. 
(b)  Kennels prohibited unless permit obtained. Any dog kennel in City of Portland is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is hereby prohibited, unless the owner there shall have obtained the permit described in paragraph (c) below. 
(c)  Permit generally; fee. Any owner of a dog kennel may make application to the police chief or designated representative for a dog kennel license entitling the applicant to keep or operate a dog kennel. Such license shall be issued by the city animal control officer or his/her authorized agent upon a proper form which has been signed and approved by the police chief, or designated representative showing that the dog kennel has met the basic requirements set forth in paragraph (d) below. The animal fee to be paid for such dog kennel license shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00). Such license shall be valid from one (1) calendar year from the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked. 
(d)  Requirements for issuance of license: revocation: administrative hearing. No dog kennel license shall be issued by the city animal control officer or authorized agent unless such kennel is located more than fifty (50) feet from any residence or property line, and more than one hundred fifty (150) feet from the property line of any food processing establishment or food service establishment, and is in a clean and sanitary condition. Any person operating a dog kennel shall keep such kennel at all times in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall not permit the same to become a nuisance. The failure to maintain a kennel in accordance with these standards shall be cause for revocation of the dog kennel license. The City of Portland may revoke the dog kennel license at any time for cause upon findings of a violation of this section at an administrative hearing before the city manager or his/her designee. Such hearing shall not be held except upon written notice as set forth below. The licensee shall be entitled to be heard in his or her own defense and to present evidence at said hearing. 
(e)  Failure to comply. The city manager or designee may hold an administrative hearing to determine whether any license issued pursuant to this section should be revoked, or to otherwise regulate the keeping of an animal within the city. Any license holder that refuses or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter, the regulations promulgated by the city regarding health, any law governing the protection and keeping of animals, or any owner of any unlicensed kennel, shall all be deemed in violation of this chapter. 
(f)  Notice of hearing. No such administrative hearing shall be held without giving the license holder, or owner of any unlicensed kennel, prior written notice of the date, time and place of hearing. Written notice shall be deemed made when a certified letter, return receipt requested, addressed to the address indicated in the holder's last license application or, if no such application is on file, to the owner's last known address, is deposited in the U.S. mail. Written notice shall also be deemed made when the notice letter is delivered by an employee or representative of the city to such address. 
(g)  Determination of hearing. At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the city manager or designee shall determine if the person holding the license, or the owner of an unlicensed kennel, has violated any provision of this chapter, the regulations promulgated by the city manager or designee, or any law governing the protection and keeping of animals. If any such violation has been found to have occurred, the city manager or designee, may at their discretion, order the facility in violation to be closed and prohibited from holding or boarding animals. 
(h)  Refusal to issue or revocation. If an applicant has withheld or falsified any information on an application, the city animal control officer may refuse to issue a license or may revoke any license issued in connection with such application. 
(i)  Prior convictions. No person who has been convicted within the preceding sixty (60) months of cruelty to animals under the animal cruelty laws of this city, state, or any other jurisdiction in the United States shall be issued a license. 
(j)  Reapplication: fee. Any person having been denied a license for any reason other than paragraph (f) above may not reapply for a period of ninety (90) days after such denial. Persons denied a license under paragraph (g) above may not reapply during the sixty-month period specified therein. Each reapplication shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable ten dollar ($10.00) fee. 
(d)  Exception for veterinary hospitals or clinics. This section shall not be construed to require veterinary hospitals or clinics operated by licensed veterinarians to obtain kennel licenses, if all of the operations and animal holding areas of such hospital or clinic are enclosed within a building. 
(l)  Issuance deemed waiver for inspection. The issuance of a kennel license shall be deemed a waiver by the licensee permitting the access to an inspection of the licensed premises by the animal control officer or designee during reasonable hours for the purpose of ensuring compliance with paragraph (d). 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-06, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, § 2, 8-19-03) 
Sec. 3-38. - License for dogs kept in kennel and not removed therefrom. 
    Dogs that are kept in a licensed kennel and not removed therefrom, except for breeding and for show purposes, shall not be required to wear a collar or harness bearing a metal individual license tag. Dogs of four (4) months of age or older removed from a licensed kennel for other than breeding and show purposes, shall wear, on a collar or harness, an individual metal license tag which the kennel owner shall obtain from the city animal control officer or his/her authorized agent by presenting an approved certificate showing the dog has been immunized against rabies, during the previous twelve (12) months and such license shall be valid for the remainder of the calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-08, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-39. - Removal of dogs under four months of age. 
    The animal control officer shall be informed, by written notice from the owner of a licensed kennel, when a dog under the age of four (4) months is removed from the kennel because of change in ownership of the dog. Such written notice shall include the age, breed, sex and color of the dog, and name and address of the new owner of the dog. Such dog need not be immunized against rabies prior to removal of the kennel. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 4-09, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - CATS 

Sec. 3-41. - "Owner" defined. 
    For the purpose of this article, the "owner" of a cat is any person who permits or suffers such cat to remain on premises for the space of five (5) days or longer. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 5-01, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-42. - Responsibility for cats. 
    It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person or household to own, possess or harbor any cat or cats that are a nuisance as defined in section 3-62(9) of this chapter. In such cases, section 3-55 of this chapter shall apply to the animal or animals creating the nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 5-02, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1160, § 1, 12-5-06) 
Sec. 3-43. - Immunization. 
    Every cat within the city limits of the City of Portland, over the age of four (4) months, shall have been vaccinated against rabies within the past twelve (12) months by a licensed veterinarian. 
    No City of Portland cat license shall be issued unless the applicant presents to the animal control officer or authorized representative an approved certificate stating that the cat has been properly immunized against rabies during the previous twelve (12) months. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 5-03, 11-15-94) 
Secs. 3-44-3-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ANIMAL BITES, RABIES, AND ANIMAL CONTROL FACILITIES 

Sec. 3-51. - Confinement of dogs or cats for rabies observation. 
    Any person who has possession of a dog or cat that has contracted rabies or that has been subjected to same or that is suspected of having rabies or that has bitten any person shall, upon demand of the city animal control officer, produce and surrender such dog or cat to the city animal control officer to be held for observation in either the local animal control facility or in an accredited veterinary hospital, the boarding cost of which shall be borne by the owner of such dog or cat. Such dog or cat shall be so held for ten (10) days or until its release is authorized by the animal control officer or a licensed veterinarian. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6-01, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-52. - Keeping a dog or cat that has been bitten by rabid animal. 
    No person shall keep or harbor any dog or cat that has been bitten by an animal known to have been afflicted with rabies. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6-02, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-53. - Notice to city when dog or cat is bitten by animal suspected to be rabid. 
    It shall be the duty of any person owning or harboring a dog or cat that has been attacked or bitten by another dog or cat or any other animal showing the symptoms of rabies to immediately notify the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6-03, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-54. - Notice to city when a dog or cat bites or scratches a person. 
(a)  If any animal within the corporate limits of the city shall bite or scratch any person or so injure any person as to cause an abrasion of the skin, and such facts be known to the owner of such animal, such owner shall immediately give his/her name and address, together with the animal's license tag number to the person so bitten or injured, provided that the person so bitten or injured is over the age of eighteen (18) years. If the person so bitten or injured is under the age of eighteen (18) years, then such required information shall be given to a parent or guardian of such person. In addition thereto, the owner of such animal shall immediately thereafter, and in no event later than twenty-four (24) hours thereof, notify the police department and the local health authority, giving his/her name, animal's license tag number, the name of the victim and any other information that the police department and local health authority may require. 
(b)  The owner of any animal within the corporate limits of the city which has bitten or scratched so as to cause an abrasion of the skin shall on demand of the local health authority, or any animal control officer or police officer of the city, surrender such animal to the animal control facility or to a licensed veterinarian hospital for observation for a period of no less than ten (10) days, subject to the provisions of subsection (1) below. 
(1)  The owner of an animal that has bitten or scratched any person shall be allowed to assume personal responsibility for confining the animal so as to prevent further exposure to humans or other animals during the observation period of ten (10) days, only under the following circumstances. 
a.  Separate facilities must be available at the home of the animal's owner, and must be approved by the local health authority, and 
b.  The animal is currently vaccinated against rabies, and 
c.  The animal was not in violation of any laws or ordinances at the time of the bite, and 
d.  The animal control officer or licensed veterinarian must observe the animal at least on the first, and last days of the quarantine period. If the animal becomes ill during the observation period the local health authority must be notified by the person having possession of the animal. At the end of the observation period, the release from quarantine must be accomplished in writing by the veterinarian. 
(2)  If an animal is believed to have rabies or has been bitten by an animal suspected of having rabies, such animal shall be quarantined for observation by a veterinarian for the appropriate period. 
(3)  The violation of the observation confinement of the biting animal as provided in subsection (1) shall be just cause for seizure and confinement of the animal in the animal control facility of the city. 
(4)  No wild animals will be placed in quarantine. All wild animals involved in biting incidents will be humanely euthanized in such a manner that the brain is not mutilated. The brain shall be submitted to a Texas Department of Health certified laboratory for rabies diagnosis. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any owner within the corporate limits of the city to conceal, sell, give away or otherwise dispose of an animal that has bitten or scratched another animal or a human, or to otherwise permit the animal to be taken beyond the corporate limits of the city after having knowledge of the animal's having bitten or having so injured another animal or a person as to cause an abrasion of the animal's or person's skin until such animal is released by the local health authority. 
(d)  The owner of any animal infected with rabies or who reasonably suspects his/her animal of having such an infection shall notify the police department or the animal control facility of the fact that his/her animal has been exposed to rabies. The local health authority is empowered to have such animal removed from the owner's premises to the animal control facility, or at the request of the owner, said animal may be placed in the veterinary hospital, and shall be placed under observation for a period of ten (10) days. Whether confined in the animal control facility or the veterinary hospital, the owner shall bear the expense of the confinement. 
(e)  Any animal surrendered to the animal control facility for the purpose of observation as provided in this article shall be kept at the facility and shall be fed and cared for at the expense of the owner for a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per day. Such fee is to be paid to the city before the animal can be reclaimed from the animal control facility at the end of the authorized quarantine and observation period. 
(f)  No animal shall be released from the observation period provided for in this article unless a licensed veterinarian certifies in writing to the local health authority that such animal is not showing symptoms of rabies. Exemption from placing such animal in the animal control facility or in a veterinary hospital as provided [in this] section shall not exempt such owner from securing a proper release, as provided above. 
(Ord. No. 893, 6-04, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, 3, 8-19-03; Ord. No. 2084, § 1, 3-4-14) 
Sec. 3-55. - Impoundment generally. 
(a)  The city shall provide an animal control facility and it shall be the duty of the animal control officer and every other person who may be employed by the city for that purpose to promptly seize, take up and place in such animal control facility all dogs or cats running at large or being kept or harbored in any place within the city contrary to the provisions of this article, and any dog or cat not being kept on the premises of the owner as described in Articles IV and V, and noisy dogs or any dogs that cause or are a nuisance as defined by sections 4-34 and 4-35, and any dangerous vicious dogs as defined in section 4-36. The animal control officer and any other person employed by the city for that purpose, shall be authorized to enter any public or private premises, other than the premises of the owner, to seize any dog or cat that the officer has observed violating this article or against which a complaint has been filed in the municipal court. 
(b)  No dog or cat shall be released from the animal control facility unless the owner or person entitled to claim the same shall pay to the city a fee as set forth in the following schedule: 
(1)  The fee for release of a dog or cat that has been immunized against rabies within the previous twelve (12) months and has a current dog or cat license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the day of impoundment plus the cost of boarding the dog or cat, which cost is hereby set at fifteen ($15.00) per additional day. 
(2)  The fee for the release of a dog or cat that does not have a current city license or has not been vaccinated for rabies within the previous twelve (12) months prior to impounding shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the day of impoundment, plus the cost of boarding the dog or cat, which cost is hereby set at fifteen dollars ($15.00) per additional day. 
a.  The person receiving a dog or cat herein shall pay an additional ten dollar ($10.00) rabies vaccination fee if the dog or cat has not been vaccinated within the previous twelve-month period. 
b.  The person receiving a dog or cat herein shall pay an additional five dollar ($5.00) city license fee if the dog or cat has not been licensed within the previous twelve-month period. 
(3)  The chief of police will administer a process by which the person paying the rabies vaccination fee or city license fee may obtain the vaccination and/or license through a partnership with local veterinarian(s). 
(4)  Any person who receives a dog or cat as described herein and pays a vaccination or license fee shall have the dog or cat vaccinated and/or licensed and provide proof to the animal control officer within ten (10) days of the release. 
(c)  Any dog or cat seized by the animal control officer and impounded three (3) or more times shall be deemed a public nuisance and the city and/or private parties may bring appropriate action to abate such nuisance. 
(d)  Dogs or cats not claimed and released within seventy-two (72) hours after being impounded may be adopted or destroyed or otherwise disposed of. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6-05, 11-15-94; Ord. No. 1079, § 3, 8-19-03; Ord. No. 2080, § 1, 12-3-13) 
Sec. 3-56. - Animal control facility records and reports; disposition of money collected at animal control facility. 
    The employees of the animal control facility shall keep a record of all seizures and the collection of all fees and other monies. Daily reports shall be made to the city secretary, such reports to include all fees collected, and the first working day of each month a monthly summary of the activities of the employees of the animal control facility shall be made to the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6-06, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-57. - Care of sick and injured animals. 
(a)  Injuries defined. 
(1)  Minor injuries. 
a.  Animal is mobile. 
b.  Minor cuts or scrapes. Bleeding is minor and not life threatening. 
c.  No pain is evident. 
(2)  Serious injuries. 
a.  Serious cut or scrapes. Bleeding that is life threatening. 
b.  Bone breaks that are evident. 
c.  Pain is evident. 
(3)  Massive or unrecoverable injuries. 
a.  Animal is not mobile. 
b.  Internal bleeding evidenced by bleeding from a place other than a cut and in massive amounts. 
c.  Evisceration of any body cavity is evident. 
d.  Massive bone damage in or around body cavities. 
(4)  All the above are guidelines only and judgment calls are necessary by a certified animal control officer. 
(b)  Any cat or dog that is wearing a license of identification that is seriously injured at the time it comes into the possession of animal control officer, will be taken for treatment by a veterinarian. The purpose will be for stabilization and administering of pain alleviating medication. These animals shall be held at the city animal shelter for the holding period prescribed by City Ordinance, if this can be done without excessive pain to the animal. 
(c)  Any dog or cat that has massive or unrecoverable injuries as determined by veterinarian or certified animal control officers may be immediately euthanized. 
(d)  Any dog or cat that has serious injuries as determined by a veterinarian or certified animal control officers, and is not wearing a tag of identification may be immediately euthanized. 
(e)  Any dog or cat that is determined by a veterinarian or certified animal control officer to be in poor and evident neglected condition, and appears to be seriously ill or appears to be in pain, and is not wearing any means of identification may be euthanized after twelve (12) hours. 
(f)  Before any dog or cat is released by animal control officers, the owner or person to whom the dog or cat is released shall pay all veterinarian and medical expenses, in addition to any animal shelter fees that may apply. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 6-07, 11-15-94) 
Secs. 3-58-3-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PROHIBITED ANIMALS 

Sec. 3-61. - "Prohibited animals" defined. 
    No person shall keep, own, maintain, use, or have in such person's possession or on premises under such person's control within the city any of the following: 
(1)  Any vicious or dangerous animal. 
(2)  Any livestock or fowl, except in accordance with Article III of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Portland, Texas. 
(3)  Any prohibited animal as defined under section 3-62(7), except those which, on the effective date of this article, are present within the city and are owned by a person who makes application to the city manager or designee for a prohibited animal permit on or before forty-five (45) days after passage of this article, and who has been granted a prohibited animal permit pursuant to regulations promulgated by the city manager or designee and on file with the city secretary: 
a.  The city manager or his/her designee shall notify by certified mail all property owners within five hundred (500) feet of the applicant's property lines of the intent to keep the animal on the property of an applicant to ensure that there is an opportunity to object to issuance of a permit. If more than fifty (50) percent of the neighbors file individual objections to the keeping of this animal with the city manager or his/her designee, the city manager shall deny the permit. Such denial by the city manager may be appealed by the applicant to the city council. 
b.  Any applicant for such permit or renewal must also provide public liability insurance naming the city as additional insured in the amount of at least two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for personal injury and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage. Such policy must contain the statement that the insurance company shall give the city at least ten (10) days advance written notice prior to cancellation of such insurance coverage. Further, each such applicant shall agree to indemnify the city, its officials and employees against any damage or injury caused by the applicant's prohibited animal or any liability whatsoever incurred in relation to the granting or renewal of any prohibited animal permit by the city. 
c.  Each application or renewal of a prohibited animal permit shall be accompanied by a filing fee of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). Such filing fee is not refundable. 
d.  A prohibited animal permit shall be valid for one (1) year after the date of issuance unless earlier revoked. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 7-01, 11-15-94) 
Sec. 3-62. - Definitions generally. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words have the meanings herein ascribed to them: 
(1)  Animal: Any living vertebrate creature, domestic or wild, other than Homo Sapiens. 
(2)  Food processing establishment: A commercial establishment in which food is manufactured or packaged for human consumption. 
(3)  Food service establishment: Any place where food is prepared and intended for individual portions service, including the site at which individual portions are provided. The term includes any such place regardless of whether consumption is on or off the premises and regardless of whether there is a charge for the food. The term also includes delicatessen-type operations that prepare sandwiches intended for individual portion service. The term does not include private homes where food is prepared or served for individual family consumption, the location of vending machines, or food supply vehicles. 
(4)  Fowl: Any live bird. 
(5)  Livestock: Horses, Shetland ponies, mules, donkeys, cattle, goats and sheep. 
(6)  Owner: Any person owning, keeping or harboring one (1) or more animals. An animal shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered. 
(7)  Prohibited animal: Any animal not normally born and raised in captivity, including, but not limited to, the following: 
a.  Class Reptiles: Family Helodermatidea (the venomous lizards) and all Varanidae (monitor); order Ophidia, family Boidoe (boas, pythons, anacondas) family Hydrophiidae (marine snakes); family Viperidae (rattlesnakes, pit vipers and true vipers); family Elapidae (coral snakes, cobras and mambas); family Colubridae, Dispholidus Typus (boomslang), Cyclagras gigas (water cobra), Boiga dendrophila (mangrove snake) and Kertlandii (twig snake) only, order Crocodilia (crocodiles, alligators and gavials); 
b.  Class Aves: Order Falconiforms, (such as hawks, eagles and vultures) and subdivision Rapitae (such as ostriches, rheas, cassowaries and emus); 
c.  Class Mammalia: Order Carnivora, (the family felidae) except household cats: the family Canidae (such as wolves, dingos, coyotes and jackals), except dogs: the family Mustelidae (such as weasels, skunks, martins, mink badgers): family procyonidae (raccoon); family Ursidae (such as bears); and order Marsupialia (such as kangaroos, opossums); order Chiroptera (bats); order Edentata (such as sloths, anteaters and armadillos); order Proboscidea (elephants); order Primata (such as monkeys, chimpanzees and gorillas); order Rodentia (such as porcupines); and order Ungulata (such as antelope, deer, bison and camels); 
d.  Class Amphibia: Poisonous frogs. 
e.  Prohibited animal: Includes all animals except livestock, fowl, poultry or normal household pets, such as a psittacine bird, canary, finch, cockatiel, hamster, guinea pig, gerbil, rabbit, ferret, fish or small nonpoisonous reptiles. 
(8)  Provocation: Any purposeful act that causes an animal to bite, scratch or attack in protection of self, owner or owner's premises. Entrance, in any manner, into an area where an animal is properly under restraint in compliance with City Ordinances would be considered provocation, irrespective of the reason for such entrance. 
(9)  Public nuisance: Any animal or group of animals which: 
a.  Is vicious; 
b.  Trespasses on school grounds; 
c.  Is repeatedly at large; 
d.  Damages private or public property; or 
e.  Barks, whines, howls or makes any annoying noises in an excessive, continuous or unreasonable fashion, or at unreasonable hours. 
f.  Create a nuisance by means of odors, noise, or unsanitary practices or pose a public health hazard. 
(10)  Vicious animal: Any animal that bites or scratches or attacks any other animal or human being without provocation. 
(Ord. No. 893, § 7-02, 11-15-94) 
Secs. 3-63-3-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BEEKEEPING[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Subsequent to the codification of Ord. No. 893, at the direction of the city the provisions of Ord. No. 851, § 2, adopted November 17, 1998 have been saved from repeal. Prior to the adoption of Ord. No. 893, Ord. No. 851 enacted provisions designated as article VI, §§ 3-103-3-114. At the discretion of the editor, said provisions have been recodified as article VIII, §§ 3-71-3-82. 

Sec. 3-71. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed in this section unless the context of their usage clearly indicated another meaning: 
    Apiary means a place where bee colonies are kept. 
    Bee means any stage of the common domestic honey bee, Apis mellifera species. 
    Colony means a hive and its equipment and appurtenances including bees, comb, honey, pollen, and brood. 
    Hive means a structure intended for the housing of a bee colony. 
    Tract means a contiguous parcel of land under common ownership. 
    Undeveloped property means any idle land that is not improved or actually in the process of being improved with residential, commercial, industrial, church, park, school, or government facilities or other structures or improvements intended for human use occupancy and the grounds maintained in association therewith. The term shall be deemed to include property developed exclusively as a street or highway or property used for commercial agricultural purposes. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-72. - Certain conduct declared unlawful. 
(a)  The purpose of this article is to establish certain requirements of sound beekeeping practices, which are intended to avoid problems that may otherwise be associated with the keeping of bees in populated areas. 
(b)  Notwithstanding compliance with the various requirements of this article it shall be unlawful for any beekeeper to keep any colony or colonies in such a manner or of such disposition as to cause any unhealthy condition, interfere with the normal use and enjoyment of human or animal life of others, or interfere with the normal use and enjoyment of any public property or property of others. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-73. - Hives. 
    All bee colonies shall be kept in Langstroth type hives with removable frames, which shall be kept in sound and usable condition. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-74. - Fencing of flyways. 
    In each instance in which any colony is situated within twenty-five (25) feet of a public or private property line of tract upon which the apiary is situated, as measured from the nearest point on the hive to the property line, the beekeeper shall establish and maintain a flyway barrier at least six (6) feet in height consisting of a solid wall, fence, dense vegetation, or combination thereof that is parallel to the property line and extends ten (10) feet beyond the colony in each direction so that all bees are forced to fly at an elevation of at least six (6) feet above ground level over the property lines in vicinity of the apiary. It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the property adjoining the apiary tract in the vicinity of the apiary is undeveloped property for a distance of at least twenty-five (25) feet from the property line of the apiary tract. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-75. - Water. 
    Each beekeeper shall ensure that a convenient source of water is available at all times to the bees so that the bees will not congregate at swimming pools, bibcocks, pet watering bowls, bird baths, or other water sources where they may cause human, bird, or domestic pet contact. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-76. - General maintenance. 
    Each beekeeper shall ensure that no bee comb or other materials that might encourage robbing are left upon the grounds of the apiary site. Upon their removal from the hive all such materials shall promptly be disposed of in a sealed container or placed within a building or other bee proof enclosure. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-77. - Queens. 
    In any instance in which a colony exhibits aggressive behavior by stinging or attempting to sting without provocation or exhibits an unusual disposition towards swarming, it shall be the duty of the beekeeper to promptly requeen the colony. Queens shall be selected from stock bred for gentleness and non-swarming characteristics. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-78. - Colony densities. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to keep more than the following number of colonies on any tract within the city, based upon the size of configuration of the tract on which the apiary is situated. 
(1)  Ten thousand (10,000) square feet or less tract size-Two (2) colonies. 
(2)  Ten thousand (10,000) square feet but less than twenty thousand (20,000) square feet tract size-Four (4) colonies. 
(3)  Twenty thousand (20,000) square feet but less than forty-three thousand (43,000) square feet tract size-Six (6) colonies. 
(4)  Forty-three thousand (43,000) square feet or larger tract size-Eight (8) colonies. 
(5)  Regardless of tract size, where all hives are situated at least two hundred (200) feet in any direction from all property lines of the tract on which the apiary is situated, there shall be no limit to the number of colonies. 
(6)  Regardless of tract size, so long as all property, other than the tract upon which the hives are situated, that is within a radius of at least two hundred (200) feet from any hive remains undeveloped property there shall be no limit to the number of colonies. 
(b)  For each colony authorized under colony densities (subsection (a)) three (3) may be maintained up on the same tract one (1) nucleus colony in a hive structure not exceeding one (1) standard 9 5/8 -inch depth ten (10) frame hive body with no supers attached as required from time to time for management of swarms. Each such nucleus colony shall be disposed of or combined with an authorized colony within thirty (30) days after the date is acquired. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-79. - Marking hives, presumption of beekeeping. 
(a)  In apiaries the name or telephone number shall be branded, painted, or otherwise clearly marked upon the structure of at least two (2) hives and placed on opposite ends of the apiary. Instead of marking the hives, the beekeeper may conspicuously post a sign setting forth the name and telephone number of the beekeeper. It is a defense to prosecution number under this section that a colony is kept under the same tract upon which the owner resides. 
(b)  Unless marked in accordance with subsection (a) it shall be presumed for purposes of this article that the beekeeper is the person or persons who own or otherwise have the present right of possession and control of the tract upon which the hive or hives are situated. The presumption may be rebutted by written agreement authorizing another person to maintain the colony or colonies upon the tract setting forth the name, address and telephone number of the other person who is acting as beekeeper. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-80. - Inspection. 
    The police chief or his designee shall have the right to inspect any apiary between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Where practicable, prior notice shall be given to the beekeeper if he resides at the apiary or if his name is marked on the hives. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-81. - Compliance. 
(a)  Upon receipt of information that any colony situated within the city is not being kept in compliance with this article, the chief of police shall cause an investigation to be conducted. If he finds that grounds exist to believe that one (1) or more violations have occurred, he shall cause a written violation of to be issued to the beekeeper. 
(b)  The notice of violation shall set forth: 
(1)  The date, time and place at which the violation occurred. 
(2)  The violation(s) alleged. 
(3)  That the bees may be ordered destroyed or removed from the city if the municipal judge finds that they have been kept in violation of this article. 
(4)  Notices shall be given by certified United States mail or personal delivery. However, if the police chief or his designee are unable to locate the beekeeper, then the notice may be given by publication one (1) time in a newspaper of general circulation at least five (5) days prior to the date of the hearing. 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 3-82. - Punishment. 
    Any violations of these provisions shall be deemed a misdemeanor and punishable by a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). 
(Ord. No. 851, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Chapter 4 - BUILDINGS AND GENERAL BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2066, § 1, adopted Feb. 19, 2013, repealed § 4-1 which pertained to construction, maintenance, and removal of telecommunication towers and derived from Ord. No. 1017, §§ 1(1-1-1-9), 2, adopted Sept. 19, 2000; and Ord. No. 1139, § 1, adopted Jan. 3, 2006. 
Sec. 4-2. - Regulations for fences, fencing materials and pool enclosures. 
    All fences shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with Unified Development Ordinance Section 707. Fences. 
(Ord. No. 1051, § 1, 7-2-02; Ord. No. 2085 , § 3, 4-1-14; Ord. No. 2087 , § 7, 5-6-14) 
Sec. 4-3. - Contractor registration and elimination of contractor generated materials. 
(a)  Definitions. The following definitions shall be used to clarify and enforce the terms of this section: 
    Contractor: A person, company or corporation that is compensated in any way (bid cost, cost plus, fixed fee, stated sum, percentage fee, time based rate or barter) for performing landscaping that generates disposable material, fencing, tree trimming or tree removal on property he, she or it does not own. 
    Materials: Tree trunks, tree limbs, brush of any kind, lumber, fencing of any kind or other landscaping by-products. 
(b)  Registration required. Contractors who wish to operate within the corporate boundaries of the City of Portland shall register with the building department before doing so. Registration shall be annual and require an administrative fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
(c)  Disposal of waste materials. Contractors shall be responsible for the collection, transfer and legal disposal of materials they generate. In no event shall materials generated by such contractors be placed within the street rights-of-way or alleys for routine collection by the solid waste company to which the City of Portland has granted an exclusive franchise. 
(d)  Compliance. The building department may suspend the registration of any contractor that fails to meet the requirements of this section. 
(e)  Penalty. Any violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, any person so violating it shall be fined a sum not exceeding two thousand dollars ($2,000.00). Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1163, §§ 1-5, 12-19-06; Ord. No. 2059, § 3, 9-18-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1163, §§ 1-5, adopted Dec. 19, 2006, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 4-3 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 4-4. - Contractor registration when a building permit is required. 
(a)  It is hereby illegal for a person, company or corporation that is compensated in any way (bid cost, cost plus, fixed fee, stated sum, percentage fee, time base rate or barter) to perform any work within the corporate limits of the city for which a building permit is required without having first registered as a contractor with the department of development services. 
(b)  Contractors who wish to operate within the corporate limits of the city are hereby required to register with the building department before doing so. Registration shall be annual and require and administrative fee of one hundred thirty-five dollars ($135.00). 
(c)  Any violation of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, any person so violating it shall be fined a sum not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1198, §§ 1-3, 10-21-08; Ord. No. 2059, § 4, 9-18-12) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1198, §§ 1-3, adopted October 21, 2008, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, inclusion as § 4-4 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 4-5-4-10. - Reserved.

Sec. 4-13. - Building Code amendments. 
    The Building Code is amended as follows: 
WIND LOADS: All buildings, structures and parts thereof shall be designed to withstand the wind load, which is determined by the Texas Department of Insurance for the City of Portland. All buildings, structures and parts thereof shall EITHER meet the framing methods and installation requirements set forth in Section 300 of the "Building Code for Windstorm Resident Construction" as adopted by the Texas Department of Insurance OR shall be designed, inspected and certified by a Professional Engineer, licensed by the State of Texas. (The wind load adopted by the Department of Insurance for the City of Portland is a basic wind speed of 95 mph with three-second gust wind speed of 120 mph. See Section 3403.1 for requirements to alter, repair or rehabilitate existing structures.) 
(Ord. No. 1021, § 1, 10-17-00; Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 12-21-04)

(Ord. No. 1021, § 1, 10-17-00; Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 4-15. - Fire Prevention Code amendments. 
    The Fire Code is amended as follows: 
1.  Chapter 1 ADMINISTRATION is amended as follows and shall include Chapter 7 of the Code of Ordinances. 
104.12 Penalty 
A person commits an offense if the person violates any of the provisions of this Fire Prevention Code. The penalty shall be not less than a fifty dollar ($50.00) fine and not to exceed a maximum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per day per violation. 
105.6.20.1 The fire official is to be notified at least twenty-four (24) hours before any building or structure is to be closed in connection with the use of any toxic or flammable fumigant and at the time the building or structure is released for occupancy. 
2.  Chapter 33 EXPLOSIVES AND FIREWORKS is amended as follows and shall include Article IV, Chapter 7 of the City of Portland Code of Ordinances. 
3303.8 Restricted Use 
person commits an offense if the person manufactures, assembles, stores, transports, receives, keeps, sells, offers or has in his possession with intent to sell, deliver to any person or place, use, discharge, cause to be discharged, ignite, detonate, fire or otherwise set in action or have in his possession or on his person or under his control any fireworks or any description except as herein provided. The fire official shall have the power to adopt reasonable rules and regulations for the granting of permits for supervised public displays of fireworks by a jurisdiction, fair associations, amusement parks, other organizations or for the use of fire works by artisans in pursuit of their trade. Every such use or display shall be handled by a competent operator approved by the fire official and shall be of such character and so located, discharged or fires so as not to be hazardous to property or endanger any person. 
3303.9 Removal and Disposal 
The presence of any fireworks within the city or within five thousand (5,000) feet of the city limits, except fireworks for a public display authorized by the Fire Official, is declared to be a common and public nuisance and detrimental to the public health, safety and general welfare and constitutes a violation of this Code. The fire official is directed and required to seize and cause to be safely destroyed any fireworks found within the city or in violation of the other provisions of this fire prevention code. Any member of the fire department of the city or any police officer is empowered to seize any fireworks found within the city or within five thousand (5,000) feet of the city limits in violation of this article and cause the fireworks to be safely destroyed. 
3303.10 Applicability 
The provisions of this section apply to all of the area within the city and to all of that area adjacent to the city and within five thousand (5,000) feet of the city limits; provided, however, that no change in the city limits occurring after December 7, 2004, shall affect an expansion of the area in which this chapter applies until the 120 th day following the effective date of such change in the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 1021, § 1, 10-17-00; Ord. No. 1123, § 1, 12-21-04)
