Editor's note- Ord. No. 1133, adopted Sept. 20, 2005, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as art. II, § 5-31 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 5-31. - Adopted. 
    The City of Portland hereby adopts the National Incident Management System (NIMS) dated March 1, 2004. 
(Ord. No. 1133, § 1, 9-20-05) 
Chapter 51/2 - COURTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 997, §§ 1-7, adopted Sept. 21, 1999, did not specifically amend the Code hence; inclusion as Ch. 51/2, was at the editor's discretion. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 51/2-1-51/2-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - MUNICIPAL COURT TECHNOLOGY FUND 

Sec. 51/2-21. - Establishment of municipal court technology fund. 
(a)  There is hereby created and established a municipal court technology fund, here-in-now known as the fund, pursuant to Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(b)  The fund may be maintained in an interest bearing account and may be maintained in the general revenue account. 
(Ord. No. 997, § 1, 9-21-99) 
Sec. 51/2-22. - Establishment of amount of the fee and assessment and collection. 
(a)  The fee shall be in the amount of four dollars ($4.00). 
(b)  The fee shall be assessed and collected from the defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor offense in the municipal court as a cost of court. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
(1)  A sentence is imposed on the person; 
(2)  The person is placed on community supervision, including deferred adjudication community supervision; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(c)  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed on or after this section is adopted. 
(d)  The clerk of the court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the Municipal Finance Director of the City of Portland, who shall deposit the fee into the municipal court technology fund. 
(Ord. No. 997, § 2, 9-21-99) 
Sec. 51/2-23. - Designated use of the fund and administration. 
(a)  The fund shall be used only to finance the purchase of technological enhancements for the Municipal Court of the City of Portland, Texas including: 
(1)  Computer systems; 
(2)  Computer networks; 
(3)  Computer hardware; 
(4)  Computer software; 
(5)  Imaging systems; 
(6)  Electronic kiosks; 
(7)  Electronic ticket writers; or 
(8)  Docket management systems. 
(b)  The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the City Council of the City of Portland. 
(Ord. No. 997, § 3, 9-21-99) 
Sec. 51/2-24. - Expiration and administration of fund. 
    In accordance with Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, this article and the assessment and collection of the municipal court technology fee expires September 1, 2005. The purpose of the use of any funds remaining in the fund shall continue to be used and administered as required by this article and for that purpose this article remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. 997, § 7, 9-21-99) 
Secs. 51/2-25-51/2-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL COURT BUILDING SECURITY FUND 

Sec. 51/2-31. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a Municipal Court Building Security Fund (the fund) pursuant to Art 102.017, Code of Criminal Procedure. The fund is established to account for the collection and expenditure of Municipal Court Building Security fees. 
(Ord. No. 1040, § 1, 9-18-01) 
Sec. 51/2-32. - Cost assessed. 
    All defendants convicted of misdemeanor offenses in municipal court shall pay a three dollar ($3.00) Municipal Court Building Security Fee (the fee). For the purpose of this article, a person is considered convicted if a sentence is imposed, the person receives community supervision (including deferred adjudication), or the court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(Ord. No. 1040, § 2, 9-18-01) 
Sec. 51/2-33. - Collection. 
    The collection and administration of the fund shall be as follows: 
(1)  The clerk of the municipal court will collect the fee and deposit it into the fund. 
(2)  The finance director will ensure that the collections are correctly deposited and that expenditures of the fund are in compliance with Art. 102.017(d) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(3)  The fund shall be administered under the direction of the City Council of the City of Portland. 
(4)  The city council may terminate the collection of the fee by ordinance at any time. All remaining monies in the fund at that time will be expended in accordance with Art. 102.017(d) of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(Ord. No. 1040, § 3, 9-18-01) 
Chapter 6 - ELECTRICAL CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1122, § 1, adopted Dec. 21, 2004, repealed Ch. 6 in its entirety. Said ordinance further provided for a new Ch. 6 to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of repeal and inclusion. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Title. 
    The title of this chapter shall be the "Portland Electrical Code." 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-2. - Intent. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to safeguard persons, and buildings and their contents from hazards arising from the use of electricity. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-3. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all electrical systems, conductors, and equipment in, on, or to buildings within the city limits of the City of Portland, unless installed by or maintained by a serving electric utility company. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to buildings that are exempt from municipal regulations as set forth in federal or state law. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-4. - Chapter does not affect liability for damages. 
    This chapter shall not relieve or lessen the responsibility or liability of any person owning, operating or installing electrical conductors or equipment for damages to persons or buildings caused by defects therein. The city shall not be held liable for any damages to persons or property caused by defective equipment or improper installation of electrical systems. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-5. - National Electrical Code. 
    The 2014 edition of the National Electrical Code, as sponsored by the National Fire Protection Association, Inc., is hereby adopted as part of the "Portland Electrical Code." Where the requirements of this chapter are different from the National Electrical Code, the provisions of this chapter shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04; Ord. No. 1155, § 1, 10-3-06; Ord. No. 2130 , § 2, 2-16-16, effective 6-1-16) 
Sec. 6-6. - Building Code. 
    In addition to this chapter, Chapter 1 of the Building Code which has been adopted by the city shall govern the administration of the "Portland Electrical Code." Where there may be a specific conflict between this chapter and Chapter 1 of the Building Code, this chapter shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-7. - Existing electrical systems. 
    Existing electrical systems shall be maintained in a safe and working condition subject to regulations in effect at the time of their installation. Repairs to existing electrical systems may be subject to compliance with current regulations if, in the opinion of the electrical inspector, the electrical system can no longer be maintained in a safe condition. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-8. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section. Words and phrases not specifically defined herein shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the National Electrical Code, the Building Code, the Texas Electrical Safety and Licensing Act, or shall have ordinarily accepted meanings such as the context implies. 
    Authorized person. An "authorized person" is an individual or authorized representative of a firm or corporation who is allowed under the provisions of this chapter to do the work provided for in this chapter. 
    Board. The "board" is the Construction Board of Adjustment and Appeals created by Chapter 1 of the Building Code. 
    Inspector. The "inspector" is an individual who has been designated by the City of Portland as an electrical inspector. 
    Maintenance work. "Maintenance work" is the act of keeping any existing electrical installation in safe operating condition, but does not include the installation of additional electrical work, electrical equipment or apparatus. 
    Special ruling. A "special ruling" is a written ruling or decision passed by the board and filed in the office of the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Secs. 6-9-6-21. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR 

Sec. 6-22. - Position created. 
    There is hereby created the position of electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-23. - Employment and supervision. 
    The inspector shall be hired by or may be the building official. The inspector shall serve under the supervision and direction of the building official, with aid furnished to him/her by the members of the board. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-24. - Qualifications. 
    The inspector should have at least five (5) years experience in the construction industry as an installer or as an inspector. The inspector should be certified as an inspector through a recognized certification program. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-25. - Conflicts of interest. 
    The inspector shall not be financially interested in the furnishing of labor, material, or appliances for the construction, alteration, or maintenance of a building, structure, service, system, or in the making of plans or of specifications thereof, unless he/she is the owner of such building. The inspector shall not engage in any other work which is inconsistent with his/her duties or conflict with the interests of the department. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-26. - General duties. 
    The electrical inspector shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Shall enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Shall delegate any powers of inspection to his/her subordinates that he/she deems advisable. 
(3)  Shall collect all fees provided for in this chapter and turn the same over to proper city officials. 
(4)  Shall issue permits for electrical work as provided for in this chapter. 
(5)  Shall make inspections of all electrical work as provided for in this chapter. 
(6)  Shall keep records of permits issued and inspections made. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-27. - Interpretive powers. 
    The inspector shall have authority to render interpretations of this chapter, which are consistent with its spirit and purpose. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-28. - Right of entry. 
    The inspector may enter any building or property, if necessary, during reasonable hours to examine any electrical installation therein, in the performance of his/her official duties. If such building or premises is occupied, he/she shall first present proper credentials and request entry. If such building is unoccupied, he/she shall first make a reasonable effort to locate the owner or other persons having charge or control of such and request entry. If entry is refused, the inspector shall have recourse to every remedy provided by law to secure entry. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-29. - Periodic inspections of existing installations. 
    The inspector may make periodic inspections of existing electrical installations in or on buildings within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-30. - Ordering compliance with chapter; disconnecting service and sealing equipment. 
(a)  The inspector shall order compliance with this chapter where changes or alterations to existing wiring in buildings or premises is needed. The notice shall be given to the owner or to the person(s) responsible for maintaining the building. The notice shall specify the corrections to be made and specify a time limit for the corrections to be made. The notice shall be served personally; or sent by certified or first-class mail addressed to the last known address; or if the notice is returned showing that the letter was not delivered, a copy thereof shall be posted in a conspicuous place in or about the structure affected by such notice. 
(b)  Upon failure to comply with an ordered correction, the inspector shall cause the electrical power to such electrical system or part thereof to be disconnected. It shall be unlawful for any person or agency to renew the supply of power without permission of the inspector to do so. 
(c)  Not withstanding the above provisions of this section, whenever the inspector finds any electrical installation to be in such condition as to constitute an immediate hazard, he/she shall have the authority to immediately disconnect, or cause to be disconnected, all sources of supply to such installation, without the notice required above. 
(d)  The inspector may place an official seal or notice on electrical equipment to prevent the use of electricity, and it shall be unlawful for any person to remove or in any way alter such seal or notice. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-31. - Notice to remove abandoned wires, poles, and apparatus. 
    It shall be the duty of the inspector to cause all abandoned dead wire or unused poles or electrical apparatus on the outside of a building to be removed at the expense of the owner thereof, by giving the owner written notice to do so. Method of notice shall be as required in section 6-30(a). 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-32. - Alternate materials and methods. 
    The provisions of this chapter are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by them provided any such alternate has been reviewed by the building official. The building official shall approve any such alternate, provided the building official finds that the alternate for the purpose intended is listed by an approved laboratory which lists electrical equipment and methods. The building official shall require that sufficient evidence or proof be submitted to substantiate any claim made regarding the alternate. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-33. - Modifications or waiver of chapter provisions. 
    Where there are practical difficulties involved in carrying out the provisions of this chapter, the inspector may grant modifications for individual cases. The inspector shall first find that a special individual reason makes the strict letter of this chapter impractical and that the modification is in conformance with the intent and purpose of this code and that such modification does not lessen any fire-protection requirements or any degree of structural integrity. The details of any action granting modifications shall be recorded and entered in the files of the building department. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-34. - Regional methods of electrical construction. 
    The inspector shall have the authority to accept methods of electrical work that may not meet the specific requirements of the National Electrical Code. Such methods must be commonly accepted by regional jurisdictions and must be acceptable to the board. It is not the purpose of this section to give law making authority to the inspector or to the board. The purpose of this section is to recognize regional methods of electrical installations and to promote consistent enforcement throughout this region. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-35. - Not personally liable for official acts. 
    Where action is taken by the inspector to enforce the provisions of this chapter, such acts are done in the name of, and on behalf of the city. The Inspector, in so acting, does not render himself/herself personally liable for any damage which may occur to persons or property as a result of acts committed in good faith and in the discharge of his/her duties. Any suit brought against the inspector because of the enforcement of this chapter, shall be defended by the city attorney until final termination of the proceedings. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Secs. 6-36-6-43. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PERMITS, INSPECTIONS AND SUPERVISION OF WORK 

Sec. 6-44. - Permit required; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to install or cause to be installed, or to allow any person to install, any electrical wiring, fixtures or equipment, or to make any alterations, additions or repairs to the same, within the city limits, without first obtaining a permit to do so from the inspector. There shall be one (1) permit for each building for which electrical work is done or where electrical equipment is installed. Accessory buildings, tourist cottages or group houses shall not be considered separate buildings when work is classed as one (1) project to be completed at one (1) time, unless separate meter loops or switches are installed thereon. 
(b)  No permit shall be required: 
(1)  For maintenance work as defined in this chapter. 
(2)  Of a refrigeration firm or HVAC contractor for replacement of a motor or HVAC equipment provided that the electrical supply to same has been or is properly installed by a licensed electrician. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-45. - Application for permit. 
    Application for permits required by this article shall be made in writing on forms provided by the inspector for that purpose. The applicant shall fill out the application to the satisfaction of the inspector. With each application there may be required a diagram or plan showing clearly the type of electrical work to be done. The plan or diagram shall show the manner in which the electrical work is to be done or the character of any repairs to any existing installation. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-46. - Permits obtained by authorized persons. 
    Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, all electrical permits shall be obtained by an electrical contractor who meets the requirements of the Texas Electrical Safety and Licensing Act. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Secs. 6-47, 6-48. - Reserved. 
Sec. 6-49. - Permit and inspection fees. 
    Permit and inspection fees shall be set forth in the City of Portland's "Development Fee Schedule" ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-50. - Issuance or refusal of permit generally. 
(a)  The inspector shall act upon an application for a permit without unreasonable or unnecessary delay. If the inspector is satisfied that the work described in an application for a permit and the contract documents filed therewith conform to the requirements of the construction codes and other pertinent laws and ordinances, he/she shall issue a permit to the applicant. An electrical permit shall carry with it the right to construct or install the work, provided the same is shown on the drawings and set forth in the specifications filed with the application for the permit. If the application for a permit and the accompanying contract documents describing the work do not conform to the requirements of this chapter or other pertinent laws or ordinances, the inspector shall not issue a permit, but shall return the contract documents to the applicant with his refusal to issue such permit. Such refusal shall, when requested, be in writing and shall contain the reason for refusal. 
(b)  No permit applicant shall file an application for an electrical permit, unless he/she is in fact the contractor for such work. The inspector shall have the power to cancel any permit found by him/her to be issued contrary to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-51. - Permits for part jobs. 
    When two (2) electrical contractors are working on the same project, separate permits and fees shall be required from each contractor. The permits shall state the scope of work that each contractor is responsible for. When one (1) contractor is hired to finish a project started by another contractor, a separate permit and fee shall be required. The city shall notify the first contractor and shall amend the scope of work covered by the first permit. The city may require a letter from the property owner or general contractor stating that the original electrical contractor is no longer doing the work. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-52. - Homeowner's permit. 
    A permit for electrical work may be obtained by a home owner for work being done at his/her principle dwelling place. The electrical work must be done by the owner or an immediate family member. The permit shall be revoked if it is ascertained that the owner is doing the work to enhance the sale of the property. The inspector may revoke a permit upon determination by the inspector that the electrical work for which the permit was issued is in violation of, or not in conformity with, the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-53. - Cancellation of permit for delay in beginning work. 
    The inspector shall have the power to cancel a permit issued under this article, where the electrical work authorized thereby has not commenced within ninety (90) days from the date of issuance of the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-54. - Rough inspection. 
(a)  When the rough wiring or installation work is completed on any premises, the person responsible shall notify the inspector that the job is ready for inspection, giving proper identification of the work, address and permit number. The inspector shall then make an inspection of the electric installation within forty-eight (48) hours from the time of notification (exclusive of weekends and legal holidays). If the work has been installed in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter, the inspector shall issue a "complies with code" tag, noting thereon the date of the approval of the work. More than one (1) rough inspection may be made without charge when the progress of construction requires such inspection. 
(b)  If the electrical work is found to not be done in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter, the inspector shall notify the responsible person who installed such work of the changes necessary to be made in order that the work shall conform to this chapter. Such person shall, within forty-eight (48) hours from the time of notification, make or start to make the changes ordered and shall proceed with the work until the same is completed. Upon completion thereof and payment of any reinspection fee that may have been required, he/she shall notify the inspector that the work has been corrected. The inspector shall then cause the reinspection to be made, and if the work is found to comply with this chapter, he/she shall issue a "complies with code" tag, noting thereon the date of approval of the work. If the electrical inspector shall again find the work incorrectly installed, he/she shall notify the responsible person of the necessary changes and may collect additional reinspection fees. If the responsible person does not make the required changes within a reasonable time, the electrical inspector may refuse to issue any further permits to such person until such work is corrected and approved. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-55. - Final inspection. 
    Upon the completion of all electrical work in any building or on any premises, the person responsible shall notify the inspector that the work is ready for final inspection, giving the electrical permit number and street address. The inspector shall then cause an inspection to be made within forty-eight (48) hours from the time of receipt of notification (exclusive of weekends and legal holidays). If the electrical work is found to not be done in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter, the inspector shall notify the responsible person who installed such work of the changes necessary to be made in order that the work shall conform to this chapter. If such work is found to be correctly installed, the electrical inspector shall issue a "complies with code" tag noting thereon the date of approval of the work. For each final inspection requested after the first inspection has been made, a reinspection fee may be charged. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-56. - Concealing work prior to inspection and approval. 
    It shall be unlawful to conceal or cause to be concealed any electrical work in or about any building or structure before the same has been inspected and approved by the electrical inspector and a tag indicating its approval posted on such building or structure wherein or whereon such electrical work has been done or installed. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-57. - Certificate of approval prerequisite to service. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection from a source of electrical energy to any electrical wiring devices or equipment on an installation for which a permit is required by this article, until permission is granted by the inspector authorizing such connection and the use of such wiring, devices or equipment. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-58. - Construction loops. 
    Construction loops shall not be connected to any power source until inspected and approved by the electrical inspector. An electrical permit must be applied for and issued prior to a construction loop inspection. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Secs. 6-59-6-91. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL LICENSES 

Sec. 6-92. - Required; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to perform any electrical work for which a permit is required, unless such person is the holder of a current license of the proper classification issued by the Texas Department of Licensing and regulation in accordance with the Texas Electrical Safety and Licensing Act. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a home owner performing work covered by a permit obtained in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Secs. 6-93-6-112. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SPECIAL ELECTRIC RULES 

Sec. 6-113. - Generally. 
    The special rules prescribed by this article are hereby set forth in addition to the provisions of the National Electrical Code. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-114. - Supplemental grounding electrode. 
    The grounding electrode for all electrical services installed, upgraded or repaired in the City of Portland shall be supplemented by a copper or copper-clad ground rod. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-115. - Equipment grounding. 
    A ground wire sized in accordance with the National Electrical Code shall be installed in all conduits and raceways installed in or on buildings within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-116. - Feeders, service drops and meters. 
(a)  Feeder conductors that serve as the main power feeder to individual dwelling units and feeders to individual occupancies in multi-tenant commercial buildings shall be pulled in conduit from each feeder origination point to their respective distribution panels, which shall be located in the occupant's rooms or premises and readily accessible to the occupant. 
(b)  Overhead service drop conductors and service masts shall be installed according to the serving electric utility company's specifications. Where these specifications are different from the National Electrical Code, the more restrictive shall apply. 
(c)  The type of metering equipment and the installation thereof shall be to the serving electric utility company's specifications. 
(d)  The main disconnect shall be located on the outside of all buildings. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-117. - Conductors and wiring methods. 
(a)  All conductors regulated by this chapter shall be copper and not smaller than No. 12 AWG, unless for use in low voltage or control circuits. 
(b)  The use of nonmetallic-sheathed cable, type SE cable, and type UF cable shall be limited to one- and two-family dwellings and their accessory buildings (including agricultural buildings), and individual dwelling units in apartments or condominiums which are built of wood. When used underground, type UF cable shall be installed at a minimum depth of twenty-four (24) inches. 
(c)  Type AC cable shall not be installed in or on any building in the City of Portland. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-118. - Special circuit requirements. 
(a)  Unless engineered electrical plans are submitted to the city, the number of outlets per circuit shall be: 
(1)  Dwelling unit general circuit, 10. 
(2)  Dwelling unit kitchen counter top circuit, 3. 
(3)  Other occupancies, 8. 
(b)  Unless engineered electrical plans are submitted to the city, convenience outlets shall not be placed on the same circuit with general lighting outlets, except in additions which are five hundred (500) square feet or less. 
(c)  When three-phase power and single phase lighting systems are used in the same building, they shall be run in separate conduits or raceways. 
(d)  When different voltages are used in the same building, they shall be run in separate conduits or raceways. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-119. - Special requirements for panels in one- and two-family dwellings. 
(a)  A space conduit or raceway, one (1) inch nominal size, shall be installed from the electrical panel to an accessible attic location. 
(b)  At the time of the original installation of the electrical panels, there shall be at least one (1) space breaker space for each five (5) breaker spaces used. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-120. - Special requirements for multi-family buildings. 
(a)  House lights and circuits fed through house panels shall be wired in a commercial type wiring method. They shall not be wired in nonmetallic sheathed cable, type SE cable, or type UF cable. 
(b)  A one hundred twenty-volt, fifteen- or twenty-amp convenience outlet, fed from the house panel and GFCI protected, shall be installed outside and within fifty (50) feet of outside HVAC equipment. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Sec. 6-121. - Wall receptacle requirements. 
    Unless engineered electrical plans are submitted to the city, the following buildings shall have one (1) wall receptacle installed for every twenty (20) lineal feet measured horizontally around the interior wall of each room excluding storage rooms: Offices, stores, restaurants, taverns, banks, studios, and mechanical garages. 
(Ord. No. 1122, § 1, 12-21-04) 
Chapter 7 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Volunteer fire department, § 4.05. 
Cross reference- Buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 4; electrical code, Ch. 6; restrictions on operation and parking of vehicles transporting explosives and flammables, § 21-48 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 7-1. - Spilling, leaking, etc., of petroleum products. 
    No person engaged in the operation of any loading rack or storage or other facilities or equipment used in the production, storage, transportation, sale or shipment of crude oil or any other inflammable petroleum product, within the city, shall permit or allow any crude oil, gas or any other inflammable petroleum product to spill over, overflow, leak, drain out, escape, or accumulate in or about the premises, or on any surface, or in any open surface ditch, or any other exposed surface conduit, in such manner or amount as to create a potential fire hazard or a potential explosion hazard. 
(Ord. No. 76, § 42, 7-3-56) 
Sec. 7-2. - Arson reward. 
    The city shall pay a reward of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) to any person who shall give information leading to the apprehension and conviction of any person guilty of arson committed within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 152, 6-19-62) 
Sec. 7-3. - Office of fire chief. 
(a)  There is hereby established the Office of the Fire Chief of the City of Portland, Texas. The fire chief shall be responsible for the general supervision of the Portland Volunteer Fire Department in all matters reasonably necessary for the proper functioning of the volunteer fire department. These duties shall include, but not be limited to, the supervision and management of personnel training, personnel assignments, equipment maintenance, and the use of the city funds and equipment by the volunteer fire department. 
(b)  The fire chief shall be selected in the following manner: The volunteer fire department will submit its nominee for fire chief to the city council for consideration at the second regular city council meeting in December of each year. The city council may ratify and adopt such nominee as fire chief. In the event the city council refuses for cause to ratify such nominee for the position of fire chief, the volunteer fire department shall thereafter select an alternative nominee for fire chief and submit such nomination to the city council for consideration and approval at the next meeting of the city council. Nominations by the volunteer fire department and consideration by the city council may continue in like manner thereafter for so long as is necessary to appoint a fire chief. 
(c)  The fire chief shall serve for a term of one (1) year, beginning January 1 of each year and ending December 31 of the same year, unless a successor has not been approved by the city council, in which event the fire chief shall hold office until a successor has been approved by the city council. The fire chief shall report directly to the city council, and shall be removable for cause during his term of office by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 812, § 1, 12-10-90) 
Secs. 7-4-7-12. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE MARSHAL 

Sec. 7-13. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 850, § 1, adopted Nov. 17, 1992, provided for the deletion of §§ 7-13, 7-14, which pertained to the creation of the office and qualifications as derived from Ord. No. 62, § 1, adopted Mar. 22, 1955. Sec. 2 of Ord. No. 850 enacted a new § 7-14 to read as herein set out. 
Sec. 7-14. - Qualifications. 
    The fire marshal shall be properly qualified for the duties of the office. 
(Ord. No. 850, § 2, 11-17-92) 
Sec. 7-15. - Duty to investigate fires. 
    The fire marshal shall investigate the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring within this city by which property has been destroyed or damaged, and shall especially make investigation as to whether such fire was the result of carelessness or design. Such investigation shall be begun within twenty-four (24) hours, not including Sunday, of the occurrence of such fire. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 2, 3-22-55) 
Sec. 7-16. - Right of entry in case of fire. 
    The fire marshal shall have the authority, at all times of the day or night, when necessary in the performance of the duties imposed upon him by the provisions of this article, to enter upon and examine any building or premises where any fire has occurred, and other buildings and premises adjoining or near the same, which authority shall be exercised only with reason and good discretion. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 7, 3-22-55) 
Sec. 7-17. - Taking of testimony; authority to summon witnesses, require production of evidence and administer oaths. 
(a)  The fire marshal, when in his opinion further investigation is necessary, shall take or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the same to be reduced to writing. 
(b)  The marshal shall have the power to summon witnesses before him to testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this article, a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper or document deemed pertinent thereto. The fire marshal is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations to any person appearing as a witness before him. 
(Ord. No. 62, §§ 3, 4, 3-22-55) 
Sec. 7-18. - Investigations may be private; separation of witnesses. 
    All investigations held by or under the direction of the fire marshal may, in his discretion, be private, and persons other than those required to be present may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held, and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been examined. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 6, 3-22-55) 
Sec. 7-19. - Misconduct of witnesses summoned by fire marshal. 
    Any witness who refuses to be sworn, or who refuses to appear or testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the fire marshal, or who fails or refuses to produce any book, paper or document touching any matter under examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the proceedings of the fire marshal in the matter of such investigation or inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter under investigation as provided in this article, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and it shall be the duty of the fire marshal to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 5, 3-22-55) 
Sec. 7-20. - Duty when evidence indicates crime in connection with fire. 
    If the fire marshal is of the opinion that there is sufficient evidence to charge any person with the crime of arson, or with the attempt to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud, or criminal conduct in connection with such fire, he shall cause such person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offense or either of them, and shall furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence together with the names of witnesses and all of the information obtained by him, including a copy of pertinent and material testimony taken in the case. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 3, 3-22-55) 
Sec. 7-21. - Record of fires to be kept. 
    The fire marshal shall keep in his office a record of all fires, together with all the facts, statistics and circumstances, including the origin of the fire and the amount of the loss, which may be determined by the investigation required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 62, § 2, 3-22-55) 
Sec. 7-22. - Inspection of premises; ordering removal or repair of dangerous conditions. 
    The fire marshal, upon complaint of any person having an interest in any building or property adjacent, and without any complaint, shall have a right at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises within the city, and it shall be his duty, quarterly or more often, to enter upon and make, or cause to be entered upon and made, a thorough examination of all mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings, together with the premises belonging thereto. Whenever he shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repair, or by reason of age or dilapidated condition, or for any cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger other buildings or property, or so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property therein, and whenever he shall find an improper or dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces, or other heating appliances of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues and pipes with which the same may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting devices or systems, or a dangerous or unlawful storage of explosives, compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals, vegetable products, ashes, combustible, inflammable and refuse materials, or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or liable to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to the firemen or occupants, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of the building or premises. If such owner or occupant deems himself aggrieved by such order, he may, within five (5) days, appeal to the city manager, who shall investigate the cause of the complaint and, unless by his authority the order is revoked, such order shall remain in force and be forthwith complied with by such owner or occupant. Any owner or occupant who fails to comply with such order shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 62, §§ 8-11, 3-22-55) 
Secs. 7-23-7-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICES 

Sec. 7-33. - Emergency medical service fee established. 
(a)  A mandatory two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) a month emergency medical service fee is hereby created, which shall be charged to every residential dwelling, to every individual unit within multi-family dwellings, to individual nonresidential establishments, and to each unit within nonresidential establishments, which receives utility service from the City of Portland. 
(b)  When a customer or business occupying a single residence, campus or business site has a main meter and an irrigation or auxiliary services meter, an emergency medical service fee shall apply only to the main meter. 
(Ord. No. 1107, § 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 1129, § 1, 9-6-05; Ord. No. 1411, § 1, 1-17-06; Ord. No. 2046, § 1, 1-3-12; Ord. No. 2077, § 1, 9-17-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1107, § 1, adopted Sept. 7, 2004, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 7-33, at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 7-34-7-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - FIREWORKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Fireworks, Vernon's Ann. P.C. art. 1725; authority of city relative to fireworks, art. 1725, § 14. 

Sec. 7-52. - Definitions. 
(a)  Fireworks. The term "fireworks," as used in this article, shall mean and include any firecrackers, cannon crackers, skyrockets, torpedoes, Roman candles, sparklers, squibs, fire balloons, star shells, gerbs, or any other substance, in whatever combination and by any designated name, intended for use in obtaining visible or audible pyrotechnic display. Such term shall include all articles or substances within the commonly accepted meaning of fireworks, whether herein specially designated and defined or not. 
(b)  Person. The term "person," as used in this article, shall mean and include any natural person, association of persons, partnership, corporation or agent or officer of a corporation, and shall also include all warehousemen, common and private carriers, bailees, trustees, receivers, executors and administrators. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 1, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-53. - Territorial application of article. 
    This article shall be applicable and in force throughout the territory within the city and within the area immediately adjacent and contiguous to the city limits and extending for a distance outside the city limits for a total of five thousand (5,000) feet, and it shall be unlawful to do or perform any act in violation of this article, within such area of five thousand (5,000) feet outside the city limits; provided that, this article shall not apply within any portion of such five-thousand-foot area which is within the territory of any other municipal corporation. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 7, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-54. - Manufacture, sale, use, etc., prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, assemble, store, transport, receive, keep, sell, offer, or have in his possession with intent to sell, or use, discharge, cause to be discharged, ignite, detonate, fire or otherwise set in action any fireworks of any description. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to signal flares and torpedoes of the type and kind commonly used by any railroad and which signal flares and torpedoes are received by and stored or transported by any such railroad for use in railroad operations; nor shall this section apply to any marine signal flare or rocket of the type and kind commonly carried by a vessel at sea for its own use and which signal flares or rockets are transported or received or stored for use only as ship's stores; nor shall this section apply to signal flares or rockets for military or police use, nor when a permit to use and discharge fireworks has been issued under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 238, §§ 2, 3, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-55. - Parents and guardians not to permit children to discharge. 
    It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian of any child under the age of fourteen (14) to permit or allow such child to use, discharge, ignite, detonate, fire or otherwise set in action any fireworks. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 6, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-56. - Permit for public exhibitions. 
(a)  Any person desiring to put on a public exhibition, display or showing of fireworks shall first obtain a permit to do so from the city manager. 
(b)  No such permit shall be issued unless application for same has been filed in writing with the city manager, stating the name of the exhibitor, the time, place and nature of the display, the name of the sponsoring association, and along with such application, the exhibitor must show financial responsibility in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), to consist of either acceptable liability insurance, surety bond or cash bond. 
(c)  No permit for the public exhibition of fireworks shall be issued within seven (7) days from date the application for same is filed with the city manager. 
(d)  For issuance of the above described permit, the city shall collect a fee of two dollars ($2.00), for which it shall issue a receipt. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 4, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-57. - Fireworks in violation of article declared to be nuisance; seizure and destruction of such fireworks. 
    The presence of any fireworks in violation of this article is hereby declared to be a common and public nuisance. The fire marshal is directed and required to seize and cause to be safely destroyed any fireworks found in violation of this article and any member of the fire department or any police officer of the city or any other duly constituted peace officer is empowered to stop the transportation of and detain any fireworks found being transported illegally or to close any building where any fireworks are found stored illegally, until the fire marshal can be notified in order that the fireworks may be seized and destroyed in accordance with the terms of this section. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 5, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-58. - Injunctive relief to enforce article. 
    Notwithstanding any penal provision of this article, the city attorney is authorized to file suit on behalf of the city or the fire marshal, or both, for such injunctive relief as may be necessary to prevent unlawful storage, transportation, keeping or use of fireworks, and to aid the fire marshal in the discharge of his duties and to particularly prevent any person from interfering with the seizure and destruction of fireworks, but it shall not be necessary to obtain any such injunctive relief as a prerequisite to such seizure and destruction. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 5, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-59. - Right of entry to enforce article. 
    The fire marshal is hereby authorized to enter any building where the unlawful presence of fireworks is suspected in order to inspect the same for the presence of such fireworks. 
(Ord. No. 238, § 5, 8-3-65) 
Sec. 7-60. - Penalties for violations of article. 
(a)  Any person who shall manufacture, assemble, store, transport, receive, keep, sell, offer for sale or have in his possession with intent to sell any fireworks in violation of this article shall be fined two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. If the fireworks are separately wrapped or packaged, the doing or omitting to do any act prohibited by this article shall be a separate offense as to each such separately wrapped or separately packaged fireworks. Each day that a violation of this article shall continue with respect to any package of fireworks shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall use, discharge, cause to be discharged, ignite, detonate, fire or otherwise set in action any fireworks in violation of this article shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(c)  Any parent or guardian violating section 7-55 shall be fined not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 238, § 6, 8-3-65) 
Chapter 8 - FOOD AND FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 8-1. - Milk ordinance continued in effect. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect Ordinance No. 208, adopted by the governing body of the city on April 21, 1964, which ordinance regulates the production and sale of milk and milk products, and such ordinance and amendments thereto are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. 
Secs. 8-2-8-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2002, §§ 1, 2, adopted December 16, 2008, repealed and reenacted article II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article II, §§ 8-21-8-30 pertained to retail establishments, mobile and roadside vendors, and derived from Ord. No. 811, §§ 1-9, 11, adopted November 20, 1990. 

Sec. 8-21. - Adoption of Texas Food Establishment Rules. 
(a)  The city adopts by reference the provisions of the current rules or rules amended by the Texas Board of Health found in 25 Texas Administrative Code, ch. 229, §§ 161-171 and 173-175 regarding the regulation of food establishments in this jurisdiction, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code chs. 437 and 438 and V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 38(a). 
(b)  Definitions. The words "authorized agent or employee" means the employees of the regulatory authority. 
    The words "food establishment" mean a food service establishment, a retail food store, a temporary food establishment, a mobile food unit, and/or a roadside food vendor. 
    The word "municipality of" in this article will be understood to refer to the City of Portland. 
    The words "state rules" mean the state rules found at 25 Texas Administrative Code, ch. 229, §§ 161-171 and §§ 173-175. These rules are also known as the Texas Food Establishment Rules. 
    The words "regulatory authority" means San Patricio County Department of Public Health who has jurisdiction over food establishments. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-22. - Permits and exemptions. 
(a)  A person may not operate a food establishment without a permit issued by the regulatory authority. Permits are not transferable from one (1) person to another or from one (1) location to another location, except as otherwise permitted by this article. A valid permit must be posted in or on every food establishment regulated by this article. 
(b)  A food establishment operated solely by a nonprofit organization is exempt from the permitting requirements of this article, but is not exempt from compliance with state rules. The regulatory authority may require any information necessary to determine whether an organization is nonprofit for purposes of this exemption. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-23. - Application for permits and fees. 
(a)  Any person desiring to operate a food establishment must make a written application for a permit on forms provided by the regulatory authority. The application must contain the name and address of each applicant, the location and type of the proposed food establishment and the applicable fee. An incomplete application will not be accepted. Failure to provide all required information, or falsifying information required may result in denial or revocation of the permit. Renewals of permits are required on an annual basis and the same information is required for a renewal permit as for an initial permit. 
(b)  Prior to the approval of an initial permit or the renewal of an existing permit, the regulatory authority will inspect the proposed food establishment to determine compliance with state laws and rules. A food establishment that does not comply with state laws and rules will be denied a permit or the renewal of a permit. 
(c)  A fee schedule will be adopted by the San Patricio County Commissioner's Court. These fees will be payable to the San Patricio County Treasurer to be deposited in a special account and expended only to defray the cost of issuance of permits and inspections of facilities regulated under this article. An audited statement detailing the receipts of funds collected under this ordinance and all expenditures of funds and fund balances will be filed with the department of state health service on or before the 31st day of January each year. 
(d)  Permits are required for all temporary events such as carnivals, festivals or other related events if they sell food or beverages to the public. The regulatory authority does not differentiate between full-time and part-time employees. All food service permits are required and must be paid prior to the last day in January of each year. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-24. - Review of plans. 
(a)  Whenever a food establishment is constructed or extensively remodeled and whenever an existing structure is converted to use as a food establishment, properly prepared plans and specifications for such construction, remodeling or conversion will be submitted to the San Patricio County Department of Public Health for review before work is begun. Extensive remodeling means that twenty (20) percent or greater of the area of the food establishment is to be remodeled. The plans and specifications will indicate the proposed layout, equipment arrangement, mechanical plans and construction of materials in work areas, and the type and model of proposed fixed equipment and facilities. San Patricio County Department of Public Health will approve the plans and specifications if they meet the requirements of the rules adopted by this article. The approved plans and specification must be followed in construction, remodeling or conversion. 
(b)  Plans will meet all codes of the city. Failure to follow the approval plans and specifications will result in a permit denial, suspension, or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-25. - Suspension of permit. 
(a)  The regulatory authority may, without warning, notice, or hearing suspended any permit to operate a food establishment if the operation of the food establishment constitutes an imminent hazard to public health. Suspension is effective upon service of the notice required by subsection (b). When a permit is suspended, food operations will immediately cease. Whenever a permit is suspended, the holder of the permit will be afforded an opportunity for a hearing within twenty (20) days of receipt of a request for a hearing. 
(b)  Whenever a permit is suspended, holders of the permit or the person in charge will be notified in writing that the permit is, upon service of the notice, immediately suspended, and that an opportunity for a hearing will be provided if a written request for a hearing is filed with the regulatory authority by the holder of the permit within ten (10) days. If no written request for hearing is filed within ten (10) days, the suspension is sustained. The regulatory authority may end the suspension at any time if reasons for suspension no longer exist. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-26. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The regulatory authority may, after providing opportunity for a hearing, revoke a permit for serious or repeated violations of any of the requirements of these rules or for interference with regulatory authority in the performance of its duties. Prior to revocation, the regulatory authority will notify the holder for the permit or the person in charge, in writing, of the reason for which the permit is subject to revocation and that the permit will be revoked at the end of the ten (10) days following service of such notice unless a written request for a hearing is filled with the regulatory by the holder of the permit within this ten-day period. 
(b)  If no request for hearing is filed within the ten-day period, the revocation of the permit becomes final. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-27. - Administrative process. 
(a)  A notice as required in these rules is properly served when it is delivered to the holder of the permit or the person is change, or when it is sent by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, to the last known address of the holder of the permit. A copy of the notice will be filed in the records of the regulatory authority. 
(b)  The regulatory authority will conduct the hearing provided for in these rules at a time and place designated by it. Based upon the recorded evidence of such hearing, the regulatory authority will make final findings, and will sustain, modify or rescind any notice or order considered in the hearing. A written report of the hearing decision will be furnished to the holder of the permit by the regulatory authority. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-28. - Remedies. 
(a)  Any person who violates a provision of these rules and any person who are the permit holders of or otherwise operates a food service establishment that does not comply with the requirements of these rules and any responsible officer of the permit holder or those persons will be guilty of a class C misdemeanor and will be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day on which a violation occurs constitutes a separate offense. 
(b)  The regulatory authority may seek to enjoin violations of these rules. 
(c)  The regulatory authority may seek administration penalties not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day and each day a violation continues or occurs is a separate violation. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-29. - Education requirements. 
(a)  Employees of food services establishments, mobile food vending units, roadside food vendors, and employees of food service facilities within a retail food store will attend a two-hour food service sanitation course offered under the supervision or approval of the regulatory authority. Upon completion of the course, the regulatory authority will issue a food handlers certificate. The certificate will remain valid for a period of three (3) years. Prior to the expiration date of the food handlers certificate one is required to follow the initial steps of retaking the two-hour food handlers certification course and repeat this process each time the certification becomes expired. A food handlers certificate will be obtained by new employees within thirty (30) days after being hired. An employee's card may be revoked at any time by the regulatory authority if an employee demonstrates unsanitary work habits. 
    All owners/managers are required to complete a department of state health service accredited fifteen-hour food manager's training course recognized by the regulatory authority. This course may be taken from a certified food managers training program. Suitable certificates issued for passing an approved food managers examination must be filed and recorded with the regulatory authority. A nominal administration fee will be required at that time. A license will then be issued by the regulatory authority. The food managers certificate holder is responsible for recertifying their certificate as required by the department of state health services. Both employees and manager's certificates may be revoked if inspection reveals inadequate sanitation practices. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-30. - Examination and condemnation of food. 
    The authorized agent or employee may examine food as often as necessary for the enforcement of this article and the state laws and rules. The authority agent may, upon written notice to the owner or person in charge, place a hold order on any food, which it believes is in violation of any state laws. A written notice must specify the reason for the hold order. The authorized agent will tag, label, or otherwise identify any food subject to the hold order. No food subject to the hold order will be used, served or moved from the establishment. The authorized agent will permit storage of the food under conditions specified in the hold order, unless storage is not possible without risk to the public health, in which case immediate destruction will be ordered and accomplished. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Sec. 8-31. - Retail food establishment inspection report. 
    The city adopts the regulatory authority's retail food establishment inspection report. See Appendix A. 
(Ord. No. 2002, § 2, 12-16-08) 
Editor's note- The Appendix A referred to in this section is not set out at length herein, but is on file in the offices of the city. 
Chapter 81/2 - SHORELINE PROTECTION[1]

ARTICLE II. - SHORELINE ACCESS AND WETLANDS PRESERVATION FUND 

Sec. 81/2-21. - Created; management of disbursements. 
(a)  A "Shoreline Access and Wetlands Preservation Fund" is hereby created for grant funds, non-refundable private donations and contributions. 
(b)  Disbursements from this designated fund may only support the planning, acquisition, improvement, operation, management, maintenance, repair, protection or preservation of shoreline property and wetlands. 
(c)  This designated fund will be managed by the finance director and subjected to audit. The city council will approve all designated fund disbursements in advance. 
(Ord. No. 978, §§ 1-3, 11-17-98) 
Chapter 10 - LIBRARY 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Library fees. 
    The fee for an overdue book, periodical, multimedia package, film, audio cassette or compact disc shall be five cents ($0.05) per day and the fee for an overdue video cassette or audio-visual hardware shall be one dollar ($1.00) per day. Overdue fees shall not exceed one-half (1/2) the purchase price of the overdue item. The fee for losing an item shall be the cost to replace it. 
(Ord. No. 749, § 1(10-23), 11-10-86; Ord. No. 1069, § 1, 2-18-03) 
Sec. 10-2. - Failure to return property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or intentionally fail to return any city property to the Bell/Whittington Public Library within thirty (30) days after the property is due to be returned under the rules and regulations of the library. Upon conviction thereof, such person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. Each separate book, pamphlet, periodical, paper, or other item of property not returned to the Bell/Whittington Public Library in violation hereof shall constitute a separate offense. For purposes of this section, "property" shall include, but not be limited to, books, periodicals, pamphlets, papers, audiovisual materials and equipment, or other property that has been taken or borrowed from the Bell/Whittington Public Library. 
(b)  Prior to the filing of a complaint against an individual for violation of this section, the staff of the Bell/Whittington Public Library shall prepare and mail to the person shown by library records to be in possession of the property an overdue notice describing the particular property, the due date for return of such property, the library bar code number for such property, and the patron library card bar code number, name and address. A copy of the notice that library property is overdue, together with evidence that the notice was mailed to the individual at the most current address known to the library staff, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the individual had knowledge that such property is overdue under the rules and regulations of the library. 
(Ord. No. 770, § 1, 5-3-88) 
Sec. 10-3. - Illegal removal of materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to take, remove or borrow from the Bell/Whittington Public Library any book, pamphlet, periodical, paper or other property of said library except in accordance with the rules and regulations of the library. Upon conviction thereof, such person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. Each separate book, pamphlet, periodical, paper or other item of property removed from the Bell/Whittington Public Library in violation of said rules shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 770, § 1, 5-3-88) 
Sec. 10-4. - Damage or injury to library and/or materials. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly, intentionally or recklessly cut, mutilate, mark, tear, write upon, deface, or otherwise destroy or injure in whole or in part any book, pamphlet, periodical, map, audiovisual material or document, picture or written, or engraved or printed paper belonging to the public library; or knowingly, intentionally or recklessly suffer any such injury to be inflicted upon any of the furniture or property in the building of the Bell/Whittington Public Library; or knowingly, intentionally or recklessly mark or deface or in any way injure said library or any part thereof or any fixture therein or appurtenances thereto. Upon conviction thereof, said person shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. Each separate book, pamphlet, periodical, paper or other item of property injured or damaged under this section shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 770, § 1, 5-3-88) 
Secs. 10-5-10-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[1] 

Footnotes:
