(b)  Upon a showing under the provisions of section 19-28, one (1) additional driveway will be permitted, provided that this additional driveway is no closer than thirty-five (35) feet from the driveway or driveways permitted under subsection (a). 
(Ord. No. 242, § 3, 11-3-65) 
Sec. 19-22. - Safety zones separating commercial driveways. 
    Safety zones separating driveways shall be outlined by curbs or posts as necessary to prohibit parking or driving across zones for all nonresidential uses. If curbs are used, they shall be concrete or masonry barrier type curbs approved by the city engineer, not less than six (6) inches in height. If posts are used, they shall be round, six (6) inches in diameter, with domed tops, two and three-quarters (23/4) feet in length, and shall be installed six (6) feet apart, extending fifteen (15) inches above the ground, painted white, and shall have reflector buttons or patches for night visibility when feasible. The barrier line nearest the street shall not be less than twenty-two (22) feet from the center of the pavement or on line with existing curbs or established curb lines. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 3, 11-3-65) 
Sec. 19-23. - General sidewalk requirements. 
(a)  Every residential driveway shall be so designed and constructed as to provide for a sidewalk having a minimum width of five (5) feet, measured at right angles to the boundary line between the public right-of-way and the private property. Such sidewalk shall be constructed so as to have one (1) edge thereof in line with the existing sidewalk, if there be one (1), and if there be no existing sidewalk, the sidewalk shall be so constructed as to have one (1) edge thereof coinciding with the boundary line between the public right-of-way and the private property line, or in keeping with the general practice established by the existence of sidewalks on a majority of the property within the block where the driveway in question is to be placed. 
(b)  Commercial driveways shall be designed and constructed so as to provide sidewalks complying with specifications prescribed by the city engineer and approved by the city council. 
(c)  Sidewalks shall be constructed at an elevation so as to provide for a minimum of one-fourth (1/4) inch per foot fall from the edge of the sidewalk farthest from the property line to the top of the curb in business and commercial areas. Sidewalks in other areas will be located in accordance with the subdivision regulations of the city, except that, where there is an established practice in the block, sidewalks shall be located to match existing walks. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 3, 11-3-65) 
Cross reference- Subdivision regulations, App. B. 
Sec. 19-24. - Material requirements. 
    All driveways, and approaches, ramps and sidewalks constructed in connection therewith, for business and commercial establishments, shall be constructed of concrete having a minimum of twenty-five hundred (2500) psi in twenty-eight (28) days, and shall have a minimum thickness of six (6) inches, and shall have reinforcing [reinforcements] consisting of a minimum of six-inch by six-inch No. 6 wire mesh, except that driveway approaches and ramps may be constructed of asphalt. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 3, 11-3-65) 
Sec. 19-25. - Grades to be fixed by city engineer. 
    The grade for all driveways, and curbs, sidewalks and ramps constructed in connection therewith, shall be fixed by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 3, 11-3-65) 
Sec. 19-26. - Where ramp to reach sidewalk grade. 
    Where a ramp section of a driveway is to be constructed, the ramp shall reach the grade of the sidewalk at a distance of not less than five (5) feet from the outside edge of the street curb line. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 3, 11-3-65) 
Sec. 19-27. - Curb return; combined property frontage for combined access facility. 
    Except where the curb is a roll-type curb, the curb return on all driveways shall have a minimum radius of not less than two and one-half (21/2) feet and the point where the return falls tangent to the curb shall be within the property lines extended of [off] the property which the driveway is designed to serve. Curb sections that need to be removed to accommodate new or reconditioned driveways will be saw cut at right angles to the street at a point extending a minimum of eighteen (18) inches from the end of the curb return radius on either side of the drive. Driveway/curb sections shall be so constructed as to maintain the grade in the existing curb flow-line. Breaking of the curb at the flow-line for driveway installation will not be allowed under any circumstances. Subgrade located under the new driveway and curb section shall be extended a minimum distance of five (5) feet from the edge of pavement towards property and will be excavated to a depth of four (4) inches and replaced with compacted crushed limestone or other approved backfill material. Lateral expansion joints should be located at appropriate intervals to allow for possible removal for utility repairs but, at a minimum, shall be installed at the owner's property line. Should two (2) or more adjacent grantees agree to combine their property frontage for a combined access facility, it would be authorized under the applicable regulations. The frontage will then be a portion of the right-of-way lying between the most distant possible lines of the combined frontage drawn perpendicularly from the centerline of the street to the grantees' abutting property line. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 3, 11-3-65; Ord. No. 931, § II, 12-3-96) 
Sec. 19-28. - Variances. 
(a)  Upon a showing that unusual circumstances exist, or that a need for a driveway of greater width exists, or some other variance from the requirements set forth in this article should be made, where such variances will not be contrary to the public interest, and that literal enforcement of the provisions of this article will result in unnecessary hardship, such regulations may be varied, by the approval of the city manager, provided that, in no instance, shall any driveway opening be in excess of forty-five (45) feet in width. Any person requesting that such regulations be varied, because of unusual circumstances, shall file a written request therefor with the city manager, setting forth the circumstances to show that literal enforcement of the provisions of this article will result in unnecessary hardship. The city manager shall either approve or deny, in writing, a request for such variance, within a reasonable time but in no event shall the city manager withhold his decision for more than thirty (30) days. 
(b)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the city manager under the provisions of this section shall have the right to appeal to the city council, upon giving written notice to the city council within five (5) days after the refusal of the application made by him for the permit required by this article. 
(Ord. No. 242, § 4, 11-3-65) 
Secs. 19-29-19-38. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ASSESSMENTS FOR STREET IMPROVEMENTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 754, § 1, adopted March 17, 1987, amended Ch. 19 by adding a new Art. III, §§ 19-29-19-36. In order to conform to Code format, and in order to provide for the inclusion of future provisions in Art. II of Ch. 11, the editor, at his discretion, has redesignated these new provisions as §§ 19-39-19-46. 

Sec. 19-39. - Initiation by city council. 
    The city council, on its own initiative or in response to a petition as described below, may determine the necessity for the improvement of streets, sidewalks, curbs, gutters, and driveways in the city, and provide for the construction of such improvements, and for the assessment of the costs thereof against the owners of property abutting thereto by the following procedure: 
(a)  The city council shall by resolution determine the necessity for the improvement of the street or streets and related improvements then being considered by the city. The resolution shall authorize and direct the city engineer and city staff to prepare plans, specifications, estimates of cost of improvements, and an assessment roll of abutting property owners for such project, and shall further authorize the advertisement for bids for the construction of such improvements. 
(b)  The city secretary shall issue and publish as required by law notice for the taking of such bids, which bids shall not be received earlier than fourteen (14) days from the date of this first publication. 
(c)  The city secretary shall file notice of the assessment proceedings in the San Patricio County Land Records. 
(d)  The city council shall receive bids and, consistent with state law, the City Charter and this Code of Ordinances, in its discretion, accept a bid and adopt a resolution awarding the contract for such improvements, or reject all bids and call for new bids. The city council further by resolution shall call a public hearing on the proposed assessment roll, and shall direct the city secretary to place at least three (3) notices of said hearing in a newspaper published in the city, the first publication of which shall be at least twenty-one (21) days before the hearing, and to mail notices to the owners of property abutting the section of street to be improved at least fourteen (14) days prior to the hearing, all in accordance with applicable state statutes. 
(e)  At the time and place set forth in the notice of hearing, the city council shall hold a public hearing on the proposed assessment roll for construction of the street improvements. At the hearing, the city shall provide expert testimony as to the enhanced value resulting to the abutting property owners from the proposed street improvements. All persons entitled by law to be heard at such hearing shall have the right to address any matter permitted by law. Thereafter, the city council shall adopt an ordinance closing the public hearing and levying such assessments against the abutting property owners as it may determine, consistent with applicable law. Said ordinance shall assess the abutting property owners for their pro rata share cost of the improvements, the same to be a personal liability of said owners, and establish a first and prior lien to the extent permitted under applicable state law against the respective abutting properties to secure payment of such assessments. 
(f)  Construction shall commence, and upon its completion, the city council shall adopt a resolution accepting the improvements and authorizing preparation of the assessment certificates. The assessment certificates shall then be prepared, signed and recorded in the San Patricio Land Records. 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-29), 3-17-87) 
Sec. 19-40. - Request by property owners for street improvements study. 
    The owners of real property abutting a public street located within the city may request of the city a preliminary engineering study and report concerning improvement of all or part of such street by presenting to the city engineer a letter of request for consideration of a street improvement project. The request shall be submitted on forms made available by the office of the city engineer. Such letter of request must specify the proposed length and location of the portion of the street for which the study is requested, and must be signed by persons constituting at least fifty-one (51) percent of the property owners and owning at least fifty-one (51) percent of the property frontage involved in the requested improvement study. Such letter of request shall designate one (1) property owner residing on such street as the representative of the property owners filing the request for communications with the city engineer and city staff. 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-30), 3-17-87) 
Sec. 19-41. - Preliminary engineering study and report. 
(a)  Upon receipt of a properly filed letter of request, the city engineer shall initiate a preliminary engineering study to determine the minimum practical project for improvement of the street and the type of construction best suited for that particular project. The city engineer and city staff shall prepare a report setting forth the minimum street improvement project which the city will undertake for the street in question. Such report may require construction of improvements on a longer or shorter section of street than that proposed in the letter of request. Such report shall show the current record title owners, legal descriptions of properties, and the front footage of each lot abutting on the portion of the street for which improvements are proposed, and the amount of the assessment which shall be borne by each abutting property owner, as determined in accordance with the front foot plan or rule. Upon completion of the report, a copy of the report shall be forwarded to the designated representative of the persons submitting the letter of request. 
(b)  For purposes of preparing the preliminary engineering study and report, the city engineer's computation of assessments against the abutting property owners for street improvements shall be calculated as follows: 
(1)  For platted property, the owners of property abutting upon the section of street to be improved shall be assessed the following amounts: 
a.  Construction of an asphalt street with curb and gutter -One-third ( 1/3 ) of current cost of construction per linear foot, as determined by the city engineer. 
b.  Construction of sidewalk -The entire current cost of construction per linear foot, as determined by the city engineer. 
c.  Construction of curb and gutter -The entire current cost of construction per linear foot, less any credit given for existing curb and gutter, as determined by the city engineer. 
d.  Construction or rebuilding of concrete driveway approaches -The entire current cost of construction per square yard, as determined by the city engineer. 
(2)  For unplatted property, regardless of the zoning classification, the owners of property abutting the section of street being improved shall pay the full cost of construction of all street improvements, sidewalks, curbs and gutters, and concrete driveway approaches. 
    The above assessment calculations are not binding upon the city, and are intended solely for use in the preliminary engineering study. The assessments may be altered by the city council within the limits prescribed by applicable state law, after due consideration of the special benefits accruing to the abutting property owners, prior to final adoption of an assessment ordinance by city council. 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-31), 3-17-87) 
Sec. 19-42. - Requirements for petition-Signatures and cash deposit. 
    For the preliminary engineering study and report to receive consideration by the city council, a petition incorporating the study and report must be signed by persons constituting seventy-five (75) percent of the abutting property owners and owning at least seventy-five (75) percent of the frontage involved in the proposed street improvement project. The petition shall be filed with the city secretary, with a cash deposit equal to fifteen (15) percent of the total amount of the property owner assessments, as shown by the city engineer's calculations in the preliminary engineering study and report. The cash deposit shall include a statement of the name, address and amount given of each contributor to the cash deposit. In the event that the city council fails to approve the proposed improvement project within four (4) months of the submission of the petition, said deposit shall be refunded without interest to the individuals named as contributing to the deposit. In the event the city council approves a plan for the street improvements and levies assessments against the abutting property owners, the deposit shall be applied to the cost of construction, and individuals contributing to the deposit shall be credited for their respective contributions. The city shall have no duty to verify the accuracy of the statement accompanying the cash deposit, and may rely conclusively on such statement in refunding or crediting the cash deposit. 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-32), 3-17-87) 
Sec. 19-43. - Evaluation of petition by city council. 
    The petition shall be reviewed by the city staff, which shall certify to the city council that the petition meets all of the requirements of this article, and that the aforesaid deposit has been made with the city. If the city council determines that such requested improvements are needed and represent a feasible improvement project for the city, the city council shall by resolution determine the necessity for the improvement of such street and order the preparation of all matters necessary for the completion of such project, as set forth in section 19-39(a) through (f) of this article. 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-33), 3-17-87) 
Sec. 19-44. - Certificates of assessment and mechanic's lien contracts. 
(a)  The city council may issue in the name of the city assignable certificates in evidence of assessments levied for the construction of the improvements described in this article. Said certificates shall be issued in the manner and form permitted by applicable state law, as amended from time to time. 
(b)  The city council may, either in lieu of or in addition to certificates of assessment, provide for the execution of mechanic's lien notes and contracts (with power of sale) by the owners of property abutting the section of street to be improved. Such lien notes and contracts shall be executed prior to the commencement of work on the project. Any abutting property owner may, either before or after the assessment hearing provided for in section 19-39, stipulate with the city as to the value of the special benefits to accrue to his property as the result of the proposed improvements, and execute a mechanic's lien note and contract (with power of sale) in an agreed amount not exceeding the value of such special benefits. 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-34), 3-17-87) 
Sec. 19-45. - Terms of payment of assessment. 
    The property owner assessments for street improvements may be paid either in cash within thirty (30) days after the completion of such street improvements, or in equal monthly installments of principal and interest over a period not exceeding eighty-four (84) months, at a simple annual interest rate not to exceed the greater of eight (8) percent or the rate payable by the city on its most recently issued general obligation bonds, determined as of the date of the first published notice for the hearing required under section 19-39(d). 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-35), 3-17-87) 
Sec. 19-46. - Vested interests; alteration of procedures. 
    No person, firm or corporation shall have any vested interest in the procedures set forth in this article and such procedures may be changed or altered by the city council in the manner provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 754, § 1(19-36), 3-17-87) 
Secs. 19-47-19-55. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - STREET CONSTRUCTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Provisions designated as Art. IV, §§ 19-56, 19-57 are derived from Ord. No. 836. Words in brackets [ ] have been added by the editor for clarity. Such ordinance has not been set out at length herein due to the technical nature of the subject matter. 

Sec. 19-56. - Standards established. 
    As of May 19, 1992, all streets constructed, or reconstructed within the corporate limits of the city shall, at a minimum be constructed to the standards established in Ordinance No. 836. [Such ordinance is not set out at length herein, but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city secretary and the engineer.] 
(Ord. No. 836, 5-19-92) 
Sec. 19-57. - Penalties for violations. 
(a)  Fines. 
(1)  Any person who shall be convicted of violating any part of Ordinance No. 836 may be fined up to one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for each violation. Each day a violation continues shall be deemed a separate violation. 
(2)  In addition to proceeding under authority of subsection (1) of this section, the city is entitled to pursue all other criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes or other ordinances against a person violating Ordinance No. 836. 
(b)  Penalty for criminal mischief. The city may pursue all criminal and civil remedies to which it is entitled under authority of statutes and ordinances against any person who negligently, willfully or maliciously causes loss or damage to the public streets or appurtenances. 
(Ord. No. 836, Art. 9, 5-12-92) 
Sec. 19-58. - Construction of streets and sidewalks; drawings established. 
    The attached Exhibit "A"* containing detailed drawings of the construction of streets and sidewalks in the City of Portland is hereby made a part of this section. All street and sidewalk construction proposed for public use within the corporate limits of the City of Portland shall conform to these standards. 
(Ord. No. 901, § 1, 3-21-95) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 901, § 1, adopted March 21, 1995, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 19-58 at the discretion of the editor. 
* Exhibit "A" referenced in this section 19-68 is not set out herein, but on file as an attachment to Ord. No. 901 in the appropriate city offices. 
Secs. 19-59-19-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ALTERING, ABANDONING, CLOSING OR VACATING STREETS, ALLEYS OR PUBLIC WAYS; PROCEDURE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 847, §§ 1-10, 12, adopted Nov. 11, 1992, enacted provisions pertaining to the procedure for abandoning, vacating, etc., streets, alleys and other throughways. Such provisions have been designated as Art. V, §§ 19-17-19-81. Subsequently, Ord. No. 1020, § 1, adopted Oct. 17, 2000, amended Art. V to read as herein set out. See the Code Comparative Table. 

Sec. 19-71. - Request to purchase. 
    Persons who wish to purchase property dedicated to the City of Portland as a street, alley or public way shall file a written request with the city manager. The request shall include a map, plat or survey that locates as well as describes the property to be purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 10-17-00) 
Sec. 19-72. - Administrative fee required. 
    A one hundred fifty dollar ($150.00) administrative fee shall be paid at the time a written request is filed to cover the costs associated with staff research and public notification. 
(Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 10-17-00) 
Sec. 19-73. - Sales restricted. 
(a)  Neither streets that provide the sole means of access to properties nor alleys being used to access adjacent properties may be sold in their entirety. Portions of such streets and alleys may be sold if adequate access to properties can be guaranteed. In no event shall street right-of-way be less than fifty (50) feet in width or alleys less than fifteen (15) feet in width following sale. 
(b)  Property owners immediately adjacent to streets, alleys or public ways shall have first right to purchase adjacent streets, alleys or public ways to the centerline of their right-of-way if the city council agrees to sell them. Adjacent right-of-way may not be sold to any other person without a written release from the property owner immediately adjacent. 
(c)  A street, alley or public way that contains public utilities or serves as a drainage way may not be sold without the dedication of an appropriate easement or without removal of the utilities. The dedication of utility or drainage easements may be required to meet future needs even if the right-of-way to be sold does not contain public utilities or currently serve as a drainage way. 
(d)  The city shall not sell property dedicated as a street, alley or public way for less than its appraised value. Appraised value shall normally be the appraised value of adjacent unimproved property determined by the San Patricio County Appraisal District (property to be dedicated as an easement shall be discounted fifty (50) percent), however, an independent appraisal may be required by the city manager to establish appraised value in the following cases: 
(1)  The street, alley or public way to be sold is located in the "OT-2" Olde Town District, "P" Professional Office District, "C-R" Retail Commercial District, "C-G" General Commercial District or "I" Industrial District. 
(2)  The street, alley or public way to be sold in any other zoning district is large enough to be platted and developed as a separate lot. 
(3)  The street, alley or public way to be sold in any other zoning district will permit a separate lot to be platted and developed. 
(e)  Any person who purchases property dedicated as a street, alley or public way shall pay the cost of the appraisal, if required, all closing costs, hold the city harmless for damages created by the sale of the property and appropriately plat the property purchased. 
(Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 10-17-00; Ord. No. 1112, § 1, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 19-74. - Feasibility study and recommendation required. 
    The city manager or his designee shall study the feasibility of selling property dedicated for streets, alleys or public ways and prepare a formal recommendation for the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 10-17-00) 
Sec. 19-75. - Public hearing to be conducted. 
(a)  When the feasibility study has been completed, a public hearing before the city council shall be scheduled. A legal notice of the public hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation in Portland at least five (5) days before the hearing is conducted and written notices mailed to owners of property within two hundred (200) feet of the property to be sold at least ten (10) days before the hearing is conducted. 
(b)  The city council shall conduct a public hearing before it formally considers the sale of property dedicated as a street, alley or public way. The person who wishes to purchase such property shall be given an opportunity to make a presentation, the city manager or his designee shall present a formal recommendation and all affected parties shall be given an opportunity to speak. 
(Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 10-17-00) 
Sec. 19-76. - Ordinance authorizing sale of property. 
    The sale of property dedicated as a street, alley or public way shall only be authorized by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1020, § 1, 10-17-00) 
Sec. 19-77. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2067, § 1, adopted Feb. 19, 2013, repealed § 19-77 which pertained to waiver of specific requirements and derived from Ord. No. 1161, § 1, adopted Dec. 19, 2006. 
Secs. 19-78-19-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ADDRESSING STANDARDS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 970, §§ 1-7, adopted Aug. 18, 1998, did not specifically amend the Code hence; inclusion as Art. VI, §§ 19-101-19-104 was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 19-101. - Street names. 
(a)  All street names within the City of Portland are hereby declared public property, subject to change by the City Council with or without notice, consistent with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  A master street addressing guide (MSAG) shall be maintained by the city. 
(c)  Names of new streets created hereafter shall not duplicate the name of any existing street anywhere within the limits of the City of Portland. Duplication means names that have either the same spelling or are so phonetically similar as to create confusion. 
(d)  Where one street joins another so as to form a logical extension of the two streets, both streets shall bear the same name and shall become one continuous street. 
(e)  Streets following a logical and continuous path from one point to another point shall bear a single name regardless of changes in direction along the continuous path. 
(f)  Street names shall not contain more than twenty (20) characters, exclusive of any prefixes or suffixes. 
(g)  Street name suffixes, such as "Street", "Road", "Lane", "Boulevard", "Drive", "Parkway", "Avenue", "Place", "Court", "Cove", "Trail", "Way", "North", "East", "West", or "South" may be used at the discretion of the city council. 
(h)  Street name suffixes, such as "Circle", "Loop", and "Cul-de-sac" shall be used only when a street actually forms a circle, loop, or cul-de-sac. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 1, 8-18-98) 
Sec. 19-102. - Street name signs. 
(a)  Street name signs are hereby declared public property and shall be erected and maintained by the City of Portland consistent with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Street name signs shall be installed at the intersection of all streets and highways and at other locations deemed necessary by the city council. 
(c)  Street name sign plates shall be constructed of aluminum or other suitable material having a thickness of at least .080 inches, with dimensions of six (6) inches high and at least by twenty-four (24) inches wide, and shall be faced with a thermosetting-setting acrylic-backed enamel or other suitable material, with a green background and white reflectorized copy. 
(d)  Street name sign copy shall be four (4) inch, upper case standard alphabet with prefixes and suffixes of two (2) inch, upper case standard alphabet. 
(e)  Block numbers shall be affixed to all street name signs using two (2) inch, standard alphabet placed above the suffix abbreviation. 
(f)  Street name signs shall be mounted on high strength aluminum alloy or galvanized steel tubing at least two and three-eighths (2 3/8 ) inches in diameter. 
(g)  Street name signs shall be erected a minimum of nine (9) feet above the level of the nearest pavement edge to the bottom of the sign. If a traffic control sign is mounted below and on the same pole as a street name sign, the bottom of the traffic control sign shall be at least seven (7) feet above the nearest pavement edge. 
(h)  The city may establish street names and erect street name signs at the entrances to private roads or drives when more than one (1) individual residence or building is serviced by the private road. The installation of a street sign in such cases shall be solely for the purpose of aiding in an emergency response and shall not imply that the city assumes any responsibility for maintenance of the private road or drive. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 2, 8-18-98; Ord. No. 1159, § I, 12-5-06) 
Sec. 19-103. - Address numbers. 
(a)  Address number ranges are hereby declared public property and shall be subject to change by the city council, with or without notice. 
(b)  All addresses numbers should be uniform, based on street frontage. The street name portion of an assigned address shall be the street or roadway to which the front entrance of the structure or house faces. 
(c)  Even and odd numbers shall always be on opposite sides of the street. For north-south streets, odd numbers shall be on west side of the street and even numbers on the east. For east-west streets, odd numbers shall be on the north side of street and even numbers on the south. This requirement shall not apply when its application to the extension of an existing street would create a conflict. 
(d)  Numbering shall be consecutive, but allow for possible future growth and development. Where practical, the number range for a street should be begin at the end of a street nearest the center of the city and increase in an outward direction. Address numbers on parallel streets should be comparable when possible. 
(e)  Street address number ranges shall begin no lower than "100." Single and double digit numbers are not permitted. 
(f)  In residential subdivisions, lots shall be numbered with no intervals between adjacent lots. In non-residential or commercial areas, numbering may include appropriate intervals between existing commercial lots so as to allow for future construction and/or replatting. 
(g)  Landlocked parcels having a "legal tract" status may not be assigned an address without a legally documented access easement to a dedicated right-of-way. 
(h)  The city building official shall maintain the official city addressing map with established block number assignments and shall, when requested, issue a corresponding address number to new houses and buildings consistent with the requirements of this section. 
(i)  Upon issuance of a new address number or revision of any existing number range, address number or street name, the city building official shall notify the city's 9-1-1 coordinator. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 3, 8-18-98) 
Sec. 19-104. - Requirements of owners/occupants. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of every house, building, or address location shall maintain a properly assigned address number in a conspicuous place clearly visible from the street. 
(b)  Address numbers shall be affixed to the house or building, except that when a house or building is situated with more than a one hundred-foot setback from the roadway, or when vegetation or fencing visually obscures the house or building, then the owner of occupant shall affix the address numbers at a location near to, and visible from, the roadway. 
(c)  Address numbers shall be at least three (3) inches high and shall be of a contrasting color to the background. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to alter, deface, or take down address numbers placed on any property, except for the repair or replacement of such numbers. 
(e)  No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any house or building until the owner or occupant has procured an address number from the city building official and affixed that number to the property as required by this section. 
(f)  Street address numbers for apartments, trailer parks, and motels shall be a single address number assigned to the main entrance. 
(g)  Owners or managers of multi-family buildings, apartments, trailer parks, and motels shall assign suffix numbers or letters to individual tenants in units, buildings or lots, consistent with this section. 
(h)  The overall appearance of building numbers is to be consistent within multiple building developments sharing a common driveway entrance. Unit, apartment, or suite numbers are to be consistent within each building. 
(i)  Individual owners or occupants of apartments, trailers or motels shall install assigned suffix numbers or letters consistent with the requirements of homeowners and building owners as described and established elsewhere in this section. 
(j)  Condominiums and townhouses developed on any named street may, at the discretion of the city council, be treated as individual residences for the purpose of addressing so long as the condominiums or townhouses are situated along the named street in a fashion similar to individual homes. Condominiums and townhouses that are located on and accessible only by a private drive shall be numbered consistent with requirements of apartments, trailer parks and motels as described and established elsewhere in this section. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 4, 8-18-98) 
Sec. 19-105. - Developers. 
(a)  Developers or other persons who establish new streets and subdivisions shall provide a plat of the new subdivision or street to the City of Portland Building Official on a scale no larger than one (1) inch equals four hundred (400) feet. The plat may include proposed street names and shall include individual lot lines. 
(b)  Developers of subdivisions shall install street signs which meet the requirements established herein prior to the acceptance of the subdivision by the city. 
(Ord. No. 970, § 5, 8-18-98) 
Secs. 19-106-19-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - AUTO WRECKER SERVICES 

Sec. 19-121. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to all auto wreckers called on to transport vehicles on behalf of the city, its agents or police officers. 
(Ord. No. 1041, § 1, 9-18-01) 
Sec. 19-122. - Definitions. 
    "Non-consent tow" means the towing of a vehicle without the consent of the owner or operator of the vehicle. 
    "Auto wrecker" means any motor vehicle used or designed for the purpose of towing, carrying, pushing, or otherwise transporting a disabled or impounded vehicle. 
    "Vehicle storage facility" means a facility approved by the Texas Department of Transportation used to store impounded vehicles. 
    "Impounded vehicle" means any vehicle which police officers are authorized to impound and remove under the provisions of any ordinance of the City of Portland, any law of the State of Texas, or any contract or agreement with any law enforcement agency. 
(Ord. No. 1041, § 2, 9-18-01) 
Sec. 19-123. - Auto wrecker permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, or partnership to drive or operate, or cause to be driven or operated, any auto wrecker for the purpose of transporting a disabled or impounded vehicle on the streets of the city in response to a request by the police department without an auto wrecker permit issued under the provisions of this article. 
    Auto wreckers owned and operated by a governmental entity or performing a consent tow are exempt. 
    The chief of police shall issue auto wrecker permits. Permits shall expire one (1) year from the date of issue. A permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be required at the time of original issuance and each renewal. 
    Auto wrecker permits are nonassignable and may be revoked by the chief of police or his designated agent if it appears that the permittee, his agent or employee, has violated or failed to comply with any provisions of this ordinance or any applicable state or federal regulation or statute. 
(a)  Applicants for an auto wrecker permit shall provide the following documents at the time of original application and at each renewal: 
(1)  Current Texas vehicle storage facility license. 
(2)  Current Texas license and receipt for the auto wrecker to be permitted. 
(3)  Current Texas tow truck registration cab card. 
(4)  Current liability insurance for the auto wrecker to be permitted in the following amounts: 
a.  Liability ..... $300,000.00 
b.  Cargo ..... 25,000.00 
c.  In-tow ..... 25,000.00 
d.  All other insurance required by state and federal law. 
(5)  A certificate of insurance listing the City of Portland as an additional insured for each required policy. 
(b)  All auto wreckers shall be rated at no less than one (1) ton. All auto wreckers shall be minimally equipped as follows: 
(1)  Power-operated winch with a line/boom capacity of at least six thousand (6,000) pounds. 
(2)  A tow sling or hydraulic lift sufficient to prevent damage to any vehicle being towed. 
(3)  Steel safety chains. 
(4)  One (1) ten-pound BC or two (2) five-pound BC fire extinguishers. 
(5)  Pry bar. 
(6)  Broom and flat-edged shovel for collecting debris. 
(7)  Container suitable for collecting and transporting recovered debris. 
(8)  Three (3) portable red emergency reflectors. 
(9)  Towing dollies (not required for rollback wreckers). 
(10)  Rope or wire suitable for securing doors, hoods, trunks, etc. 
(11)  A spotlight or flashlight. 
(12)  Outside rear-view mirrors on both sides of truck. 
(13)  One (1) set of tow lights for towed vehicles. 
(14)  Amber or blue flashing or rotating emergency lights mounted at such a height as to be visible from the rear of the wrecker with a towed vehicle in place. 
(15)  Signs or placards on each door identifying the wrecker company. 
(16)  A police radio transceiver, or a police receiver and a cellular phone capable of clearly communicating with the police dispatcher. 
(c)  Storage facility requirements. 
(1)  An auto wrecker permit shall be issued only to an owner of a facility that meets the following requirements: 
a.  The facility must be enclosed by a wire or wooden fence at least six (6) feet high or as required by zoning ordinances, including a gate which is locked at all times when the facility is unattended. 
b.  The facility must have an all weather surface that enables the safe and effective movement of stored vehicles, regardless of the weather conditions. 
c.  A sign clearly visible and readable with the name of the facility, address, telephone number and hours of operation that vehicles can be released. 
d.  A sign clearly listing daily storage fees and all other fees that may be charged. 
e.  Adequate lighting for nighttime release of vehicles with a minimum of one (1) light fixture (at least two hundred fifty (250) watts) for each three (3) acres. 
f.  The facility must meet all other applicable city codes relating to building and zoning. 
g.  No vehicle towed under this section may be stored at a storage facility more than two (2) miles from the city limits of Portland. 
(2)  An auto wrecker permittee shall maintain liability insurance of not less than twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for injury to, or destruction of, the property of others. 
(d)  Non-consent fee. 
(1)  Any peace officer that authorizes the towing of a vehicle may also require its impoundment. 
(2)  An auto wrecker operator who performs a non-consent tow at the direction of a Portland Police Officer shall collect a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) from the owner or driver of the vehicle. The payment of such non-consent tow fee shall not excuse the owner or driver of the vehicle from any other charge or fine resulting from the violation of other provisions of this Code. 
(3)  An auto wrecker permittee shall remit all collected non-consent fees to the city on a quarterly basis. All collect fees shall be deposited in the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1041, § 3, 9-18-01; Ord. No. 2114 , § 1, 8-4-15) 
Sec. 19-124. - Chief of police to establish response time requirements. 
(a)  The chief of police may establish a maximum response time for all auto wreckers operating under this article. 
(b)  When a permittee or a permittee's agent accepts an assignment to respond to a tow request under this article, the permittee accepts the responsibility to respond to the assigned location not longer than the maximum response time. 
(c)  An auto wrecker permit may be revoked by the chief of police if the permittee fails to respond to an assigned location within the maximum response time requirement on three (3) or more occasions within a 60-day period. 
(Ord. No. 2114 , § 1, 8-4-15) 
Sec. 19-125. - Penalty. 
    A person violating any term or provision of this article shall be subject to a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). A person commits a separate offense for each violation that is committed or for possession of each item described under this article. 
(Ord. No. 2114 , § 2, 8-4-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2114 , § 2, adopted Aug. 4, 2015, did not specifically amend the Code, § 19-125; hence, its conclusion herein is at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 20 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Division of taxation, § 5.29. 
State Law reference- Taxation generally, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. Title 122, Vol. 20; Title 122A, Vol. 20A. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Residence homestead exemption for the elderly. 
    Pursuant to Section 11.13 of the Property Tax Code of the State of Texas, each taxpayer who has attained the age of sixty-five (65) years is hereby granted an exemption and shall not be taxed on the first fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) of the appraised value of his residence homestead in the City of Portland, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 646, § 1, 9-7-82; Ord. No. 979, § 1, 12-15-98) 
Sec. 20-2. - Additional sales and use tax. 
    The governing body has found and determined, and hereby finds and determines, that an additional sales and use tax in the amount of one-half of one (0.5) percent is hereby levied, imposed, ratified, and confirmed on the receipts from the sale at retail of taxable items within the city in accordance with the provisions of the Act, the Texas Tax Code, including, but not limited to, Section 321.102(a), as amended, Texas Tax Code, and all other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 887, § 1, 7-19-94) 
Secs. 20-3-20-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - OCCUPATIONAL TAX ON COIN-OPERATED MACHINES 

Sec. 20-16. - Definitions. 
    Words and phrases used in this article shall have the same meanings as ascribed to them in Title 122A, Chapter 13, Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes of Texas. 
Sec. 20-17. - Levied; amount. 
    Every owner who owns, controls, possesses, exhibits, displays, or who permits to be exhibited or displayed in the city, any coin-operated machine, shall pay and there is hereby levied on every coin-operated machine, except such as are exempted from taxation by state law, an annual occupation tax in an amount equal to one-half (1/2) of the state tax levied thereon. 
(Ord. No. 236, § 1, 7-20-65) 
State Law reference- Amount of state tax, V.A.T.S Tax.-Gen. art. 13.02; exemptions from tax, art. 13.03; authority of city to levy tax in amount equal to one-half (1/2) the state tax, art. 13.14. 
Sec. 20-18. - Issuance of license upon payment; license to be attached to or posted near machine. 
    Upon payment of the tax levied by this article, the city assessor-collector shall issue a license for the coin-operated machine, which license shall be securely attached to the machine in a manner that will require continued application of steam and water to remove the same, or it shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the machine so as to be easily seen by the public. 
(Ord. No. 236, § 2, 7-20-65) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.A.T.S. Tax.-Gen. art. 13.06. 
Sec. 20-19. - Tax period; prorating when paid after January first. 
    The tax levied herein is for a period of twelve (12) months. Upon the issuance of license after the first day of January of any one (1) year for the remainder of the year, there shall be collected such fractional part of the tax as the remaining months in the calendar year (including the month in which such tax is paid) bears to the twelve-month period. 
(Ord. No. 236, § 3, 7-20-65) 
Sec. 20-20. - Sealing machine for nonpayment. 
    Any member of the police force of the city shall seal any coin-operated machine on which the tax levied by this article has been paid, and the city assessor-collector shall charge a fee of five dollars ($5.00) for the release of any machine so sealed. Whoever shall break the seal so affixed in the name of the city, or display or remove from location any machine on which the seal has been broken, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 236, § 4, 7-20-65) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.A.T.S. Tax.-Gen. art. 13.15. 
Secs. 20-21-20-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 910, §§ 1-10, adopted December 19, 1995, was treated as superseding Art. III, §§ 20-31-20-37, in its entirety. Formerly, §§ 20-37 contained similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 577, §§ 1-7, adopted July 17, 1979. 

Sec. 20-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases are defined as follows: 
(a)  Hotel: Means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations, including hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses, or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a consideration, but not including hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes. 
(b)  Consideration: Means the cost of the room in a hotel only if the room is ordinarily used for sleeping, and not including the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying of such room for occupancy. 
(c)  Occupancy: Means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or rooms in a hotel if the room is one which is ordinarily used for sleeping and if the occupant is other than a permanent resident as hereinafter defined. 
(d)  Occupant: Means anyone who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has a right to use or possess any room or rooms in a hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract or agreement, other than a permanent resident as hereinafter defined. 
(e)  Person: Means any individual, company, corporation or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
(f)  Tax assessor-collector: Means the Tax Assessor and Collector of the City of Portland, Texas. 
(g)  Quarterly period: Means the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first quarter being composed of the months of October, November and December; the second quarter being the months of January, February and March; the third quarter being the months of April, May and June; and the fourth quarter being the months of July, August and September. 
(h)  Permanent resident: Means any occupant who has or shall have the right to occupancy of any room or rooms in a hotel for at least thirty (30) consecutive days during the calendar year or preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 1, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 20-32. - Levied; exception. 
    There is hereby levied a tax of seven (7) percent of the price paid for a room in a hotel on every person who, under a lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract, or agreement, pays for the use or possession, or for the right to the use or possession, of a room that is in a hotel, costs two dollars ($2.00) or more each day, and is ordinarily used for sleeping. The price of a room in a hotel does not include the cost of food served by the hotel and the cost of personal services performed by the hotel for the person except those services related to the cleaning and readying of the room for possession. Exceptions are as follows: 
(1)  No tax shall be imposed upon a permanent resident. 
(2)  No tax shall be imposed for federal or state employees traveling on official business. 
(3)  No tax shall be imposed for diplomatic personnel who present a tax exemption card issued by the United States Department of State. 
(4)  No tax shall be imposed for federal or state military personnel traveling on official military business. This exemption does not cover military staff on leave or between stations. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 2, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 20-33. - Collection. 
(a)  Any person operating a hotel, as defined by the Texas Tax Code Section 156.001, within the city must collect and remit to the City of Portland on the form prescribed by the finance director the occupancy tax previously established by the city. 
(b)  The hotel operator shall be entitled to one (1) percent of the hotel occupancy tax revenues collected as reimbursement for the operator's administrative costs for collecting the tax; however, as hereinbelow provided, this reimbursement may be forfeited at the discretion of the city if the hotel operator fails to timely pay over the tax or timely file a report as required by the city or files a false report with the city. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 3, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 1126, § 1, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 20-34. - Report and remittance of tax. 
    The report and the remittance of the taxes are due to the city no later than the last day of the month following the month in which the taxes are collected. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 4, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 1126, § 2, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 20-35. - Powers of tax assessor-collector; access to books and records. 
    The assessor-collector shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are reasonable and necessary to effectively collect the tax levied hereby, and shall upon reasonable notice have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article, and the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 5, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 20-36. - Penalties. 
(a)  Failure to report and pay the taxes collected in a timely manner will result in penalties and interest as per the following schedule: 
Penalty 5% if filed 1 to 29 days late, plus additional 5% if filed more than 30 days late Interest 10% per year beginning 60 days from the due date  
(b)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this article, including hotel operators who fail to collect the tax, fail to file a return, file a false return, or who are delinquent in their tax payment, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction, be fined in any sum not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00), and each twenty-four (24) hours of any such violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 6, 12-19-95; Ord. No. 1126, § 3, 7-19-05) 
Sec. 20-37. - Authority of city to take action against violators. 
    The city is hereby authorized to take the following actions against any person required to collect the tax imposed hereby and pay the collection over to the city and [who] has failed to file a report, or filed a false report, or failed to pay the tax when due: 
(1)  Require the forfeiture of any revenue the city allowed the hotel operator to retain for its cost of collecting the tax; 
(2)  Bring suit against the hotel for noncompliance; and/or 
(3)  Bring suit against the hotel seeking any other remedies provided under state law. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 7, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 20-38. - Legal suit against violators. 
    The city attorney is hereby authorized to bring suit against any person required to collect the tax imposed hereby and required to pay the collection over to the city and who has failed to file a report, or filed a false report, or failed to pay the tax when due. Such suit may seek to collect such tax not paid or to enjoin such person from operating a hotel in the city until the tax is paid or the report is filed or both, as applicable and as provided in the injunction. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 8, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 20-39. - Use of revenue. 
(a)  The revenue derived from any hotel occupancy tax imposed and levied by this article may be used only to promote tourism and the convention and hotel industry, and that use is limited to the following: 
(1)  The acquisition of sites for, and the construction, improvement, enlarging, equipping, repairing, operation, and maintenance of, convention center facilities, as such is defined in V.A.T.S. Tax Code, Section 351.001; 
(2)  The furnishing of facilities, personnel, and materials for the registration of convention delegates or registrants; 
(3)  Advertising and conducting solicitations and promotional programs to attract tourists and convention delegates or registrants to the municipality or its vicinity; 
(4)  The encouragement, promotion, improvement, and application of the arts, including instrumental and vocal music, dance, drama, folk art, creative writing, architecture, design and allied fields, painting, sculpture, photography, graphic and craft arts, motion pictures, radio, television, tape and sound recording, and other arts related to the presentation, performance, execution, and exhibition of these major art forms; and 
(5)  Historical restoration and preservation projects or activities or advertising and conducting solicitations and promotional programs to encourage tourists and convention delegates to visit preserved historic sites or museums which are: 
a.  At or in the immediate vicinity of convention center facilities; or 
b.  Located elsewhere in the municipality or its vicinity that would be frequented by tourists, convention delegates, or other visitors to the municipality. 
(b)  Revenue derived from the hotel occupancy tax shall be expended only in a manner which directly enhances and promotes tourism and the convention and hotel industry as hereinbefore delineated. Such revenue shall not be used for the general revenue purposes or general governmental operations of the municipality which are not directly related to promoting the hotel and convention industry of tourism in the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 9, 12-19-95) 
Sec. 20-40. - Administration; recordkeeping. 
(a)  The city council may, by contract, delegate to a person, including another governmental entity or a private organization, the management or supervision of programs and activities funded with revenue from the hotel occupancy tax. The city council shall approve in writing in advance the annual budget of the entity to which it delegates those functions, and shall require the entity to make periodic reports to the city council at least annually listing the expenditures made by the entity of revenue from the tax provided by the municipality. 
(b)  The entity must maintain the revenue provided by the municipality from the tax in a separate account established for that purpose and may not commingle that revenue with any other money or maintain it in any other account. 
(c)  The municipality may not delegate to any person or entity the management or supervision of its convention and visitors programs and activities funded with, revenue from the hotel occupancy tax other than by contract as provided herein. 
(d)  The approval by the city council of the annual budget of the entity to which these functions are delegated creates a fiduciary duty in the person or entity with respect to the revenue provided by the municipality to the person or entity under the contract. 
(e)  A person or entity with whom the municipality contracts to conduct authorized activities shall maintain complete and accurate financial records of each expenditure of hotel occupancy tax revenue made by the person or entity and, on request of the city council or other person, shall make the records available for inspection and review. 
(f)  Hotel occupancy tax revenue may be spent for day-to-day operations, supplies, salaries, office rental, travel expenses, and other administrative costs only if those administrative costs are incurred directly in the promotion and servicing of expenditures hereinbefore authorized. The portion of the total administrative costs for activities for which hotel occupancy tax revenue may be used may not exceed the administrative costs actually incurred in conducting the authorized activities. 
(g)  Hotel occupancy tax revenue may not be spent for travel for a person to attend an event or conduct an activity the primary purpose of which is not directly related to the promotion of the person's job in an efficient and professional manner. 
(Ord. No. 910, § 10, 12-19-95) 
Chapter 21 - TRAFFIC[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Prohibited uses of motor vehicles on off-street parking areas, § 11-59; impoundment and sale of abandoned vehicles and vehicles left standing or parked in violation of ordinances, § 11-89 et seq.; streets and sidewalks, Ch. 19; vehicles for hire, Ch. 22. 
State Law reference- Uniform Traffic Act, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 21-01. - State statutes adopted. 
    The City of Portland, Texas hereby adopts the provisions of Article 6701d, Vernon's Annotated Texas Statutes as part of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Portland, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 7, 12-19-78) 
Sec. 21-02. - Powers and duties of chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall exercise the powers and duties with respect to traffic as provided in this chapter. 
    The chief of police shall place and maintain official traffic-control devices when and as required under the traffic ordinances of this city to make effective the provisions of said ordinances, and may place and maintain such additional official traffic-control device(s) as he may deem necessary to regulate, warn or guide traffic under the ordinances of this city and the state vehicle code. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 6, 12-19-78) 
Sec. 21-03. - Enforcement duties of police department. 
    It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the street traffic regulations of this city and all of the state vehicle laws, to make arrests for traffic violations, to investigate accidents and to cooperate with the city manager and other officers of the city in the administration of the traffic laws and to carry out those duties specially imposed by this chapter and the traffic ordinances of this city. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 5, 12-18-79) 
Sec. 21-1. - Load limits-Generally. 
    No commercial motor vehicle, truck tractor, trailer or semi-trailer or combination of such vehicles shall be operated on any street not designated as a truck route, within the corporate city limits, having a weight in excess of one (1) or more of the following limitations: 
(1)  No such vehicle or combination of vehicles shall have a greater weight than twenty thousand (20,000) pounds carried on any one (1) axle; or a tandem axle weight in excess of thirty-four thousand (34,000) pounds. 
(2)  No such vehicle or combination of vehicles shall have an overall gross weight of over fifty-four thousand (54,000) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 117, § 1, 1-19-60; Ord. No. 748, § 1, 11-17-86) 
Sec. 21-2. - Prohibited or limited parking. 
(a)  The chief of police, as director of traffic engineering, is hereby authorized to erect signs or markings indicating no parking or limited parking upon any street, when such parking, would, in his opinion, interfere with traffic or create a hazardous situation. 
(b)  The following markings are designated for parking prohibitions and limitations within the city, and when such markings are placed upon curbs in the city, they shall constitute parking signs as indicated: 
(1)  Solid red. No parking. 
(2)  White with stencil number. Time limit governed by the time indicated by stencil. 
(c)  When official signs or marking prohibiting or limiting parking are erected upon streets, as authorized in this section, no person shall park a vehicle upon such street in violation of any such sign or marking. 
(Ord. No. 150, §§ 1-3, 3-21-62) 
Sec. 21-3. - Official map indicating stop and yield sign locations adopted. 
(a)  An official map of the City of Portland, Texas, indicating the locations of all "stop" and "yield" signs which have heretofore been erected in the City of Portland, which map shall be identified by the inscription thereon of the number of this ordinance [Ord. No. 565] and the date of passage of same [Dec. 19, 1978], is hereby adopted by the City of Portland. 
(b)  All signs indicated on said map are hereby validated and adopted as official traffic signals in the City of Portland, Texas. 
(c)  The respective intersections at which the "stop" or "yield" signs are indicated are hereby designated as "stop" or "yield" intersections. 
(d)  All persons are hereby required to obey said signs under the provisions of this section and of the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways, same being Article 6701d, V.A.T.S., and violation of same shall be punishable as set out in the statutes above mentioned. 
(Ord. No. 451, §§ 1-4, 12-26-72; Ord. No. 565, §§ 1-4, 12-19-78) 
Sec. 21-4. - Driving, riding or operating motor vehicles on public property prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate or cause to be driven or operated any motor-powered vehicle on, over or across any public park, easement, right-of-way or any other public property for any purpose, except that portion of streets, alleys and highways paved, improved or designated for and regularly used by motor-powered vehicles duly licensed for operation and use on public streets and highways by the State of Texas. 
(b)  Any violation of the terms of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof, any person so violating shall be fined in any sum not exceeding two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. No. 576, §§ 1, 2, 7-3-79) 
Sec. 21-5. - Parking or standing of motor vehicles on private property; obstructing fire lanes. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to park or stand a vehicle next to or within twenty (20) feet of any building in any part of the City of Portland zoned commercial, providing such twenty-foot area is marked and identified as a no-parking area or a fire lane or a fire zone. 
(b)  Defense to prosecution. It shall be a defense to prosecution that such building is adjacent to an alley which is dedicated to the public and shown on a map or plat, approved by the City of Portland and legally filed in the public records of San Patricio County, Texas. 
(c)  "Stand" defined. For the purpose of this section, "stand" shall mean the halting of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, otherwise than temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in receiving or discharging passengers. 
(Ord. No. 632, §§ 1-3, 4-6-82) 
Cross reference- Camping in public parks or on public streets, highways, thoroughfares, etc., § 14-4. 
Sec. 21-6. - Truck routes-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate or park any truck, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle in excess of one and one-half (11/2) tons net carrying capacity according to manufacturer's rating on any city street not designated as a truck route, except to arrive or depart from their designation to load or unload. Recreational vehicles are exempt from provision of this section. 
(Ord. No. 748, § 2, 11-17-86; Ord. No. 833, § 1, 4-21-92) 
Sec. 21-7. - Same-Established. 
    The following roads, streets, highways, or portions thereof, by the terms of this section, are hereby designated as truck routes to the exclusion of all other roads, streets, highways or portions thereof: 
(1)  U.S. Highway 181 and access roads within the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  State Highway 2986 (Wildcat Drive) within the corporate limits of the city. 
(3)  State Highway 893 (Moore Avenue) within the corporate limits of the city. 
(4)  State Highway 3239 (Buddy Ganem Drive) within the corporate limits of the city. 
(5)  Any other state or federal highway within the corporate city limits. 
(Ord. No. 748, § 2, 11-17-86) 
Sec. 21-8. - Same-Shortest and most direct route to be taken. 
    Any truck, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle in excess of one and one-half (11/2) tons net carrying capacity operating on any street not designated as a truck route within the corporate city limits shall use the shortest and most direct route, unless otherwise directed by the chief of police or his designees, to arrive and depart their designated destination(s) to load or unload. 
(Ord. No. 748, § 2, 11-17-86; Ord. No. 833, § 2, 4-21-92) 
Sec. 21-9. - Same-Loading or unloading time limits. 
    Any truck, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle in excess of one and one-half (11/2) tons net carrying capacity which is parked within the corporate city limits for the purpose of loading or unloading shall not remain parked for a time exceeding twelve (12) hours, unless otherwise authorized by the chief of police or his designee. Recreational vehicles, when properly parked on private property, are exempt from provision of this section. 
(Ord. No. 748, § 2, 11-17-86; Ord. No. 833, § 3, 4-21-92) 
Sec. 21-10. - Same-Overnight parking prohibited. 
    Overnight parking on any city street within the corporate city limits by any truck, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle in excess of one and one-half (11/2) tons net carrying capacity is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 748, § 2, 11-17-86; Ord. No. 833, § 4, 4-21-92) 
Sec. 21-11. - Assessment and collection of special expense for cases dismissed pursuant to Section 143A(a), Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways. 
    The judge of the municipal court shall assess and collect a special expense of ten dollars ($10.00) for payment of the costs of services provided by the municipal court in each instance in which a case pending before the court is dismissed pursuant to the provisions of Section 143A(a), the Uniform Act Regulating Traffic on Highways (Article 6701d, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes) because of actions by or on behalf of the defendant subsequent to the date of the alleged offense. 
(Ord. No. 763, § 1(21-6), 10-6-87) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 763, adopted Oct. 6, 1987, amended Ch. 21 by adding provisions designated as § 21-6. Inasmuch as Ord. No. 748, § 2, adopted Nov. 17, 1986, already enacted provisions included herein as § 21-6, the editor, at his discretion, has included these new provisions as § 21-11. 
Sec. 21-12. - Establishment of one-way streets. 
(a)  Prohibited. It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this section for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer a vehicle to enter or travel on a street in the opposite direction from that designated in this section as one-way. 
(b)  Appropriate signage. When a street is designated as one-way, appropriate signage shall be erected by the city in conformance with provisions of the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices so indicating. 
(c)  Designated. The traffic flow of the following streets shall be one-way: 
(1)  Northshore Boulevard, north lanes, westbound from Broadway Avenue to U.S. 181 Service Road. 
(2)  Northshore Boulevard, south lanes, eastbound from U.S. 181 Service Road to Broadway Avenue. 
(3)  Country Club Drive, north lanes, westbound from Walden Drive to Broadway Avenue. 
(4)  County Club Drive, south lanes, eastbound from Broadway Avenue to Walden Drive. 
(5)  Augusta Drive, north lanes, westbound from cul-de-sac end to Broadway Avenue. 
(6)  Augusta Drive, south lanes, eastbound from Broadway Avenue to cul-de-sac end. 
(Ord. No. 765, § 2, 10-20-87) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 765, adopted Oct. 20, 1987, amended Ch. 21 by adding provisions designated as § 21-6. Inasmuch as Ord. 748, § 2, adopted Nov. 17, 1986, already enacted provisions codified herein as § 21-6, these new provisions have been included herein as § 21-12 at the editor's discretion.

ARTICLE III. - SPEED REGULATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Speed of vehicles in cities and authority of city council to alter prima facie speed limits established by state law, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6701d, §§ 166, 169. 

Sec. 21-32. - Maximum limits. 
(a)  No person shall drive a vehicle on a highway or street or alley in the City of Portland at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the circumstances then existing. Except when a special hazard exists that requires lower speeds, as provided in paragraph (c), the limits specified in this article shall be lawful but any speed in excess of the limits specified in this article shall be prima facie evidence that the speed is not reasonable or prudent and that it is unlawful. 
(b)  It is hereby determined, on the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, that the maximum reasonable and prudent speed for the operation of vehicles upon the streets of the city is thirty (30) miles per hour and speed in excess thereof shall be prima facie evidence that such speed is not reasonable or prudent and that such speed is unlawful and a violation of this section; provided, however, that this provision shall not apply at specific streets and locations in the city, as hereinafter provided, where the city council, upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, shall have found and declared a different speed to be the maximum reasonable and prudent speed. 
(c)  No person shall drive a vehicle on city highways, streets or alleys at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having regard to the actual and potential hazard then existing. In every event, speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the highway, street or alley in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(d)  It is hereby determined, upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, that the prima facie maximum speed limit on the following streets should be reduced; the City Council of the City of Portland hereby declares and determines that the reasonable and safe prima facie maximum speed limit on the following streets is twenty (20) miles per hour: 
    Starlite, Denver, Austin, Dallas, Crosby and Walker, Southcliff, Northcliff, Easthaven, Dolphin and Portland Drive; Pecos Street; Sabine Street between Alazan and Broadway; Commons Way North, and Commons Way South; 
    and that speed in excess thereof shall be prima facie evidence that such speed is not reasonable or prudent and that such speed is unlawful and a violation of this section. 
(e)  It is hereby determined upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, and the City Council of the City of Portland hereby declares and determines that the following maximum prima facie safe and reasonable speed limits be established: 
(1)  Broadway Boulevard, from its intersection with San Saba Drive to its intersection with U.S. Highway 181, thirty-five (35) miles per hour. 
(2)  Northshore Boulevard, along its entire length, forty (40) miles per hour. 
(3)  Sunset Drive, south of Bayview Boulevard, thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(f)  Penalty. Any violation of the terms of this section shall be deemed a misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof any person so violating same shall be fined a sum not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 336, § 2, 6-3-39; Ord. No. 391, § 2(b), 7-20-71; Ord. No. 630, § 1, 1-5-82; Ord. No. 656, § 1, 1-18-83; Ord. No. 664, § 1, 7-19-83; Ord. No. 695, § 1, 8-21-84; Ord. No. 802, § 1, 7-17-90; Ord. No. 945, §§ 1, 2, 9-2-97; Ord. No. 955, § 1, 11-4-97; Ord. No. 1003, § 1, 2-1-00; Ord. No. 1152, § 1, 9-5-06) 
Sec. 21-33. - Maximum limits in alleys. 
(a)  It is hereby determined, upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, that the prima facie maximum speed limit on alleys should be reduced; the City Council of the City of Portland hereby declares and determines that the reasonable and safe prima facie maximum speed limit is twenty (20) miles per hour on any alley in the City of Portland. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, an "alley" shall be defined as the entire width between the boundary lines of every way publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for purposes of vehicular travel, having no legal or official name and of twenty (20) feet or less in width. 
(Ord. No. 336, §§ 2, 3, 6-2-69; Ord. No. 391, §§ 2(a), 3, 7-20-71; Ord. No. 656, § 2, 1-18-83) 
Sec. 21-33.1. - Speed limits for roads under construction or repair. 
    The Chief of Police of the City of Portland, Texas, upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, shall determine the maximum reasonable and prudent speed limit on any street, road, highway, bridge or causeway within the city upon which construction, reconstruction or repair is in progress or any construction on private property abutting any street, road or highway of the city in connection with which construction work [on] a portion of the street, road, highway is being barricaded or used and shall be as follows: 
(a)  Where the regular lawful maximum speed is above thirty (30) miles per hour, the speed may be reduced in increments of five (5) miles per hour down to thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(b)  Where the regular lawful maximum speed is thirty (30) or less miles per hour, the speed may be reduced down to fifteen (15) miles per hour in increments of five (5) miles per hour. 
(c)  Where the condition in the street, road, highway, bridge, or causeway is determined by the chief of police of the city to require caution in the driving of any motor or other vehicle thereon, the maximum speed is hereby limited to fifteen (15) miles per hour, regardless of the regular lawful maximum speed applicable. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 10, 12-19-78) 
Sec. 21-33.2. - Speed limit signs to be posted; detour considered part of roadway under construction for speed limit purposes. 
(a)  Signs shall be posted by the chief of police of the city so indicating the reasonable and prudent maximum speed limit as hereby fixed, and it shall be and it is hereby made unlawful for any person to drive a motor or other vehicle on or upon the street, road, highway, bridge or causeway so signed at a speed greater than such maximum. 
(b)  Where any detour of any portion of a designated street, road or highway is established, the detour signed as herein provided as to speed limit shall be considered as part of the street, road or highway under construction or repair. 
(Ord. No. 565, § 11, 12-19-78) 
Sec. 21-34. - Maximum speed in school zones on city streets. 
    It is hereby determined, upon the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation, that the prima facie maximum speed limit on that portion of the following street at the times herein specified should be reduced, the city council of the City of Portland hereby declares and determines that the reasonable and safe prima facie maximum speed limit is twenty (20) miles per hour on each and every school day being Monday through Friday, at the times designated, during the weeks that school is in regular session on the following streets or parts of streets: 
(1)  Broadway Boulevard, from two hundred thirty (230) feet north of its intersection with Northshore Boulevard to three hundred fifty (350) feet north of its intersection with Meadowbrook Drive at those times when the school zone lights are flashing; 
(2)  Akins Road, from its intersection with Lang Road to a point two hundred forty-five (245) feet south of its intersection with Atascosa, at those times when the school zone lights are flashing; 
(3)  Lang Road, from a point two hundred twenty-five (225) feet east of Memorial Parkway Boulevard to a point one hundred (100) feet east of Stark Road one thousand eight hundred forty (1,840) feet west of Akins Road at those times when the school zone lights are flashing; 
(4)  Memorial Parkway Boulevard, from its intersection with Oak Ridge Drive to its intersection with Oak Park Drive, at those times when the school zone lights are flashing; 
(5)  Billy G. Webb Drive, from twelve hundred five (1,205) feet southeast of its intersection with Memorial Parkway Boulevard to its intersection with Memorial Parkway Boulevard at those times when the school zone lights are flashing; 
(6)  Buddy Ganem Drive, from two hundred thirty (230) feet northwest of its intersection with Wildcat Drive to thirteen hundred thirty feet (1,330) feet northwest of its intersection with Wildcat Drive at those times when the school zone lights are flashing; and 
(7)  Moore Avenue, from two-hundred (200) feet east of Stark Road/Allen Drive to two thousand eighty-five (2,085) feet west of Stark Road/Allen Drive at those times when the school zone lights are flashing. 
(Ord. No. 354, § 1, 1-6-70; Ord. No. 578, § 3, 8-7-79; Ord. No. 630, § 2, 1-5-82; Ord. No. 656, § 3, 1-18-83; Ord. No. 782, § 1, 3-21-89; Ord. No. 861, § 1, 4-20-93; Ord. No. 873, § 1, 9-21-93; Ord. No. 881, § 1, 2-1-94; Ord. No. 883, § 1, 5-3-94; Ord. No. 908, § I, 10-3-95; Ord. No. 960, §§ 1, 2, 2-3-98; Ord. No. 1013, § 1, 8-1-00; Ord. No. 1109, § 1, 9-7-04; Ord. No. 2116 , § 1, 8-18-15; Ord. No. 2140 , § 1, 9-6-16; Ord. No. 2183, § 2, 1-2-19 ) 
Secs. 21-35-21-37. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former substantive §§ 21-35-21-38 were repealed by Ord. No. 834, § 1, adopted Apr. 21, 1992. Prior to repeal, such sections pertained to speed limits on F.M. Highway Nos. 893, 2986, 3239, and U.S. Highway No. 181, and were derived from Ord. No. 299, § 1, adopted July 2, 1968; Ord. No. 320, § 1, adopted Jan. 21, 1969; Ord.
