Sec. 21-38. - Maximum limit on F.M. Highway No. 3239, also known as Buddy Ganem Drive. 
    On the basis of an engineering and traffic investigation made by the Texas Department of Transportation, the speed prescribed for all motor vehicles in and along portions of Texas F.M. Highway No. 3239 shall be as follows: 
(1)  Beginning at the west city limit of Portland to a point 0.237 mile east of the west city limit, forty-five (45) miles per hour.

Sec. 21-39. - Department of Transportation authorized to reduce speed limits in construction zones.

The maximum legal speed limit on state maintained thoroughfares in construction zones may be reduced in five (5) mile increments to fifteen (15) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 1074, § 11, 4-1-03)

(2)  From a point four hundred eighty-nine one-thousandths (0.489) miles south of the north city limit to a point 42.24 feet north of F.M. Highway No. 3239 (Buddy Ganem Drive), fifty-five (55) miles per hour. 
(3)  From a point forty-two and twenty-four one-hundredths (42.24) feet north of F.M. Highway No. 3239 (Buddy Ganem Drive) to a point one and two hundred sixty-five one-thousandths (1.265) miles south of F.M. (4)  From a point three thousand nine hundred and forty-nine (3,949) feet west of Stark Road/Allen Drive to the western City of Portland City Limits eight thousand seven hundred and sixty (8,760) feet west of Stark Road/Allen Drive, seventy (70) miles per hour.

ARTICLE IV. - VEHICLES USED FOR TRANSPORTATION OF EXPLOSIVES, FLAMMABLES, POISONS, ETC.[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 7. 

Sec. 21-48. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Class A poisons: Extremely dangerous poisonous gases or liquids of such nature that a very small amount of the gas or vapor of the liquid, mixed with air, is dangerous to life. 
    Class B poisons: Less dangerous poisonous liquids or solids (including pastes or semi-liquids) which are chiefly dangerous by external contact with the body or by being taken internally, as in contaminated foods or feeds. The vapors of some of this class of poison are also offensive and dangerous, but to a lesser extent than class A poisons. 
    Class C poisons: Tear gas or irritating substances in liquid or solid form, giving off dangerous or intensely irritating fumes when exposed to air or upon contact with fire. 
    Class D poisons: Radioactive materials or substances which spontaneously emit radiations which are capable of penetrating and severely damaging living tissues and surrounding shipments. 
    Compressed gas: Any material with a gauge pressure exceeding forty (40) pounds per square inch at seventy (70) degrees Fahrenheit; or any flammable materials having a Reid vapor pressure exceeding forty (40) pounds per square inch, absolute, at one hundred (100) degrees Fahrenheit. 
    Corrosive liquids: Liquids which will cause severe damage to living tissue and to freight by chemical action when in contact therewith. These liquids may also cause fire when in contact with organic matter or certain chemicals. 
    Explosive: Any chemical compound, mixture or device, the primary or common purpose of which is to function by explosion. 
    Flammable liquids: Any liquid which gives off flammable vapors. 
    Flammable solids: Solids, other than explosives, which are liable to cause fires through friction, through absorption of moisture, through spontaneous chemical changes, or as a result of retained heat from the manufacturing or processing of the commodity. 
    Oxidizing materials: Substances that yield oxygen readily to stimulate the combustion of organic matter. 
(Ord. No. 199, § 5, 11-19-63) 
Sec. 21-49. - Operation on streets or alleys prohibited; exceptions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or cause to be driven, or operate or maintain, any motor vehicle, truck, trailer or any other vehicle having thereon or attached thereto a tank or tanks or other receptacle used for the carrying of explosives, flammable liquids, flammable solids, oxidizing materials, corrosive liquids, compressed gas, class A poisons, class B poisons, class C poisons, or class D poisons, over any street, highway or alley within the corporate limits of the city, except the following specifically designated streets or highways: 
(1)  U.S. Highway No. 181. 
(2)  State Farm to Market Road No. 893. 
(Ord. No. 199, § 1, 11-19-63) 
Sec. 21-50. - Parking prohibited when loaded or partially loaded. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked or to maintain any truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle having thereon or attached thereto a tank or tanks or other receptacle, filled or partially filled with explosives, flammable liquids, flammable solids, oxidizing materials, corrosive liquids, compressed gas, class A poisons, class B poisons, class C poisons, or class D poisons, on any private property or public place within the city. 
(Ord. No. 199, § 3, 11-19-63; Ord. No. 243, § 1, 11-16-65) 
Sec. 21-51. - Parking on streets or alleys prohibited, whether loaded or empty. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or cause to be parked, on any highway, street or alley within the corporate limits of the city, any truck, trailer, motor vehicle or other form of vehicle having thereon or attached thereto a tank or tanks or other receptacle used for the carrying of explosives, flammable liquids, flammable solids, oxidizing materials, corrosive liquids, compressed gas, class A poisons, class B poisons, class C poisons or class D poisons, whether loaded, partially loaded or empty of such products. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to the stopping of any such vehicle when said stopping is necessitated by the breakdown of same. 
(Ord. No. 199, § 2, 11-19-63; Ord. No. 405, § 1, 3-7-72) 
Sec. 21-52. - Exemptions from article. 
    In addition to exemptions specifically granted elsewhere in this article, the provisions of sections 21-49, 21-50 and 21-51 shall not apply under the following conditions and circumstances: 
(1)  When any such truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle is carrying explosives, flammable liquids, flammable solids, oxidizing materials, corrosive liquids, compressed gas, class A poisons, class B poisons, class C poisons, or class D poisons to commercial consumers, domestic consumers, gasoline service stations or bulk stations located within the corporate limits of the city. 
(2)  When any such truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle is carrying any of the above products to be used exclusively for its own propulsion. 
(3)  When any such truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle, loaded or partly loaded, has stopped on any street or highway designated in section 21-49 at a gasoline service station or garage for necessary repairs, with the further provision that such vehicle shall not remain at such gasoline service station or garage longer than thirty (30) minutes, unless the police department is notified that it is necessary to remain for a longer period than thirty (30) minutes. 
(4)  When any such truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle needs immediate repairs and is not loaded or partially loaded with any of the above named products and is on direct route to a garage or to its owner's private property or place of business of the owner of the truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle or to the owner's place of business exclusively controlled by such owner. 
(5)  When any such truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle has broken down, has a flat tire, or tires, or becomes out of repair or out of gasoline for its own propulsion, to the extent that it cannot be propelled with its own power, then the necessary repairs can be made where such vehicle as above described has been forced to stop, provided that such vehicle can be repaired within a period of two (2) hours; further provided that the driver of such vehicle shall immediately notify the police department of such forced stoppage; and further provided that during such period for repair or repairs a policeman or someone designated by him remains at such place of stoppage to warn other persons using the street or highway of such danger. 
(6)  When any such truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle is loaded or partially loaded and has broken down and is out of repair to the extent that such above described vehicle cannot be repaired within two (2) hours and the police department has been notified and the same is being removed from such place of stoppage or breakdown to a garage or some other place within the corporate limits of the city, under the direction of the police department. 
(7)  When any person is engaged in the business of hauling explosive, flammable liquids, flammable solids, oxidizing materials, corrosive liquids, compressed gas, class A poisons, class B poisons, class C poisons, or class D poisons and has his place of business within the corporate limits of the city, such person shall have a right to convey such truck, trailer, motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle to such place of business without police protection, provided such vehicle (excluding its own tank or receptacle used for its own propulsion) is empty and free of all of the above described products. 
(8)  All emergency vehicles operating under the supervision of the City of Portland. 
(9)  Any truck or motor vehicle or any other form of vehicle used in business requiring compressed gas, the quantity to be limited to four (4) bottles per vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 199, § 1, 11-19-63; Ord. No. 378, § 1, 3-2-71) 
Secs. 21-53-21-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SKATES AND SKATEBOARDS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 898, adopted February 7, 1995, added provisions designated as Ch. 21, §§ 21-39-21-45. For purposes of classification, such provisions have been redesignated as Ch. 21, Art. V, §§ 21-61-21-77 at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 21-61. - Definitions. 
(a)  Skater defined means every person using a human propelled device having two (2) or more wheels and attached to their feet, or used by standing on, for the purpose of carrying that person. 
(b)  Skates defined means every device propelled by human power upon which any person may ride, having two (2) or more wheels and attached to the feet of, or stood on by, the person it is conveying. 
(Ord. No. 898, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-62. - Skaters subject to traffic control signals and signs. 
    Skaters shall be subject to traffic control signals and signs at intersections as provided by Section 33 of Art. 6701d of the Texas Motor Vehicle Laws but at all other places skaters shall be accorded the privileges and shall be subject to the restrictions stated in this article. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 1, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-63. - Driver of vehicle to yield right-of-way. 
    The driver of a vehicle emerging from or entering an alley, building, private road or driveway shall yield the right-of-way to any skater approaching on any sidewalk extending across such alley, building entrance, road or driveway. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 2, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-64. - When traffic-control signals not in place or operational. 
    When traffic-control signals and signs are not in place or not in operation the driver of a vehicle shall yield the right-of-way, slowing down or stopping if need be to so yield, to a skater crossing the roadway within a crosswalk when the skater is upon the half of the roadway upon which the vehicle is traveling, or when the skater is approaching so closely from the opposite half of the roadway as to be in danger, but no skater shall suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and skate into the path of a vehicle which is so close that it is impossible for the driver to yield. This provision shall not apply under the conditions stated in this section. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 3, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-65. - Overtaking vehicle stopped for skater to cross roadway prohibited. 
    Whenever any vehicle is stopped at a marked crosswalk or at any unmarked crosswalk at an intersection to permit a skater to cross the roadway, the driver of any other vehicle approaching from the rear shall not overtake and pass such stopped vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 4, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-66. - Skater to yield right-of-way when crossing at unmarked crosswalk. 
    Every skater crossing a roadway at any point other than within a marked crosswalk or within an unmarked crosswalk at an intersection shall yield right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 5, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-67. - Where pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing had been provided. 
    Any skater crossing a roadway at a point where a pedestrian tunnel or overhead pedestrian crossing had been provided shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 6, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-68. - Adjacent intersections, where traffic-control signals and signs are inoperative. 
    Between adjacent intersections at which traffic-control signals and signs are in operation skaters, shall not cross at any place except in a marked crosswalk. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 7, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-69. - Crossing intersections diagonally. 
    No skater shall cross a roadway intersection diagonally unless authorized by official traffic-control devices; or signs; and, when authorized to cross diagonally, skaters shall cross only in accordance with the official traffic-control devices or signs pertaining to such crossing movements. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 8, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-70. - Due care to be exercised. 
    Notwithstanding other provisions of this article every driver of a vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any skater upon any roadway and shall give warning by sounding the horn when necessary and shall exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any obviously confused or incapacitated person upon a roadway. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 9, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-71. - Skaters to move upon right half of crosswalks. 
    Skaters shall move, whenever possible upon the right half of crosswalks. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 10, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-72. - Adjacent arterial or collector streets. 
    Where sidewalks are provided it shall be unlawful for any skater to skate along and upon any adjacent arterial or collector street as described in the city's adopted Comprehensive Plan. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 11, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-73. - When sidewalks are not provided on arterial or collector streets. 
    Where sidewalks are not provided on an arterial or collector streets, and all other roadways, and skater skating along and upon a roadway shall when possible skate only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic which may approach from the opposite direction. Every skater skating upon a public roadway shall skate as close as practical to the curb or edge of the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 12, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-74. - Power of store owners. 
    This article does not limit the power of store owners and owner of other private property from banning skaters from their property or certain parts of their property. It shall be unlawful for anyone to skate on a sidewalk in a public place when signs are posted prohibiting such skating. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 13, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-75. - Unlawful to erect structure upon or across sidewalks or roadway for recreational use. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to erect or cause to be erected any structure upon or across any sidewalk or public roadway for recreational use, including skateboard or bicycle ramps. It shall further be unlawful for any parent, guardian, or property owner to knowingly allow such structure to be erected. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 14, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-76. - Reflective tape or other visible device required. 
    Every skater when skating at night upon a public roadway shall wear a reflective tape or other device that shall be visible from all directions, a minimum of one hundred fifty (150) feet when directly in front of lawful beams of head lamps on a motor vehicle. Said reflective tape or device shall be white or red in color. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 15, 2-7-95) 
Sec. 21-77. - Penalties. 
    An offense under sections 21-39 through 21-45 is a Class C misdemeanor and punishable by a fine of up to fifty dollars ($50.00) for the first offense, one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the second offense, and five hundred dollars ($500.00) for all subsequent offenses. 
(Ord. No. 898, § 18, 2-7-95) 
Secs. 21-78, 21-79. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - PARKING ON UNIMPROVED SURFACES 

Sec. 21-80. - Parking on unimproved surfaces. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
    "Building line" means a line parallel or approximately parallel to the street line and beyond which, buildings or fences may not be erected. 
    "Corner lot" means a residential property located at the intersection or confluence of two (2) or more streets such that public street rights-of-way are directly adjacent to at least two (2) contiguous sides of the lot. 
    "Driveway" means the primary improved or unimproved parking surface, which provides egress and ingress from a garage, carport or off-street parking area to an adjacent street or alley. 
    "Front yard" means the area from the front face of a residential structure to the front property line or street right-of-way line or, when a structure does not exist, the area from the front building line to the front property line or street right-of-way. 
    "Improved parking surface" means an area used for the parking or storage of vehicles that is overlaid or otherwise paved with concrete, asphalt, paving stones or other hard surfaced durable material approved by the building official. 
    "Rear yard" means the area from the rear face of a residential structure to the rear property line. 
    "Side yard" means the area from the side of a residential structure to the side property line. 
    "Vehicle" means every device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn or moved upon a street, highway, waterway or airway and shall include any automobile, bus, truck, tractor, motor house, farm machinery, motorcycles, scooters, mopeds, all-terrain vehicles, boats, aircraft, recreational vehicles, golf carts, go-carts, trailers, fifth wheel trailers, campers, camper shells, wheeled towing frames, semi-tractor trailers, truck beds mounted on chassis and mobile homes. This definition does not include non-motorized bicycles, small engine lawn mowers and devices of similar scale. 
(b)  Regulations. 
(1)  Parking on unimproved surfaces restricted. A person commits an offense if, upon a residential single-family, duplex or townhouse lot or tract: 
a.  The person causes, permits or allows the parking or storage of any vehicle in the front yard upon any surface other than an improved parking surface. 
b.  The person offense causes, permits or allows the parking or storage of any vehicle upon the side yard or rear yard of a corner lot upon any surface other than an improved parking surface, unless otherwise concealed from view from all public street rights-of-way by: 
1.  A solid, opaque, screening fence or wall at least six (6) feet in height; 
2.  Vegetation consisting of a solid hedgerow of evergreen shrubs, or trees and shrubs, providing full screening from the ground to a minimum height of six (6) feet; 
3.  Any combination of the above that effectively conceals the vehicle from view and accomplishes the required screening height; or 
4.  Any other form of compatible and appropriate screening approved by the building official. 
(2)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution for parking or storing vehicles in an unimproved driveway if an existing residence has no improved parking surface on the day of passage of this ordinance. However, at such time that such existing residence is completely rebuilt, or improvements to the same real property constitute fifty (50) percent or more of the property's total assessed value, compliance with this section shall be required. 
(3)  It is an affirmative defense to prosecution for parking or storing vehicles on an unimproved surface or in an unconcealed or unscreened manner if such vehicles are parked in the rear yard and the rear yard is not a corner lot or directly adjacent to a public street right-of-way. 
(c)  Maintenance. All improved parking surfaces shall be maintained in good and safe condition and be free of holes, cracks or other failures that may affect the use, safety, appearance or drainage of the surface or of an adjoining property. 
(Ord. No. 1029, § 1, 5-15-01; Ord. No. 2016, § 1, 4-20-10) 
Chapter 22 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 22-1-22-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - TAXICABS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 831, §§ 1-31, adopted Apr. 7, 1992, amended Ord. No. 136 in its entirety, being Art. II, §§ 22-16-22-27, 22-36-22-41, as amended by Ord. No. 270, § 2, adopted June 20, 1967; Ord. No. 227, § 1, adopted Mar. 16, 1965; and Ord. No. 276, § 1, adopted June 20, 1967. Provisions of Ord. No. 831 have been codified herein as Art. II, §§ 22-16-22-23, 22-26-22-45, and 22-48-22-50. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-16. - Definitions. 
    [The following words and phrases, as used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed thereto:] 
    Certificate: Means a certificate of public convenience and necessity issued by the city council authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a taxicab business in the city. 
    Driver or chauffeur: Shall be held to include every person in actual charge of the operation of a taxicab, whether he is the owner or is an agent, servant or employee of the owner. 
    For hire: For money or other thing of value, gratuities, tips and free-will offerings, whether paid directly or indirectly, as compensation or consideration for services rendered. 
    Owner: Any person, firm, corporation, association, partnership or society who holds a valid and current certificate of convenience and necessity issued after and/or a current franchise granted prior to, and who has control, direction, maintenance and the benefit of the collection of revenue derived from the operation of one (1) or more taxicabs on or over the streets or public ways of the city, whether as owner or otherwise. 
    Taxicab: Every automobile or motor-propelled vehicle used for the transportation of passengers for hire over the public streets of the city and not over defined or fixed route, irrespective of whether or not the operation extends beyond the city limits, at rates for distance traveled, for waiting time, for both or at rates per hour, per day, per week or per month under circumstances that such vehicle is routed under the direction of the passenger hiring same. The term "taxicab" does not include driverless vehicles nor does it include vehicles operated exclusively under special certificate carrying to or from any municipal airport of the city to any point within the city or through any part of the city, but provisions relating to drivers shall apply to all vehicles operated under special certificate, as well as other vehicles included herein, when a driver is furnished. 
    Taxicab stand: A public place alongside the curb or curbline of a street which has been designated by the city secretary as reserved exclusively for the use of taxicabs in accordance with the provisions of this article and the traffic articles of the city. 
    Taximeter: A machine adapted automatically to calculate at a predetermined rate and to register the charge for hire of a taxicab, and such charges shall be indicated numerically. 
    Waiting time: Such time as may be consumed or lost at the special instance and request of a passenger after such passenger has first entered the taxicab to make trip and before reaching his/her final destination; and no charge shall be made against a passenger for any time lost on account of any other delay whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-17. - Enforcement and administration. 
    Enforcement and administration of the provisions of this article shall be a function of any officer or employee so designated by the city manager. The designated employee shall exercise powers and promulgate rules necessary to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 2, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-18. - Police assistance. 
    Such employees as are designated by the city manager may call upon the police department of the city for cooperation in enforcing the provisions of this article, and it shall be the duty of the chief of police to direct the members of the police department to give such cooperative action as requested, and it shall further be the duty of all police officers of the city to make investigations of violations of this article and to make arrest for violations of this article committed in their presence in the same manner as for violations of the traffic articles of the city. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 3, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-19. - Duties of city secretary and police chief. 
    It shall be the duty of the city secretary to receive all applications for certificates to operate taxicabs and to receive all other applications under this article, and to conduct hearings thereon. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to inspect the operations of taxicabs, inspect the taxicab vehicles within the city, and such other duties as may be required of him in connection with the taxicab operations. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 4, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-20. - Records and reports; action to suspend or revoke privilege; records and reports by others. 
    The chief of police shall establish, maintain and keep a system of records showing whether the holder of any certificate to operate a taxicab in the city has been guilty of a breach of any condition of such certificate or has failed to comply in any material manner with the terms and stipulations thereof, and the chief of police shall take action when, in his/her opinion, the certificate of any such operator should be suspended or revoked or penalties imposed on the holder under all the facts and circumstances reflected by the records. 
    The records to be kept by the chief of police as to performance of certificate holders shall include, but without limitation, records of charges, convictions, reprimands, warnings, and observations by officers and employees of the city concerning the performance of any certificate holder or employee of such holder. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 5, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-21. - Certificate holder's duty to enforce compliance by drivers. 
(a)  A holder of a valid and current certificate of convenience and necessity shall establish policy and take action to discourage, prevent, or correct violations of this chapter by drivers, who are employed by or contracting with the holder. 
(b)  A holder shall not permit a driver who is employed by or contracting with the holder to drive a taxicab if the holder knows or has reasonable cause to know that the driver has failed to comply with the rules and regulations established by this article. 
(c)  Any failure to comply with regulations established under this article shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the certificate of convenience and necessity authorizing the holder to operate a taxicab service within the city. 
Sec. 22-22. - Contract driver. 
(a)  Certificate holders may contract with a driver, but only if the contract: 
(1)  Provides that the certificate holder, taxicab owner, and any taxicab driver shall indemnify the city and hold the city harmless for all claims or causes of action against the city arising from the conduct of the driver, operation of business, condition or operation of vehicles or claims arising under contract; and 
(2)  Provides that any taxicab operated pursuant to such contract be properly licensed, be in good working order and be equipped with a two-way communication system, taximeter, top light or flag indicating occupancy; and 
(3)  Provides that the driver agrees to operate the taxicab and conduct himself/herself in compliance with the Code of Ordinances of the City of Portland including but not limited to this article; and 
(4)  Provides that the certificate holder and driver agrees not to subcontract or allow another person other than such driver to operate his taxicab while a valid contract is in effect with such driver; and 
(5)  Provides that failure to comply with any requirements of the City Code by the driver will constitute a breach of contract with the certificate holder. 
(b)  The form of the contract between a holder and driver must be reviewed and approved by the city secretary or his/her designee before the contract is valid. The city secretary may disapprove a contract form if he/she determines that the contract is inconsistent with regulations established under this article. A holder may not use a contract that has not been approved by the city secretary or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 7, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-23. - Suspension and revocation of certificate. 
    Any certificate of convenience and necessity may be either suspended for any period of time not to exceed six (6) months or revoked by the city secretary. 
(1)  The city secretary shall suspend or revoke a certificate of convenience and necessity if it is determined that the holder has: 
a.  Failed to comply with a correction order issued to the holder by the city secretary or his/her designee, within the time specified in the order; or 
b.  Intentionally or knowingly impeded the city manager or a law enforcement agency in the performance of their duties; or 
c.  Failed to comply with the requirements established in this article in any way; or 
d.  Been convicted for violation of another city, state or federal law, which violation reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to perform a public transportation service; or 
e.  Substantially breached the terms of the certificate; or 
f.  Failed to pay city ad valorem taxes, when due, on all vehicles and other equipment used in connection with the taxicab service; or 
g.  Failed to pay the street use fee at the time it is due. 
(2)  Every suspension or revocation of the certificate of convenience and necessity shall be in writing, dated and shall state the reason for such suspension or revocation. 
Such notice shall immediately be sent to the holder of such certificate. Such order of suspension or revocation shall be effective as of the date of such notice; provided, however, that the holder whose certificate has been suspended or revoked may within five (5) days after the date of such notice appeal to the city manager or his/her designee for reinstatement by a request in writing for such relief. The city manager or his/her designee shall set a date not later than fifteen (15) days following receipt of the notice of appeal for hearing and after such hearing sustain or reverse the suspension or revocation. If no appeal is taken within the time and by the method hereby provided then the order of suspension or revocation by the city secretary shall be final. 
(3)  A suspension of a certificate shall not affect the expiration date of the certificate. 
(4)  Upon revocation of a certificate, said holder shall be ineligible for a new certificate for a period of two (2) years. 
(5)  Reinstatement. After suspension of a permit, a holder may file with the city secretary a written request for reinstatement. The city manager or his/her designee shall inspect the operation of the suspended holder to determine if the deficiency causing the suspension has been corrected by the holder. After inspection, the city manager shall submit his/her recommendation together with supporting facts to the city council. The city council may as it determines appropriate, reinstate the certificate or deny reinstatement. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 8, 4-7-72) 
Secs. 22-24, 22-25. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE, LICENSE, FEES, BUSINESS REGULATIONS 

Sec. 22-26. - Certificate, license and permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to provide taxicab services (to drive or operate or to cause to be driven or operated any taxicab upon or over any street or thoroughfare) originating or terminating within the city limits of Portland, unless the owner or operator thereof has first secured a certificate from the city to operate a taxicab and the required license and permit to operate such vehicle under this article has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 9, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-27. - Certificate application requisites, filing. 
    Every person proposing to operate a taxicab service in the city shall make application in writing on forms provided by the city requesting a certificate pursuant to the terms of this article for such proposed taxicab service. 
    Such application for certificate to operate a taxicab service shall be verified under oath and shall be filed in triplicate and accompanied by a nonrefundable filing fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) to cover administration cost and the costs of publication of notices as required in this article. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 10, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-28. - Same-Information to be given. 
    Every application for a certificate under this article shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  Financial status of the applicant, including the amounts of all unpaid judgments against the applicant and the nature of the transaction or acts giving rise to such judgments. 
(3)  Experience of the applicant in the transportation of passengers. 
(4)  Any facts which the applicant believes tend to prove that public convenience and necessity require the granting of the proposed certificate. 
(5)  The minimum and maximum number of vehicles proposed to be operated by the applicant. 
(6)  Location of proposed base of operations and call box stands. 
(7)  The color scheme and insignia to be used to designate the vehicles of the applicant. 
(8)  The probable age and condition of the vehicles to be used by applicant. 
(9)  The public telephone number to be used by the public to request service. 
(10)  A description of the communications system to communicate requests from prospective passengers to the taxicab driver. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 11, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-29. - Same-Consideration of application or reapplication. 
    When application for a certificate has been made, the city manager or his/her designee shall determine if the public convenience and necessity will justify the granting of additional taxicab service, taking the following into consideration: 
(1)  Financial responsibility of the applicant, i.e., solvency, indebtedness. 
(2)  The number of taxicabs already in operation in the city. 
(3)  The character, work experience and responsibility of the applicant. 
(4)  The ability of the applicant to comply with the regulatory articles of the city, including the equipment and service proposed to be furnished. 
(5)  Published reports and data, generally accepted to be reliable because of reference to the taxicab industry and transportation services in other cities of the United States, may be utilized. 
(6)  Such other relevant facts as the city council or city manager may deem reasonably advisable, pertinent or necessary to aid in determining whether public convenience and necessity require the additional taxicab service. The matter of determining public convenience and necessity may be referred to the chief of police for his/her advisory finding on such matter, and the chief of police is authorized to hold such hearings as will give all interested parties an opportunity to present evidence on the question. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 12, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-30. - Same-Burden of proof at hearing. 
    In all hearings pursuant to section 22-29, the burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish by clear, cogent and convincing evidence that the public convenience and necessity require such operation of the taxicab service for which the application has been made and that the applicant is fit, able and willing to perform such transportation of persons and property by taxicab as proposed in the application. Proof that the applicant seeks renewal of an existing certificate for operating taxicabs shall constitute prima facie proof of public convenience and necessity. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 13, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-31. - Same-Public notice of application; hearings. 
    Upon any application for a taxicab certificate under the provisions of this article, the chief of police shall cause a notice to be published in the official newspaper of the city. The notice shall state that an application has been filed for a taxicab certificate, setting forth the name of the applicant, kind of equipment and the ownership of same and all other pertinent data set forth in such application which the city may deem necessary. 
    Publication of such notice shall constitute a notice to all holders of the existing certificates that a public hearing will be held by the chief of police at a public place in the city to be designated by the chief of police in the notice and at a designated time given in the notice. Such designated time shall not be less than seven (7) days nor more than fifteen (15) days after the date of the first publication of the notice, and the notice shall be published for two (2) consecutive weeks. All holders of taxicab certificates or any other citizen shall thereupon be entitled to file any comments, complaints or protests. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 14, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-32. - Same-Issuance. 
    If it is determined from the investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity justify the granting of a certificate, a recommendation shall be made to the city council that a certificate to operate taxicab service in the city be granted for a term not to exceed five (5) years from the date of issuance specifying the maximum number of taxicab vehicles which may be operated by the certificate holder during the five-year term. The applicant shall be notified of such recommendations. 
Sec. 22-33. - Taxicab street use fee. 
(a)  Each owner holding a certificate to operate a taxicab upon the streets within the city shall pay the city each six-month period as a taxicab street use fee an amount equal to eighty-seven dollars and fifty cents ($87.50) times the maximum number of vehicles authorized by a current and valid certificate of convenience and necessity. All applicants filing an application for a certificate after January 1, 1992, shall be limited to five (5) vehicles or less. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the provisions of section 22-32, a certificate holder may, upon written request to the city secretary or his/her designee, apply to increase or decrease the maximum number of vehicles authorized to be operated during the remaining term of the current certificate of convenience and necessity. 
(c)  The number of vehicles in service by a certificate holder shall not exceed the maximum number of vehicles authorized to be operated under such certificate. 
(d)  The annual street use fee shall be paid in two (2) payments. The first half of the annual street use fee for any calendar year shall be paid on or after January 1, and before January 10. The second half of the annual street use fee shall be paid on or after July 1 and before July 10. This fee shall be prorated for periods of less than six (6) months. 
(e)  If the holder of the certificate shall fail to comply with any requirement herein or shall willfully file any false statements, the same shall be cause for suspension or revocation of the certificate of convenience and necessity authorizing the holder to operate a taxicab service within the city. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 16, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-34. - Payment of taxes, fees, etc. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner of any taxicab operated within the city to render for and pay all ad valorem taxes to the city for all vehicles and other equipment used in such business, and a failure to render for and to pay such ad valorem taxes to the city or failure to pay any other fees, licenses or charges to the city before they become delinquent shall, if not paid after written notice of default, operate as a revocation of any certificate, license or permit authorizing the operation of taxicabs over the public streets, alleys and ways of the city. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 17, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-35. - Report as to drivers in charge of particular taxicabs. 
    The owner of any taxicab used in the business of carrying passengers for hire upon the streets of the city and which is licensed to carry on such business shall, upon request of the chief of police, report the drivers who are in charge of the particular cars at a specified time. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 18, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-36. - Certificate, license and permit required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to provide taxicab services (to drive or operate or to cause to be driven or operated any taxicab upon or over any street or thoroughfare) originating or terminating within the city limits of Portland, unless the owner or operator thereof has first secured a certificate from the city to operate a taxicab and the required license and permit to operate such vehicle under this article has been issued. The driver of the taxicab must have in his/her possession said taxicab driver's license issued by the chief of police, as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 19, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-37. - Taxicab driver's license; application. 
(a)  Filing. Every person desiring to drive a taxicab on the streets of the city whether as an owner or an employee of the owner of such taxicab, shall file with the chief of police a written application for a license to be known as a "taxicab driver's license." 
(b)  Contents. Each applicant shall file with his/her application two (2) copies of a photograph one (1) inch by two (2) inches in size of himself/herself taken within three (3) months of the date of the application. One (1) of said photographs shall be firmly affixed by the chief of police to the application and the other photograph shall be firmly affixed to the license, if granted. Each application shall contain the following: 
(1)  Full name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  Age, height, weight, color of eyes, color of hair. 
(3)  Place of birth. 
(4)  Marital status. 
(5)  Nationality. 
(6)  Length of time applicant has resided in the city. 
(7)  Places of residence for the preceding three (3) years. 
(8)  Previous employment and employer. 
(9)  Applicant's prior criminal record (if any) including all convictions of any crime and disorderly persons offenses. 
(10)  Length of time applicant has been a licensed automobile driver of the state. 
(11)  Driver's license number. 
(12)  Whether a driver's license issued to him by Texas or any other state or any municipality has been suspended or revoked, and for what crime. 
(13)  Such other reasonable information the chief of police may require. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 20, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-38. - Qualifications for license. 
    No taxicab driver's license shall be issued unless the applicant shall be: 
(1)  At least eighteen (18) years of age; 
(2)  A resident of the state for six (6) months or more; 
(3)  The holder of a current and valid automobile driver's license issued by the State of Texas; 
(4)  Able to read and write the English language; 
(5)  A citizen of the United States; 
(6)  Clean and neat in dress and person, and not addicted to the use of intoxicating liquor or drugs; 
(7)  Of sound physique, have good eyesight and hearing, and not subject to epilepsy, vertigo, heart trouble or any other infirmity of mind or body which might render him unfit to drive and operate a taxicab safely on the streets of the city; 
(8)  A person of good moral character. He shall submit with his/her application, on blank forms to be provided by the chief of police, certificates of good character from two (2) reputable citizens of the city who have known him personally for at least six (6) months prior to his/her application. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 21, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-39. - Investigation of applicant. 
    Before any taxicab driver's license is issued, the chief of police shall investigate or cause to be investigated the driving record and moral character of the applicant. The applicant shall submit himself/herself to be fingerprinted by the police department. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 22, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-40. - Determination; issuance of license; fee; term of license. 
    If the chief of police determines that the applicant for a taxicab driver's license has a sufficiently good moral character and has met all other qualifications, he/she shall, upon the payment of a taxicab driver's license fee of ten dollars ($10.00), issue a taxicab driver's license to the applicant. 
    All taxicab driver's license shall be issued for a period of one (1) year from date of issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked by the chief of police. 
Sec. 22-41. - Renewal. 
    A taxicab driver's license may be renewed from year to year by the chief of police upon the written application of any licensee and an appropriate endorsement made upon the application for renewal. Each renewal shall be investigated by the police department. Such application for renewal shall show thereon the date upon which the original license was granted. The fee for such renewal shall be the same as that for an original license. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 24, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-42. - Contents; display. 
    Every taxicab driver's license shall contain the name, signature and photograph of the licensee, and such other information as the chief of police may require. Such license shall be signed by the chief of police. 
    Whenever the licensed taxicab driver is operating a licensed taxicab, the taxicab driver's license shall be placed in a conspicuous part of the interior of the licensed taxicab which the licensee is authorized to operate and shall be placed in full view of all passengers while such driver is operating a taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 25, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-43. - Records in connection with calls. 
    Every holder of a certificate and owner or operator of a taxicab shall keep accurate records relating to calls received and services performed, the time of such calls or services, the name of the driver performing the service or making the service call, the place of such call and the time of return from such call; and access to such records shall be given to the chief of police; and every refusal to give such records or furnish information kept regarding such matters shall be and is hereby made a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 26, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-44. - Vehicles equipment and maintenance. 
(a)  Vehicles must be licensed. Prior to the use and operation of any vehicle under the provisions of this article said vehicle shall be thoroughly examined and inspected by the police department and found to comply with such reasonable rules and regulations as may be prescribed by the city council. These rules and regulations shall be promulgated to provide safe transportation and shall specify such safety equipment and regulatory devices as the city council shall deem necessary. 
(b)  Every vehicle operating under this article shall be inspected every twelve (12) months by a state authorized inspection facility. On the sixth month after the state inspection each licensed taxi shall undergo a city safety inspection conducted by the chief of police. Every vehicle operating under this article shall be periodically inspected by the police department to ensure continued maintenance of safe operating conditions. A report is to be made and kept by chief of police. 
(c)  Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 27, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-45. - Responsibility of each person in engaging a taxicab. 
    By taking any action in connection with this article on taxicabs (including, but not limited to, inspections, investigations, administration, enforcement, recordkeeping, and the granting, suspension and revocation of certificates, licenses, and permits), the city and its agents and employees do not in any way represent or undertake to represent the fitness of any taxicab, driver, or aspect of the taxicab business, and it shall be the sole responsibility of each person to decide whether to engage or use a taxicab without relying on any action of the city. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 28, 4-7-72) 
Secs. 22-46, 22-47. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY 

Sec. 22-48. - Liability insurance-Generally. 
    Before any license or permit shall be issued to any owner or operator of a taxicab or before any renewal of a license or permit shall be granted, the owner or operator shall be required to file a certificate of insurance with the chief of police and thereafter with a company duly authorized to do business in the state and performable in the county insuring the public against any loss or damage that may result to any person or property from the operation of such vehicle; provided, that the maximum amount of recovery in such policy of insurance specified shall not, for each vehicle, be less than two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for injury or death of one (1) person and five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injuries or death in any one (1) occurrence; and not less than fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injury to or destruction of property in any one (1) occurrence. Each insurance policy shall require notice from the insurer to the city at least ten (10) days before any such policy is to be terminated for any reason by the insurer or by the insured. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 29, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-49. - Same-Compliance with Safety-Responsibility Act. 
    The owner or operator of a taxicab may comply with the insurance provisions required in this article by obtaining approval from the Texas Department of Public Safety as a self-insured under the Texas Motor Vehicle Safety-Responsibility Act, Vernon's Annotated Texas Civil Statutes, Article 6701h, and keep in full force and effect excess public liability insurance providing coverage not less than the limits specified in section 22-38. A certificate from the Texas Department of Public Safety and an insurance certificate indicating coverage under the excess liability policies must be furnished the chief of police and maintained in accordance with the provisions of section 22-38. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 30, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-50. - Nonliability of city for pecuniary responsibility. 
    Neither the city nor any officer thereof shall be held liable for the pecuniary responsibility or solvency of any certificate holder or insurer or in any manner become liable on account of any act or omission relating to the operation of a taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 31, 4-7-72) 
Sec. 22-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EMERGENCY MEDICAL SERVICE VEHICLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1170, §§ 1-3, adopted May 15, 2007, has been treated as superseding the provisions of Art. III, §§ 22-52-22-56. Formerly, said article pertained to ambulances as enacted by Ord. No. 485, adopted Aug. 20, 1974; as amended. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 

Sec. 22-52. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to establish a regulated ambulance service system which can provide quality care, with reasonable, reliable response time standards and with the goal of furnishing the best possible chance of survival, without disability or preventable complication to citizens in need of ambulance transport for both emergency and non-emergency transfers. This article establishes a sole-provider ambulance system because it is unreasonable to unnecessarily create high rates to make needed improvements to ambulance service within the City of Portland, when a more efficiently designed system can achieve the same results at lower cost. The most efficient design to achieve the goals of high-quality emergency and transfer ambulance service, at the lowest cost to the citizens, is through the implementation of a sole-provider ambulance system. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 1, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 22-53. - Definitions. 
    The following words and phrases as used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Advanced life support ambulance means any vehicle that meets or exceeds any requirements established in Chapter 773 of the Texas Health and Safety Code, and that is equipped to provide treatment of life-threatening emergencies through the use of advanced airway management, intravenous therapy, and other advanced pre-hospital care procedures and which is equipped to transport sick or injured persons to or from health care facilities. 
    Ambulance means any privately or publicly owned motor vehicle that is specially designed or constructed and equipped and is intended to be used for and is maintained or operated for the emergency or other transportation of patients. 
    Ambulance patient or patient means any person being transported in a wheelchair or in a reclining position within the City of Portland to or from health care facilities except when the transportation originates outside the City of Portland. 
    Ambulance service contractor means that entity which is currently under contract with the City of Portland to provide all ambulance and ambulance patient service within the City of Portland. 
    Emergency medical services means the transportation of a patient in an ambulance within the City of Portland whether of an emergency nature, non-emergency transfer or otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 2, 5-15-07) 
Sec. 22-53. - Authority to operate. 
(a)  No person, firm, corporation, partnership or other entity shall operate or cause to be operated an ambulance, nor shall such furnish, conduct, maintain, advertise or otherwise be engaged in the business or service of the transportation of ambulance patients, emergency or otherwise, within the City of Portland unless such person is the ambulance service contractor. No person shall knowingly solicit ambulance services as regulated herein except the ambulance service contractor. 
(b)  However, the prohibitions set forth in subsection (a) above, shall not be applicable to an ambulance or ambulance service provider(s): 
(1)  Which is rendering assistance to patients in the case of a major catastrophe emergency with which the ambulance service contractor's ambulances are insufficient or unable to cope; or 
(2)  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location beyond the City of Portland and transported to a location within the city; or 
(3)  Transporting a patient who is picked up from a location beyond the City of Portland and transported to a location beyond the limits of the City of Portland and incidentally passing through the City of Portland. 
(Ord. No. 1170, § 3, 5-15-07) 
Chapter 23 - WATER, SEWERS AND SOLID WASTE[1]

ARTICLE II. - SERVICES AND CHARGES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 23-21. - Applicability. 
    In all cases, except as otherwise noted, the conditions set out in this article shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4, 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4, 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV, 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-22. - Separate service for each separate entity; exceptions. 
    Any water or sewer service provided to any residence, any business or commercial entity, any industry, and/or any other type of separate entity, (even to one (1) on the same tract of land as an existing facility or entity) shall only be through a separate metered service for each entity, facility, store, residence, business, or establishment. Existing services cannot be extended to service any other facility or entity. With prior approval by, and solely at the discretion of, the city manager and finance director, an apartment complex, office complex, strip center, mall, hospital, hotel, motel, school, church, mobile home park, or recreational vehicle park, may be exempted from this requirement. Connections existing at the time of adoption of Ordinance No. 896 will be allowed to remain, but may not be changed, expanded, or upgraded without coming into compliance with Ordinance No. 896. The rates for prior existing connections and for those permitted above shall be the appropriate monthly fees stated in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(A), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(A), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(A), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(A), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-23. - City maintenance limit for water and sewer lines. 
    City maintenance of the water service ends at the customer side of the connection to the water meter itself. City maintenance of the sewer service ends at the outside surface of the pipe on the sewer main, where the tap is made. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(B), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(B), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(B), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(B), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-24. - Illegal taps or connections. 
    Criminal charges will be filed by the city on all illegal taps or illegal connections. Before any further service will be provided to the party or parties so convicted, all fines assessed by the court of jurisdiction must be paid in full. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(C), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(C), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(C), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(C), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-25. - Plumbers to contact city prior to unblocking line on city side of service. 
    The city shall not pay for, or reimburse, any plumber or any utility customer, for charges for services incurred in unblocking service or main lines, or any other related work, unless the plumber first contacts the city to allow a city representative to examine the conditions first-hand and assist the plumber in determining whose responsibility it is to rectify the situation. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(K), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(K), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(K), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-26. - Courtesy hookup. 
    The city may allow a "courtesy hookup" for a base minimum water charge for three thousand (3,000) gallons for a period of ten (10) calendar days. The purpose of this hookup is to accommodate facilities being prepared for sale (or some similar set of circumstances) If the customer uses more than three thousand (3,000) gallons during the ten-day period, a normal bill including garbage, wastewater and all appropriate taxes and fees will be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(D), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(D), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(D), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(D), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 1086, § 1, 9-2-03) 
Sec. 23-27. - Returned check, service charge for. 
    There will be a twenty dollar ($20.00) service charge for returned checks. If a check is returned, the account (including penalties) must be settled by means of cash, cashier's check, or money order. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(E), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(E), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(E), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(E), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-28. - Location of new taps. 
    New taps shall only be located on the city's dedicated street or alley rights-of-way. Exceptions to this requirement shall be allowed only with the city council's formal approval, and then only when good cause has been shown for the request. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(F), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(F), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(F), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(F), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-29. - Irrigation wells and septic tanks. 
    If water or sewer mains with adequate capacity require less than two hundred (200) feet of pipe extension to any portion of a piece of property within the city limits, then no alternate sources, such as wells (except for irrigation purposes) or septic tanks may be constructed, and the property must be connected to the city's services as required in sections 23-73 and 23-74. Wells or septic tanks existing at the time of adoption of Ordinance No. 896 shall be exempted from the requirements of this paragraph, but only if they perform adequately and meet all permit and health requirements. If they fail, this paragraph shall apply. Wells may be used exclusively for irrigation purposes, but they must be permitted through the city inspection department and must have all necessary state permits. Absolutely no "cross-connections" between the private supply and city's water system shall be allowed under any circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(G), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(G), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(G), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(G), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-30. - Third party use of solid waste container illegal. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any person to give permission to place solid waste material, which was generated at a site other than the site served by that person's municipal solid waste container, to any third person. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(I), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(I), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(I), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(I), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-31. - Placement in or around solid waste container of prohibited materials. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any person to place any solid waste material in or around a municipal solid waste container that cannot be completely contained within the closed container or is so dense that the container cannot be lifted by normal mechanical means. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(J), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(J), 8-17-93; Ord No. 892, Art. 4(J), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(J), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-32. - Use of solid waste container only for waste generated at the pickup site. 
    It shall be a violation of this section for any person to place solid waste material in a municipal solid waste container, if that waste was not generated at the pickup site within the city limits, unless this service has been specifically contracted for, with the city, in writing. It shall not be a defense to prosecution under this section that the waste is generated outside the city limits, but by a person paying for the solid waste service inside the city limits. For purposes of this section, the term "municipal solid waste container" shall mean any solid waste container owned by the city (or its franchisee) used for the purpose of collection of solid waste for later disposal, or placement at the curbside within the city with the purpose of having the waste removed by the city's solid waste operations. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 4(H), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 4(H), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 4(H), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. IV(H), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-33. - Drainage utility fund established. 
(a)  Fund established. A drainage utility fund is hereby created, the purpose being to finance drainage system permits, studies, plans, maintenance and improvements. 
(b)  Fee established. A three dollar ($3.00) per month drainage utility fee is hereby created, which shall be charged to every residential dwelling, to every individual unit within multi-family dwellings, to individual nonresidential establishments, and to each unit within nonresidential establishments, which receives utility service from the City of Portland. 
(c)  When a customer or business occupying a single residence, campus or business site has a main meter and an irrigation or auxiliary services meter, the drainage utility fee shall apply only to the main meter. 
(Ord. No. 1111, §§ 1, 2, 9-21-04; Ord. No. 2026, § 1, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 2046, § 3, 1-3-12; Ord. No. 2077, § 3, 9-17-13) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1111, §§ 1, 2, adopted Sept. 21, 2004, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 23-33 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 23-34-23-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MONTHLY CHARGES AND BILLINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1124, § 1, effective Dec. 31, 2004, amended Art. II, Div. 2, §§ 23-41-23-50 in its entirety. Formerly, said division pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Ord. No. 849, §§ 1-8, adopted Nov. 11, 1992; as amended. 

Sec. 23-41. - Minimum charges. 
(a)  Residential and commercial customers shall be charged the minimum monthly rates per metered water connection as established in Table 1 and Table 2. Application for water service shall automatically require application for solid waste service as well, and wastewater service where applicable. 
(1)  The minimum monthly charge for water will be based on the class of customer and the size of the meter providing connection for the customer to the city's system. There will not be any amount of usage included in the minimum monthly bill. 
(2)  In addition to the minimum monthly sewer charge shown in Table 1, there shall be usage charges for water and sewer and both shall be based on the amount of water used. However, there shall be no water or sewer charge where the water or sewer service is not specifically required or provided. 
(3)  The solid waste removal charges shown in Table 2 for residential customers apply to each living unit or entity. Charges for commercial customers are also a per unit (or entity) minimum charge. The city manager, with concurrence of the public works director, shall have the authority to require any business or industry to have one (1) or more dumpster type containers of the size the city deems necessary, based on the type of business or industry served. These requirements may be adjusted up or down after an actual history has been developed. The city shall establish consistent requirements for like uses. 
(4)  The minimum fees in Tables 1 and 2 shall be charged whether the customer actually uses the services or not.

This adjusted rate shall include any previous increases or decreases and shall be included in the first billing statement after the new rate becomes effective. Any such increase in the rates must then be approved by majority vote of the city council within sixty (60) days or that increase or decrease shall be removed from the rates. 
(b)  New "master meter" systems (where many entities or units are served through one (1) meter) shall only be allowed with prior written approval of the city manager and finance director. All "master meter" systems for apartments, multi-family units and commercial entities shall be charged a monthly minimum rate of thirty dollars and seventy cents ($30.70) for water (plus usage as outlined in Table 3). Apartment complexes (five (5) units and up) and commercial accounts on master meters will be charged a per-unit charge of twenty-five dollars and seventy-four cents ($25.74) for wastewater (plus usage as outlined in section 23-42). Multi-family units of two (2) to four (4) units will be charged thirty-seven dollars and eighty cents ($37.80) per unit for wastewater (plus usage as outlined in section 23-42). The per-unit charges will not vary based on occupancy of the unit. Minimum solid waste service for master metered units shall be established by the city, based on a projected volume of waste.

No. 2081, § 1, 1-7-14; Ord. No. 2081, §§ 1, 2, 1-7-14; Ord. No. 2083, § 2, 2-18-14; Ord. No. 2093 , § 1, 9-16-14; Ord. No. 2101 , §§ 1, 2, 1-6-15; Ord. No. 2122 , § 1, 10-20-15; Ord. Sec. 23-42. - Monthly usage charges. 
(a)  Water . Water usage (per metered connection) for each one thousand (1,000) gallons or part thereof shall be billed as stated in Table 3. 
Table 3. Water Usage Charges per Thousand Gallons 
Potable Water Raw Water 0 to 13,000 $3.74 $3.98 13,001 to 25,000  3.80  3.98 25,001 to 40,000  4.03  3.98 40,001 and up  4.33  3.98  
(b)  Wastewater. All residential customers shall be charged a wastewater discharge usage fee of one dollar and thirty-three cents ($1.33) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of average monthly consumption. The average monthly consumption is defined as either the system-wide single-family residential average or the specific single-family residential location average for the previous months of December, January and February. Commercial customers shall be charged a wastewater discharge usage fee of one dollar and thirty-three cents ($1.33) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of actual usage each month. 
    Customers who pay all of the necessary fees for an additional and separate water service (with a separate meter) for lawn irrigation or livestock watering use, will not be required to pay any sewer service on water used through that meter, but that additional service shall absolutely not be used for any purpose other than irrigation or livestock watering. This option shall only be available to customers who already have metered water and wastewater service to the residence to be served by the irrigation meter, or to a vacant lot, but only with approval by the city manager. 
(c)  Solid waste collection. There shall be no additional charge (above and beyond the minimum fees required) for residential solid waste collection with two (2) regular pickups per week (except those weeks containing city approved holidays), one (1) brush and one (1) recycling pickup every two (2) weeks, at a minimum. Where such services are provided by the city to commercial accounts, billing shall be at the appropriate rate based on the capacity and frequency of service provided. 
    Where solid waste service is provided by commercial private haulers, the haulers shall also be required to provide recycling service to the facilities being served. A proposed service program must be submitted to the city manager for approval within sixty (60) days of adoption of this section, and the actual service to be provided must begin within one (1) week after such approval (with any revisions and additional stipulations which are deemed necessary) is granted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04; Ord. No. 1147, § 3, 8-1-06; Ord. No. 1185, § 3, 12-18-07; Ord. No. 1199, § 3, 10-21-08; Ord. No. 2033, § 3, 1-18-11; Ord. No. 2045, § 3, 1-3-12; Ord. No. 2063, § 3, 1-2-13; Ord. No. 2081, § 3, 1-7-14; Ord. No. 2101 , § 3, 1-6-15; Ord. No. 2129 , § 3, 2-16-16; Ord. No. 2148 , § 3, 2-7-17; Ord. No. 2158 , § 3, 1-2-18; Ord. No. 2166 , § 2, 4-3-18; Ord. No. 2184, § 3, 1-2-19 ) 
Sec. 23-43. - Services outside the city limits. 
    When city utility services beyond the city limits are allowed by the city council, users shall pay one hundred twenty-five (125) percent of the rate of applicable water, wastewater and solid waste fees. A city plumbing permit shall be required, and all work shall meet city codes for plumbing, whenever the city is supplying water to any part of a facility or location. 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04) 
Sec. 23-44. - Meter tests. 
    A water meter test shall be performed if requested by the customer. The water meter will be tested by the city. If the meter is found to be "fast" (registering over one hundred one (101) percent), there shall be no charge for the test and the meter shall be replaced. If the meter is found to be "normal" (between ninety-six (96) percent and one hundred one (101) percent), the customer shall be billed ten dollars ($10.00) for the testing service. If the meter is found to be "slow" (below ninety-six (96) percent), the customer shall be billed ten dollars ($10.00) and the meter shall be replaced. The city manager shall be authorized to waive this fee in cases of extenuating circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04) 
Sec. 23-45. - Billing date. 
    Bills shall be mailed on or about the last day of each month. The billing date shall be the date of mailing. The failure of the user to receive any such bill shall in no way relieve the user of the duty to pay for the service rendered. 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04) 
Sec. 23-46. - Due date. 
    All bills for water, and/or sewer, and/or solid waste services are due on or before the 15th day of each month. 
    Except as allowed by state law for certain types of individuals, if payment is not made by the due date, the bill shall be considered delinquent, and the city shall promptly notify the nonpaying user. Delinquent bills shall be charged a penalty of twenty (20) percent of the amount of the delinquent bill. 
    If payment is not made within thirty (30) days of the billing date, services shall be disconnected and discontinued. 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04) 
Sec. 23-47. - Disconnected services. 
    No disconnected services shall be reinstated until all charges shown on the past due bill, a twenty dollar ($20.00) disconnect processing fee (charged even if the disconnect has not physically taken place), a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) reconnect fee (if a reconnect is to take place during normal business hours) or a forty-five dollar ($45.00) reconnect fee (if a reconnect is to take place outside of normal business hours), and all other applicable penalties, are paid in full. When a user can prove (to the satisfaction of both the city manager and water billing supervisor) that the original billing and subsequent notices were not received, these penalties may be waived. In addition to the foregoing, any user so disconnected who has had their deposit applied to the delinquent bill, shall be required to place a new deposit with the city as stipulated in sections 23-56 through 23-59 to secure the user's future charges. 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04; Ord. No. 2072, § 1, 6-18-13) 
Sec. 23-48. - Turn off and turn on service. 
    Except for disconnection and reinstatement fees for nonpayment of bills (as addressed in section 23-47 above), the charge for turning off and turning on the water at the meter will be twelve dollars and fifty cents ($12.50) during normal city working hours and eighteen dollars ($18.00) before or after working hours or on weekends. The total fee for transferring an account will be ten dollars ($10.00) and the fee for beginning service will be ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04) 
Sec. 23-49. - Adjustments. 
    The city manager, with the water billing supervisor's concurrence, is hereby authorized to adjust a customer's water bill if the customer provides reasonable proof that the excessive consumption was due to extremely unique or unusual causes that were not the fault or responsibility of the customer. The city shall make such adjustments in a fair manner, consistent with any previous adjustments. 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04) 
Sec. 23-50. - Confidentiality. 
    If properly requested on the form provided by the city, the city will make a good faith effort (but in no way makes any implied or stated guarantee) to not release information contained in the utility files to anyone except law enforcement agencies, other utility services, consumer reporting agencies (such as a collection or credit service), contractors or subcontractors approved by and providing services to any utility service or any governmental agency, and to anyone the customer has waived, in writing, the confidentiality requirement. The fee for implementing this service will be five dollars ($5.00). 
(Ord. No. 1124, § 1, 12-30-04) 
Sec. 23-51. - Fire service fee established. 
(a)  A mandatory two dollars ($2.00) a month fire service fee is hereby created, which shall be charged to every residential dwelling, to every individual unit within multi-family dwellings, to individual nonresidential establishments, and to each unit within nonresidential establishments, which receives utility service from the City of Portland. 
(b)  When a customer or business occupying a single residence, campus or business site has a main meter and an irrigation or auxiliary services meter, the fire service fee shall apply only to the main meter. 
(Ord. No. 1128, § 1, 9-6-05; Ord. No. 2046, § 4, 1-3-12; Ord. No. 2077, § 4, 9-17-13; Ord. No. 2184, § 4, 1-2-19 ) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1128, § 1, adopted Sept. 6, 2005, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 23-51 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 23-52-23-55. - Reserved.

    Deposits will be accepted only in the form of cash, money order, personal, cashier's, or certified check, or approved bank issued letter of credit. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 3(B), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 3(B), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 3(B), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. III(B), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-58. - Application of deposit to delinquency. 
    After the due process on any delinquent bills, as described in sections 23-44 and 23-45, the user's deposit, or part thereof as may be necessary, will be applied to any delinquent city utility service charges, with all water service charges satisfied in full first, sewer charges satisfied in full second, and any balance remaining going toward other service charges. In the event such application of the deposit is necessary, or if the customer has ever had three (3) months of delinquent payments in any consecutive twelve-month period, a new deposit of twice the past average monthly bill for that customer or account may be required before service can be continued, reinstated, or granted to such customer or account at any location. The amount of such deposit shall be due and payable before service will be provided to the customer. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 3(C), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 3(C), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 3(C), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. III(C), 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-59. - Service request; additional requirements. 
    A driver's license or social security card must be produced by the person making the request for service, and the information thereon shall be kept on file. The customer must also sign an application stating that the service being requested is either for their own personal use or will serve property that they own or legally control. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 3(D), 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 3(D), 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 3(D), 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. III(D), 1-17-95) 
Secs. 23-60-23-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TAPS AND LINE EXTENSIONS 

Sec. 23-71. - Applications. 
    Taps may be requested only for a specific location and shall only be issued in conjunction with a building permit. The specific type of use for the tap, such as residential, commercial, office, industrial, etc., must be stated in the application. 
(Ord. No. 849, Art. 2, § 2, 11-11-92; Ord. No. 874, Art. 2, § 2, 8-17-93; Ord. No. 892, Art. 2, § 2, 1-17-95; Ord. No. 896, Art. II, § 2, 1-17-95) 
Sec. 23-72. - Fees. 
    The tap fees (or connection fees) shown in Table 4 shall be charged to each user connecting to the water system or sewer system of the city. These fees are nonrefundable.

(a)  Water tap fees:

No contractor installations may be made without prior approval by the city of the specific contractor making the tap, and then the tap shall only be made with a city inspector on site at the time the tap is made.
